editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: AN HISTORICAL AND Geographical Account OF THE MOREA, NEGROPONT, AND THE Maritime Places, AS FAR AS THESSALONICA.
Illu≈øtrated with 42 Maps of the Countries, Plains, and Draughts of the Cities, Towns and Fortifications.
Written in Italian by P. M. Coronelli, Geographer to the Republick of Venice.
Engli≈øhed by R. W. Gent.
London, Printed for Matth. Gillyflower at the Spread-Eagle in We≈øtmin≈øter-Hall, and W. Canning at his Shop in Vine-Court in the Middle Temple, 1687.

div.head: THE PUBLISHER TO THE READER.
div.p:
THis Book having been Publi≈øhed in Italian in the Year 1685. by the Ingenious Coronelli, and the la≈øt Year in French with Additions, 'twas thought a Pre≈øent not unacceptable to give our Nation the Tran≈ølation of it in Engli≈øh, which how performed here we leave to
thy candid Judgment. The Draughts of the Cities, Towns and Fortifications, having already received ≈øufficient Approbation.

As to the Book it ≈øelf, we dare promi≈øe the Reader Diver≈øion and Plea≈øure mixt with Profit, let his Genius be what it will. The Sons of Mars will with Warmth and Action read of the glorious Victories, and even envy the glittering Fame of tho≈øe Noble Hero's that ≈øleep in the Bed of Honour. The Poetick Fancy will be diverted with the old Fictions, like ≈øweet Flowers ≈øtrewed over
the whole, and the grave Mythologi≈øt with their Morals. The Antiquary and Hi≈øtorian will find Entertainment in the Melancholyplea≈øing Remains of pa≈øt State and Glory, that were once the Scenes of the greate≈øt Performances the Mind of man joyned to active Bodies is capable of, and reflect on the Fate of human Affairs ≈øubject all to Time and Chance. The Naturali≈øt will meet with the De≈øcriptions of the Labours and Sports of Nature, and find ≈øome Account of the hitherto puzling Tides of the Euripus. Nor will the
≈øolid Mathematician lo≈øe his Time, but with ≈øatisfaction behold the Views of Cities, Plains of Fortifications, and Charts of Shores, Rocks and Seas: But we refer to the Book it ≈øelf. Farewel.

div.head: PART I. VVherein is ≈øhown, That the Morea is a Penin≈øula; the different Names by which it has been called; its Extent and Figure; the Divi≈øions that the Ancients and Moderns have made of the Provinces contained in it: with a Di≈øcour≈øe of its Con≈øines and Frontiers; and at the End, ≈øeveral Curious Relations are added upon the ≈øame Subject.
div.p:
IF a Land ≈øurrounded by the Sea, except a ≈ømall I≈øthmus, that joyns it to the Continent, may be called a Cher≈øone≈øus, or Penin≈øula, the Morea may ju≈øtly be ≈øo reckoned, ≈øince being on all ≈øides environed
by the Sea, 'tis at the North only joyned to Achaia, by the I≈øthmus of Corinth.

This plea≈øant part of Greece has not always had the Name of Morea, as 'tis now commonly called; but formerly, Argos, Apia, and Peloponne≈øus. Its Figure well enough re≈øembling the Leaf of a Mulberry, or Plane-tree, gave ≈øufficient ground to the later Emperors of Con≈øtantinople to entitle it Morea; tho' ≈øome will not a≈ø≈øent to this, but pretend to derive the Name from Romea, which by a tran≈øpo≈øition of the Letters was changed into Morea, grounding them≈øelves upon this, That the Greeks, while ≈øubject to the Empire of Con≈øtantinople, and that City was ≈øtiled New Rome Which Name it kept till Con≈øtantine the Great., were them≈øelves al≈øo called Romei, as much as to ≈øay, Romans. Doglioni thinks that it took this Name when invaded by the Moors. Strabo in≈øinuates, that it was anciently called Argo, or Argos, from a famous City of that Name within its Confines; and Aegialea from Aegialus, a renowned King of the Sicyonians. According to Compend. Hi≈øt. ∆≤niv. di Nic. ∆≤ dogl. p. 11. Apollodorus, and Pliny, it had the Name of Apia from Apis, the Third
King of the Argives, who reigned from about the year of the World's Creation, 2307. to the year 2342. that is 1647. years before the Nativity of Chri≈øt. This Apis was the Son of Egialus. Four hundred and twenty years after, it had the Name of Peloponne≈øus, from Pelops, Son of Tantalus, King of Phrygia and Taygeta, a Man ≈øufficiently famous for his Ivory ≈øhoulder, and Ince≈øts with his own Daughters. Its bounds (which, as we ≈øaid, are of the ≈øhape of a Plane-tree Leaf), are ≈øixt between the end of the 35. degree, and beginning of the 38. degree of North Latitude, and at the Extremities of the degrees 37, and 51. of Longitude, taking the mo≈øt We≈øt part of the I≈øle of Ferro for the fir≈øt Meridian.

As to its Circum≈øerence, Authors di≈øagree, ≈øome making it bigger, others le≈øs. I≈øidore allows its Circuit to be 363. Miles; Bourdon extends it to 563. Porchacchi adds Ten more, a≈ø≈øuring us, that it is 573. Miles round: Blean, Sagredo, and Vianoli, a≈ø≈øign it 600. Baudrand, a Geographer, of our time, makes it but 550. Miles.

Strabo makes its length 1400. Stadia; and Sagredo agrees with him, making 170. Miles from the I≈øthmus to Modon. Baudrand makes it five Miles longer from the Cape of Schilli to the Ca≈øtle Torne≈øe, and takes its breadth, which, according to him, exceeds not 150. Miles between Corinth and the Cape of Matapan.

The mo≈øt skillful Geographers de≈øcribing this delicious Penin≈øule, have employed the greate≈øt accuracy in di≈øtingui≈øhing tho≈øe parts from the re≈øt, whereon Nature has been at the greate≈øt expence for Embelli≈øhments, that they might the more advance its Glory and Reputation. As Pau≈øanias reports, it was once divided into five parts, the fir≈øt containing Arcadia, the ≈øecond Achaia, the third Doria, &c. Ptolemy, and others, divided it into Eight Provinces; viz. Achaia, properly ≈øo call'd, Arcadia, Argos, Corinthia, Elis, Laconia, Me≈ø≈øenia, and Sicyonia, or Sicyonis.

Achaia was bounded on the North with the Gulf of Lepanto, on the We≈øt with the Ionian Sea, on the South with Elis and Arcadia, and on the East
with Sicyonia. Patras was then its capital City.

Arcadia being up in the Countrey, and by con≈øequence di≈øtant from the Sea, had for its Ea≈øtern boundaries Argos and Laconia, with the Mountain Oronio; Elis and Mount Flora for the We≈øtern; on the North, Achaia proper, and Mount Skinfali; and on the South, Me≈ø≈øenia, and the Mountain Taygeta. Its principal City was Megalopolis; that is, the great Arta ≈øituated at the foot of Mount Coronio, called at this ‚Ä¢ ime El Ce≈øal Londari.

Argos he ‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ the Ea≈øt the Gulf of Napoli di ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ mania, and the Aegean
‚Ä¢ ea; on the West, Arcadia; on the
‚Ä¢ outh, Laconia, and on the North, the Gulf of Engia, or Sinus Sardonicus. Ar
‚Ä¢ os was its chief City.

Corinthia, which was the mo≈øt Nor
‚Ä¢ hern part of Peloponne≈øus, was extended ‚Ä¢ etween Sicyonia We≈øtward, and Argos ‚Ä¢ outh and Ea≈øtward; and was ≈øepara
‚Ä¢ ed from Achaia by the I≈øthmus and Gulf of Lepanto. It took its Name ‚Ä¢ om Corinthus, the Son of Jupiter, or ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
Ephipeus, who al≈øo gave a Name to ‚Ä¢ e Capital City.

Elis bordered on the North upon Achaia, properly ≈øo called; on the Ea≈øt upon Arcadia, on the South upon Me≈ø≈øenia, and on the We≈øt upon the Ionian Sea. Polybius and Strabo name this likewi≈øe Elea and Cauconia. Its principal City was al≈øo called Elis.

Laconia had for its Southern Limits partly the Gulf of Colochina, and partly that of Coron; for its Ea≈øtern, the Gulf of Napoli di Romania; for its Northern, Arcadia; and for the We≈øtern, Me≈ø≈øenia. Sparta was its chief City.

The South of Me≈ø≈øenia was between Laconia towards the Ea≈øt‚ñ™
‚Ä¢ nd Elis towards the We≈øt: it had Arcadia on the North, and contained all that ≈øpace between the Gulfs of Coron and Zonchio. Me≈ø≈øene was the principal City.

Sicyonia, or Sicyonis, which was the lea≈øt of the Provinces, took the Name from its capital City called likewi≈øe Sicyon. It bordered Ea≈øtwards on Corinthia, We≈øtward on Achaia; the Gulf o ‚Ä¢
Corinth was on its North, and Arcad ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
on the South.

Pomponius Mela divides the whol ‚Ä¢
Lib. 2. cap. 3. Morea into ≈øix Provinces; viz. Argo ‚Ä¢ Laconia, Me≈ø≈øenia, Achaia, Elis, and Arcadia.
At this time Morri and Baudrand make but four Provinces of it: and this Divi≈øion is likewi≈øe approved of by the Learned Cautelli, in his Geography, received with general Applau≈øe.

The fir≈øt of th ‚Ä¢ ≈øe four Provinces comprehends the whole Extent of Achaia proper Sicyonia, and Corinth, and is called the Duche of Chiarenza. Its Northern bound is the Gulf of Lepanto; and on the South the Province of Belvedere. This Province has ≈øeveral Cities and Towns. Patras is its chief City, after which Chiarenza, Caminitza, Ca≈øtel-Torne≈øo claim their places: but we ≈øhall re≈øerve their de≈øcription to the Second Part, where we will give particular Informations of the whole Countrey.
Its mo≈øt noted Promontories are the Cape de Rio, of which we will ≈øpeak when we come to treat of the Gulf of Patras.

Another is the Cape by Bourdon, called the Cape de Chiarenza, and by Pto
‚Ä¢ emy and Strabo, Araxis Promontorium, which extends it ≈øelf into the Ionian
Sea, not far from the Mouth of the River Lari≈ø≈øus, between the Gulfs of Patras and Chiarenza.

The la≈øt, lying Southward, is Cape Torne≈øo, which Strabo called Chelonates Promontorium, Thevet Cape Thorice, and Sophianus Cape Chlumutzi. This likewi≈øe ≈øtretches it ≈øelf into the Ionian Sea, between the Gulf of Chiarenza and that of Arcadia.

The ≈øecond Province termed Belvedere, reaches where Elis and Me≈ø≈øenia were formerly: It confines Northward on the River Carbon, which al≈øo divides it from the Province of Chiarenza; and on the South it is bounded by the Gulf of Coron; on the Ea≈øt it has Braccio di Maina; and on the We≈øt the Gulf of Arcadia and Zonchio. It contains ≈øeveral Countries and Cities, among≈øt which Modon is the principal, then Coron, Calamata, and Navarin, follow in dignity.
The mo≈øt celebrated Promontories are Cape Jardau, which is the Ichtus Promontorium of Ptolemy, and is the mo≈øt Northern of all.
Cap de Zonchio, which Pau≈øanias calls Corypha≈øium Promontorium.
Cap de Sapienza, or Cap Gallo, by Ptolemy named Acritas Promontorium.

The third Province is called Saccania, or the le≈ø≈øer Romania, and contains all the Ancient Argos. It has its North Confines on the Gulf of Lepanto, the Gulf d' Engia, and the I≈øthmus; its South on Braccio di Maina, and the Gulf of Napoli di Romania; its We≈øt in part on the Duche of Chiarenza, and part on Traconia. Napoli di Romania is the capital, the other chief Towns are Argos and Corinth.
The Palus, or Mora≈øs of Lerna, where Hercules killed the Seven-headed-Hydra, is a place very remarkable in this Province.

Though this Mon≈øter was but a Fiction, yet it is true, that there were Seven Brethren that lived in this place, and pillaged all Pa≈ø≈øengers, making the Countrey de≈øolate; again≈øt the≈øe Hercules undertook the Combate, and having killed the fir≈øt that encountered him, he di≈øpatch'd the re≈øt two by two, as they came under his hands. Whence
the Poets took occa≈øion to feign an Hydra with Seven Heads, and its Death from that of the Seven Brethren ≈øacrificed by Hercules his Rage to the ju≈øt Revenge of the Countrey.

This Province has but one Promontory, but that very famous, and known by ≈øeveral Names. It is called Cape Shilli, in Pliny Scylaeum, and in Pau≈øanias Plethon Promontorium, by Ptolomy Scillium, by Favolius Sigillo, by Sophianus Scylli, by Villanova Damala. This Promontory with its oppo≈øite, called Colonne in Attica, makes the entrance of the Gulf of Engia.

The fourth Province, which has changed its Name, Laconia for Zaconia, is the Braccio di Maina, and is at this day indifferently called by tho≈øe two Names. It much ≈øurpa≈ø≈øes the bigne≈øs of either of the three former, as it is al≈øo more extended on the South along the Sea-≈øide. It was at fir≈øt called Lelegia from Lelex, who fir≈øt ruled there as King. Virgil, and other Poets, call it Oebalia from Oebalus, Lord thereof; and, according to Strabo, 'twas likewi≈øe termed Argos. 'Tis
wa≈øh't on the South by the Gulf of Calamata, and in part by that of Colochina; on the Ea≈øt by the Gulf of Napoli di Romania; its We≈øt bounds on the Province of Belvedere, and ≈øome part of it on the Duch√© of Chiarenza.

This Province has many high and dreadful Rocks and Precipices, whence 'tis ≈øubject to frequent Earthquakes. The mo≈øt of its deep Caverns are found about Mount Tageta, at this time called, on the ≈øide of Mi≈øitra, Voutri tis Mi≈øitras, and on the ≈øide of the Main, Voutri tis Portais.

It breeds Dogs of good e≈øteem: Zaiman Ba≈øha, or the Grand Signior's chief Hunt≈øman, choo≈øes a great number of them yearly for the Sultan's u≈øe and diver≈øions: and there is ≈øcarce a Turk that lives at any Rate, but has one of them.
The principal places of this Province are Malva≈øia, Mi≈øitra, Sarnata, Chielefa, Vitulo, Pa≈ølava, and others; of which in their places.

Its Promontories are the Cape of Matap√†n, of which we will give a particular de≈øcription when we come to
≈øpeak of that of Maina. The Cape Onugnato, or A≈ø≈øes Jaw, di≈øtant from Cape Rampani about 200. Stadia; there ≈øtood once the Temple of Minerva, built by Agamemnon. The Cape of Malea bru≈øht by the South Wind from the Sea of Candia: It is famous not only for its exqui≈øite Wines, but al≈øo for its Shelves and Shoaly ground, dreadful to the Mariners. Ptolomy calls it Malea, Pliny Maleum, He≈øychius Promaleum, Sophianus Capo Malio. The Seamen (as Bredebachius ≈øays) name it Ale di San Michael, Saint Michael's Wings. Brichus calls it Capo Malio di Sant Angelo: according to Baudrand 'tis Ten Miles di≈øtant from Cerigo, 90 from Napoli, 70. from Sparta, and 60. from Candia. Mention Aeneid. lib. 5. Amor. l. 2. Baudr. let. M. Laur. p. 164. is made of this place by Virgil, Ovid, in the Univer≈øal Geography of Baudrand, and in the Greek of Laurembergius.

div.head: Of the Mountains of the Morea.
div.p:
AMong≈øt the Mountains of this Penin≈øula is reckoned that of Foloe, near which was once ≈øituated the City of Olympia, ≈øo much famed by the Poets for the Country of the Centaurs. The ri≈øe of this name was thus, Hercules having ≈ølain the Nemaean Lyon, and being Victorious over the Lernaean Hydra, and the Boar of Erymanthus, happened to go to this Mountain, where he retired into the Cave of the Centaur Foloeus, who treated him with a great deal of Civility, and entertained him with excellent Wine which he kept there hid from the re≈øt of the Centaurs; it chanced while they were thus Carou≈øing, ≈øome other Centaurs pa≈ø≈øing by, were drawn by the ≈ømell of the Wine, and running to the Den endeavoured to enter by Violence. Foloeus's chief endeavour was for an hiding place, ≈øo that Hercules was left alone to engage with all the Centaurs; he then playd his be≈øt, and gave them ≈øuch terrible
Effects of his Rage, that having killed ≈øome, the re≈øt betook them≈øelves to flight to carry away a wretched Life. The Combat ended, Foloeus crept out of his hole, and ≈øufficiently admired the Valour of his Gue≈øt; but by mi≈øfortune handling the Arrow wherewith Hercules killed the Hydra, he let one of them fall on his Foot, the wound was ≈øo deep that he fell down and dyed on the ≈øpot; Hercules much grieved at this accident, and in acknowledgement of his kind Entertainment buried him in his own Cave, and named the Mountain from his name Foloeus.

The other mo≈øt noted Mountains are Cyllene, Lyceus, Parthenius, Menalus, and Sepia; of all the≈øe Cyllenius is the highe≈øt, 'tis near that of Calidoria, at the Top whereof are yet to be ≈øeen the remains of the Temple of Mercury, from thence called Cyllenius; yet ≈øome will have that name to be derived from Cyllenus Son of Aleates. The Mountain Lyceus taking its beginning in Zaconia, is memorable for the place where the Tyrant Ari≈øtarchus was made an offering to the publick Rage of the
Lacedemonians, who there ≈øtoned him. It joyns to Mount Menalus, which is cover'd with green and ≈øhady Groves and plea≈øant Pa≈øturage for Cattel; a place for the coolne≈øs of its Shades, and refre≈øhing briezes of ≈øerene Air dedicated to the God Pan, as Mount Cyllene, who≈øe name ≈øignifies Maiden, was Sacred to the ≈øame Deity. Mount Sepia is that where, as Pau≈øanias reports, Epites, the Son of Eleates was ≈øtung to death by a Serpent. The Duch√© of Chiarenza has on the North the Mountain now called Poglizi from Diana's Temple which once adorned it; it was at fir≈øt named Geronte, then Skinfale from the name of a Nymph, the Daughter of Arcas, or from certain large Birds of Prey called Stymphalides, that live in the≈øe quarters in great flocks: The≈øe devoured Men, wherefore they were either cha≈øed away, or the Species quite de≈øtroyed by the ≈ølaughter Hercules made of them.

On the Ea≈øt ≈øide between Saccania and Tzaconia lyes Mount Cronie commonly called Grevenos, on who≈øe farthe≈øt Northern part ≈øtood the Temple of Lucina and Fe≈øipoli, ≈øo named from
the Idol to which the Eleans offered Sacrifices. Where is found the Stone called a Cylinder which may be taken from the Rock, when the thunder rumbling in the Clouds cau≈øes an agitation of the Air.

In the Province of Belvedere Mount Mintia or Mente now Olonos comes in view; its South has a Pro≈øpect of the Gulf of Coron, on the North ri≈øes the River Alpheus; it took its name from Pluto's Mi≈øtre≈øs, when Pro≈øerpina Jealous of her Husband, ≈øought after her and found her in this place, and changed her into the Herb Mint, a great quantity of which grows wild on this Mountain; and in Memory of this Act of the Infernal Godde≈øs, the proud Fanes of Pluto and Pro≈øerpina once ≈øtood there.

The little Mount Neris lifts it ≈øelf up in Saccania and Nonacris in Tzaconia, at the foot whereof roul the fatal Waves of Styx, fatal to tho≈øe that ta≈øte the otherwi≈øe clear and tempting Stream. The Poets make this one of the infernal Rivers; Inachus al≈øo has its ≈øource in this Province. There is likewi≈øe Mount Artemi≈øius, thought to be
Mount Parthenius; 'twas named Artemi≈øius, from the abundance of the Herb Artemis, wherewith it is covered.

The mo≈øt con≈øiderable and famous of all the Grecian Mountains, and that which Polybius compares with the Alpes is Taygeta, bearing another name now of Orta, it extends it ≈øelf in the Province of Tzaconia not far from the River Taenarus, very near the Eurotas that runs by Mi≈øitra; 'tis ≈øtockt with Deer, Bears, Boars and other wild Bea≈øts: It took its name from Taygeta, the Daughter of Lacedaemon, who being ravi≈øht by Jupiter, out of ≈øhame and grief for her lo≈øt Virginity, killed her ≈øelf there. At different times this Mountain has been Sacred to Bacebus, Ceres, Apolle, and Diana; and in its Entrails are found excellent Whet≈øtones.

div.head: Of the Streams and Rivers of the Morea.
div.p:
HAving di≈øcour≈øed of the mo≈øt remarkable Mountains of the Morea,
it ≈øeems natural to de≈øcend from them with the Streams and Rivers that water the lower Grounds of this Kingdom. Among≈øt the≈øe is reckon'd that in the Duch√© of Chiarenza commonly called Carbon, and by Sophianus Or≈øea; Strabo names it Alpheus, Ptolemy Alpehius, others Strimphalus and the River Nyctimus; into this ≈øtream One hundred and forty Torrrents, who≈øe Virtues are ≈øo extolled for taking away Tetters or other deformities in the Skin. The Poets have ≈øung a thou≈øand ≈øtrange things of this River; they would per≈øwade us that its Waves have a peculiar ≈øubterraneous Chanel under the Sea, and that pa≈ø≈øing the Arcadian Gulf without mixing with it; beyond the Strophades they ha≈øte to unite with their beloved Fountain Arethu≈øa, which is in the Territory of Syracu≈øe a City of Sicilia: This River receives ≈øeveral le≈ø≈øer into it, as Celadon, Erimantus and Amarinthus: It's name was derived from Alpheus. Tebba after the Death of his Brother Cercafus, flying from the ≈øury of the Arcadians and de≈øpairing of e≈øcape, his Enemies being at his Heels,
drownded him≈øelf in this River. It formerly had the name of Strimphelus from one of the Sons of the God Mars; one may well term it the Antaeus of Rivers, for after having ≈øeveral times ingulfed it ≈øelf in narrow Pa≈ø≈øages under the Rocks, it breaks out at la≈øt and ≈ølides with a ≈øerene Maje≈øty within its own Banks.

The River Eurotas is al≈øo in great Reputation, at this day called Va≈ø≈øali Potamos: Niger names it Iris, Plutarch Hemerus and Martathon; it pa≈ø≈øes through the middle of Mi≈øitra, and falls into the Gulf of Colchina; it has its ≈øource from the ≈øame place as the River Carbon. The name of Eurotas, ≈øo celebrated by the Ancients, was given to it from Eurotas the third King of the Lacedemonians, either, as, Pau≈øanias reports, for that this Prince made a new Bank to this River to keep in its Waters, that ≈øometimes u≈øed to overflow the Country to their great damage; or as Plutarch ≈øays, becau≈øe that this King having lo≈øt a Battel he had engaged in before the Full Moon, in ≈øcorn of the ≈øuper≈øtitious Cu≈øtome of the Lacedemonians, carryed
on by the height of De≈øpair, ca≈øt him≈øelf into this River; which from ≈øo Tragical an Event changed the name Himerus to Eurotas. As for the name Va≈ø≈øali Potamos, the Inhabitants ≈øay it ≈øignifies the Imperial River, which name was impo≈øed on it by the De≈øpots of Morea, who de≈øcended from the Imperial Blood, and for the mo≈øt part re≈øided at Mi≈øitra, for the plea≈øant Diver≈øions of Hunting, &c. on the Banks of Euretas, which the Lacedemonians called the Imperial River in flattery, and to enhan≈øe the Glory of the≈øe De≈øpots and De≈øpoenes, a name given to the Prince≈ø≈øes the De≈øpots Wives. This Stream is ≈øtill adorned with Silver Swans, which here come in great flocks to ≈øport them≈øelves; the≈øe are the more admirable for their extraordinary Beauty and Size, be≈øides their extream whitene≈øs; po≈ø≈øibly the Poets on this account called this River Olorifer, upon which Statius ≈øings,

div.head: Taygetique falx & oloriferi Euro ‚Ä¢ ae.
div.p:
And ≈øince its Banks were cloathed with Laurels, 'twas dedicated by the
Poets to Apollo; all the Summer it de≈øerves not the name of a River, for 'tis ≈øo ≈øhallow, that it may rather be taken for a pretty large clear purling Brook; but in Winter encrea≈øed by the Rains, it proudly lifts it ≈øelf up, and ≈øometimes overflows its bounds. It once had on its left the Country of Ormoas, which Strabo and Pliny call Acria.

There is al≈øo in Tzaconia the River Inachus, taking its ≈øource from the Mountain Crovia; 'tis at this time called Planizza, once Cramavor, then Haliacmon; in fine, Inachus, from the name of a Son of Occanus and Thetis. The cau≈øe thus, Inachus not being able to take the Ravi≈øhing of his Daughter by Jupiter, without repining and murmuring again≈øt the deflowring God, in puni≈øhment for his Murmurs was ≈øo tormented by a wild Bea≈øt, that he became be≈øotted, and precipitated him≈øelf into this Stream, which took its name from his death.
Between Inachus and Saccania are ≈øeen the Rivers Linceus, A≈øteria or Stella and Era≈øinus, which rapidly‚ñ™ wa≈øh the Foot of Mount Strimphalus.

We mu≈øt not forget the River Spirnazza, which is not the lea≈øt con≈øiderable: Stiled by Niger, Stomius; by Strabo and Pliny, Pamylus; and by Ptolomey, Pany≈øus; it di≈øcharges it ≈øelf into the Gulf of Coron near Calameta.

div.head: Of the Confines and Frontiers of the Morea.
div.p: THe Morea is bounded by the Ionian Sea, that of Sapienza and the Aegean; which are known by ≈øeveral names, as we ≈øhall ≈øhew in their order in the ≈øecond Part of this Treati≈øe.

We may take as a part of the Mediterranean,
Plin. l. 8. c. 11. that Sea which Strabo and Pliny call the Ionian, and which was likewi≈øe named the Grecian, bounding Northwards upon the Mouth of the Gulf of Venice, on the We≈øt upon the Borders of Calabria and Sicilia, beginning from the point of Santa Maria, and ≈øo on to the Cape of Pa≈ø≈øaro; its Ea≈øtern bounds are the Shores of Epirus, and the Morea from Cape Lenguetta
to Cape Matapan, and on the South it has the African Sea.
This Sea on its We≈øtern extent, on which ≈øide it wa≈øhes the Morea, comprehends the following Gulfs:

The Sea of Sapienza, which is al≈øo a part of the Mediterranean, takes its name from the I≈øles near Modon, and has on the We≈øt the Ionian, and on the Ea≈øt the Aegaean Seas: its South beating upon the Morea includes the≈øe Gulfs.
The Aegean Sea a part likewi≈øe of the Mediterranean, contains within its whole extent a great many Gulfs, we will only mention tho≈øe on the Morean Shore.

row.cell: The Aegean Sea towards the Morea comprehends

div.p: All Europe affords not a place comparable to this plea≈øant Penin≈øula, enricht by Nature with ≈øo many rare Qualities: Its fruitful Plains flouri≈øh with plenty, adorned with the charms of Variety; and its high Hills, which might be thought an unplea≈øing Object for their craggine≈øs, are yet made agreeable by the Verdant Crowns they wear of rare and excellent Plants and delicious Fruits. Its Inhabitants have a Genius fit for great Undertakings, and are in≈øpired with a Martial Soul: Its Cities have all once had glorious Founders; and its Climate is ≈øoft, ≈øerene and temperate.

This Place has ≈øtill had the Prerogative, and been chief over all Greece, and indeed its main Bulwark; a thou≈øand Illu≈øtrious Monuments pre≈øent our Eyes with Objects of Beauty, Grandeur, Magnificence, Splendor, and Glory; on the one ≈øide Sumptuous and Stately Buildings rai≈øe their
once proud Heads; on the other ≈øide we have the Melancholy plea≈øing view of the Imperial Seats of the My
‚Ä¢ enians, Corinthians, Lacedemonians, Si
‚Ä¢ yonians, Elians, Arcadians, Pyleans, and Me≈ø≈øenians. Arms and Learning have always been the two famous Pil
‚Ä¢ ars ≈øet up here among≈øt this People, of ‚Ä¢
Ne plus ultra to others. The Athe
‚Ä¢ ian School had here its Foundation, ‚Ä¢ n who≈øe Front were engraven the≈øe words Mater Sermonum, the Mother ‚Ä¢ f Eloquence: Here likewi≈øe, as in ‚Ä¢ he true Field of Mars, the mo≈øt He
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ick Captains of Greece have poured ‚Ä¢ ut their Blood, for never-dying ‚Ä¢ ame. War has here either been per
‚Ä¢ etual, or at lea≈øt frequent.

Among≈øt all, the Athenians have ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ew'd them≈øelves the valiante≈øt con
‚Ä¢ enders for Liberty; for from the year ‚Ä¢ 23. in the LXXXVII. Olympiad, ‚Ä¢ o the year 350. they ≈øtill defended ‚Ä¢ hem≈øelves, tho they had then lo≈øt ‚Ä¢ ome of their Power. This little Re
‚Ä¢ ublique (its Government being only ‚Ä¢ ltered) became after ≈øome Ages a ‚Ä¢ reat and powerful Kingdom; when ‚Ä¢ aving pa≈ø≈øed through ≈øeveral hands,
it at la≈øt met the beginnings and cau≈øes of its future Ruine under Emanuel the Grecian Emperor: For that Prince, ignorant of that Maxime, That the power of a Monarch is maintained by the Union of the Princes, and that a failure in this brings on the Ruine of Kings and Kingdoms, through a fatal Policy equally divided his Realms among≈øt his ≈øeven Sons; and by that ≈øowed the Seed of di≈øcord and inte≈øtine Broyls, which in the end produced the intire de≈øtruction of that Empire.

The Princes that had the Government of this Province were ≈øtiled De≈øpotes; and though there happened a frequent alteration of Governours, and tho≈øe of different Extractions, yet the De≈øpotate was ≈øtill continued in its Pro≈øperity; for the Election depending on the Emperours plea≈øure, he ≈øeldom promoted any to this Eminent Employment but his Brothers or his own Sons, or ≈øome other of his Relations, or great Favorites, who by their good Services merited ≈øo high a Recompence.

Con≈øtantine Sirnamed Dragares, Brother to Theodore the Second, was De≈øpot when Amurath the Fir≈øt made an irruption into the Morea, and began to exerci≈øe Acts of Ho≈øtility; a ≈øtop was for ≈øome time put to the proceedings of this terrible Enemy, but 'twas upon this Condition, which the prudent Emperour propo≈øed, of paying an annual Tribute, and with that price bought his Peace; a while after this having taken the Imperial Crown in the City of Con≈øtantinople, he divided the Morea between his two Brothers Demetrius and Thomas; Thomas had for his ≈øhare the De≈øpotate of Carinth, and Demetrius that of Sparta; there aro≈øe between the≈øe two Brethren an irreconcileable Enmity and Divi≈øion; po≈ø≈øibly being both equally ≈øwayed with a ≈øecret wicked de≈øign, that by embroiling the Affairs of the Empire, they might le≈ø≈øen its Glory, and thereby encrea≈øe their own, and obtain by its Ruine the independence of their Government: Thomas had gained to his Party the Albanians and Latins, who were equally at his devotion: Demetrius was a≈ø≈øi≈øted by the
Turks, and Turchan Beglerbey of Romania defired nothing more than to procure and forward the Ruine of this Empire.

The≈øe unfortunate Princes went one after another to make their complaints to Mahomet the Second; who≈øe aid they implored, and did him Homage, never con≈øidering that thereby they lo≈øt ≈øo much of their Power; and gave it up as a Sacrifice to him who wi≈øht but to devour them both: At la≈øt they came to be ≈øen≈øible of their Error, but too late; for Thomas perceiving that the Turks made Inroads even to his Borders, and ju≈øtly ≈øu≈øpecting a de≈øign to ≈øurprize him, was forced to provide for his ≈øafety by flight; and Demetrius was made an example of the Turks cruel perfidiou≈øne≈øs, and would have thought it a great Felicity if he could have prevented a mi≈øerable Captivity by a glorious Death. The fir≈øt fled for refuge to Rome, where in con≈øideration of his Royal Extraction, and the Pre≈øent which he brought of the Head of the famous Apo≈øtle St. Andrew, he received an honourable and advantagious
Entertainment. The other tran≈øported to Adrianople, by a malicious ≈øurprize of the Ottomans, was forced not to think it his greate≈øt Misfortune to E≈øpou≈øe his own Daughter, ≈øo to free her from the danger of lo≈øing her Honour with her Liberty.

The Virtues which have rendered Greece ≈øo famous, have indeed had ‚Ä¢ heir Birth there, but they could never have grown to that height, if the Republick of Venice had not a≈ø≈øi≈øted and ≈øu≈øtained them; for ≈øhe has al
‚Ä¢ ays been a good Mother, and ≈øigna
‚Ä¢ z'd her tenderne≈øs, by that ≈øtrict al
‚Ä¢ ance ≈øhe has always had with Greece. Tis an unque≈øtionable Truth as apears by the Hi≈øtorys of Venice, and which any one may be ea≈øily ≈øatisfied ‚Ä¢ n, that there is no Empire, Realm or ‚Ä¢ rovince in all Greece where the Vene
‚Ä¢ ans have not left ≈øome marks of ‚Ä¢ heir Dominion. In the declining of ‚Ä¢ he Greecian Empire, when it ≈øuffered ‚Ä¢ everal di≈ømembrings, the greate≈øt ‚Ä¢ arcels thereof ≈øubmitted to the Ve
‚Ä¢ etians; for under their dependance ‚Ä¢ ere Arcadiopolis, Rode≈øto, Adriano
‚Ä¢ e, Gallipoli in Thrace, and therewith
all the County about Preve≈øa and Arta part of Macedonia, the Province of Lacedaemon, and a great deal of the Morea; be≈øides, they were acknowledged Soveraigns of mo≈øt of the I≈øle ‚Ä¢ of the Archipelago. In fine, the≈øe were the Titles of the Venetian Empire born by the ≈øole Per≈øon of the Doge Dux Venetiarum, Dalmatiae, Croatiae, Dominus quartae partis & dimidiae toti ‚Ä¢ Imperii Romaniae; and if the≈øe Te≈øtimonies were not ≈øufficient to evinc ‚Ä¢ the va≈øt extent of the Venetian Empire, in Greece we need only bring an Epitome of what Hi≈øtorian ‚Ä¢ have related in ≈øeveral great Volumes.

The de≈øigning Turks having go ‚Ä¢ footing in the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions of the Provinces of the≈øe two Princes, de≈øire ‚Ä¢ nothing more than to invade the re≈øt of the Country, ≈øo to become ≈øol ‚Ä¢ Ma≈øters of the Penin≈øula. The Venetians only could put a check to the height of Ambition, which was altogether unju≈øt, e≈øpecially ≈øince they went about to violate the Faith o ‚Ä¢ Treaties, and break the Peace concluded. But 'tis a Maxime of the
Barbarous Nations, to count nothing inviolable, but the advancement of their Intere≈øts by any means what≈øoever, and take occa≈øion then to make War, when their Enemies think them≈øelves mo≈øt ≈øecured by Peace. Thus the Turks never making them≈øelves Slaves to the Religious ob≈øervance of the Peace, ≈øurpri≈øed Argos, and then behaved them≈øelves as declared Enemies. The Republick found by this fir≈øt Attempt of the Enemy, that it was full time to provide for their defence; and it being an Enterprize of great Importance, and that from Heaven only we expect the mo≈øt powerful Aids and an happy Succe≈øs, it was above all things re≈øolved that the Standards ≈øhould bear the En≈øigns of our Redemption. Then Troops were rai≈øed, and the General Command given to Bertoldo d' E≈øte: This great Captain armed with his utmo≈øt Courage for ≈øo great an Attempt, ≈øet ≈øail for the Morea, and landed with his whole Army between the Gulfs of Engia and Lepanto. He at fir≈øt applyed him≈øelf to get a perfect knowledg of the place, and to find means of putting
a ≈øtop to the frequent irruptions of the Enemy; to which end he began that memorable Work, and in few days fini≈øhed it, the famous Wall called Eximile; after which he employed his whole Forces in the defence thereof, and in a thou≈øand glorious Actions, gave Proof of his great Courage, and perfect Experience in the Art of War: Neither his Head nor his Hands were idle, he was the fir≈øt in all perilous Encounters, undervaluing his Life, ≈øo he might Sacrifice it to the Service of his Country, and at the ≈øame time forward the lo≈øs of his natural and ≈øworn Enemy. He was arrived to the height of his hopes, and his Troops animated by his Example, had already gained ≈øeveral advantages promi≈øing a glorious Victory, and entire defeat of his Enemies; when God, who≈øe Thoughts are not as our Thoughts are, and who when he plea≈øes can give the greate≈øt Conquerors their defeat, and Death in the Field where they expected to be Crowned with Victory, and ride Triumphant; permitted by the ≈øecret orders of his Providence, or Effects of
his Ju≈øtice upon us, that our General ≈øunk and dyed of ≈øeveral Glorious Wounds. The Head being thus cut off, the Members ≈øoon langui≈øht, and the Enemy becoming more ≈øierce through the weak re≈øi≈øtance they found, renewed the Combat with greater Fury, and gained the Victory; after which ≈øetting no Bounds to their unju≈øt Ambition, they ravaged and became Ma≈øters of all the Country, po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed for ≈øo many Years by our Augu≈øt Republique.

After which they e≈øtabli≈øh there a Governour of ≈øome Quality with the Title of Sangiac, or Morabegi, as much as to ≈øay, Lord of the Morea, and allowed him an Hundred thou≈øand A≈øpers a year, obliging him to keep a thou≈øand Hor≈øe with all nece≈ø≈øary Equipage, to be at the di≈øpo≈øal of the Beglerbey of Greece.

For all the advantages which this Sangiac enjoys, yet he is not without his Thorns in his ≈øide; for there happen frequent Di≈øputes with the Dins, the Beglerbey or Ba≈øha of the Sea, about certain rights he pretends to in all Maritime places, upon
all Merchandizes imported or exported.

Modon is the u≈øual place of the Sangiac's Re≈øidence: the Republick of Venice, who only to maintain their Rights in this Kingdom, hath ever Valorou≈øly been at War with the Turk, has been the fir≈øt that have attempted its Re-conque≈øt: and its Arms had ≈øo great Succe≈øs in the Campagne in 1685. as to be Victorious over almo≈øt all the Southern places, reckoning among≈øt the≈øe Conque≈øts the City and Fortre≈øs of Coron, the Towns of Calamata, Zarnata, Pa≈ø≈øava, and Chielefa: be≈øides the frequent in roads made by the Troops up in the Country, that were ≈øent to ≈øuccour any Fortre≈øs that was vigorou≈øly attacked; the Venetian Army will make this next Campagne a more advantagious Progre≈øs; which we are the more a≈ø≈øured of from this hopes, that its Arms are employed only for the great Glory of the Catholick Religion, and to promote the Ruine of Infidels.

div.head: OF THE MOREA.

PART II. Wherein is given a particular De≈øcription of the Maritime Towns, the Gulfs, Rocks under Water, and of the I≈øles, not only tho≈øe on the Morea ≈øide, and which are in this Sea, but likewi≈øe in the Ionian.
div.p:
AFter having in the Fir≈øt Part of this Work treated of the Morea in general, I de≈øign here to Di≈øcour≈øe in particular, and with all the exactne≈øs agreeable with my propo≈øed Brevity, of all the Maritime Places, of the Gulfs, hidden Rocks,
and I≈øles, as well on this ≈øide, as in the Ionian Sea. My Readers may take notice, that after having ≈øhewn the different Divi≈øions that have been made of the Morea, I agree with the Sentiment of tho≈øe who divide it into four Provinces, and that I ≈øhall refer to one of the≈øe Provinces each of the places whereof I ≈øhall have occa≈øion to ≈øpeak.

div.head: The I≈øthmus of Corinth.
div.p: THe I≈øthmus of Corinth, otherwi≈øe Geogr. Reform. Ricioli. l. 1. c. 16. called the ≈øtraight of the Morea, or the Argolique ≈øtraight, is a tongue of Land very rough and Stony; ≈øituated between the Gulf of Lepanto, and that of Engia, uniting the Morea with Achaia.

This I≈øthmus is famous for the I≈øthmian Games, in≈øtituted by The≈øeus here, and which were Celebrated every five years or Lu≈øtrum; as likewi≈øe for its Theatre, its furlong of white Marble, its Temple Dedicated to Neptune, and its Fore≈øt of Pines who≈øe
Branches Crowned the Victorious Combatants.

It were a great advantage to Navigation, and which would make it ea≈øie and ≈øafe, if a Chanel of communication were cut between the two Seas; and what might promote this De≈øign and encourage its Execution, is that it has been thought practicable, and attempted by ≈øeveral Princes; as Alexander
Pau≈øanias, Rannus. Nero would him≈øelf give the fir≈øt ≈øtroak with a Mattock, to make this famous Chanel. Zonora. p. 200. the Great, Pitias, King Demetrius, Cae≈øar, the Emperor Caligula, Nero, Herodes the Athenian. 'Tis true indeed, the≈øe Princes, diverted from this De≈øign by more important Affairs, or di≈øheartned by the tediou≈øne≈øs of the Work, have given it over, and de≈øi≈øted from bringing it to an End, that would much have advanced their Glory.

To ≈øupply in ≈øome ≈øort the want of Corinth was the fir≈øt City which put great Ve≈ø≈øels to Sea. Sabel. Hi≈øt. di Venet. deca. 3. l. 8. this Chanel, the Emperour Emanuel in the Year 1413. cau≈øed a Wall to be there rai≈øed, by Volateran and Niger, called Hexameli, by Hermola√ºs Heromilion, and by Ni≈øchius Dioclos, which beginning at Port 'Leche√© 16. Stadia from Corinth, 50. from the Gulf of Saronica (which according to Baudrand,
who differs from Lauremburgh is that which we now call Le≈øte Jocori) ≈øituated at the We≈øtern edge of the Gulf of Corinth, was extended to Six miles length to the Port of Cenchrea, on the Ea≈øt towards the Gulf of Engia; the Commodiou≈øne≈øs of the≈øe two Ports much advanced and facilitated the Ea≈øtern Trade.

Amurat the Second after the Siege of Con≈øtantinople in the Year 1424. notwith≈øtanding the Peace with the Greek Emperour, cau≈øed the Eximile to be demoli≈øhed. The Republique o ‚Ä¢
Venice highly re≈øented the≈øe Infringements of the League, and the Violences of Amurat, perceiving that by this Action the Enemy had an open Liberty of invading all the Neighbouring Countrys. Wherefore Luigi L ‚Ä¢ redano General at Sea, had orders to land at this place with his whole Army, who joyning his Forces with Bertoldo d' E≈øte, they employed 30000. There were 3600. according to Sagr. 69. Men with ≈øo much heat, that in the Year 1463. they fini≈øht the Wall in fifteen days, and added to what was before, ≈øeveral very broad double Ditches, and 136. Towers, which made
his Wall of much greater ≈øtrength ‚Ä¢ nd more tenable than it was before; ‚Ä¢ o implore a particular Ble≈ø≈øing, and ‚Ä¢ s it were an E≈øtabli≈øhment to this Edifice, and an happy ≈øucce≈øs to the Arms of the Republique from Hea
‚Ä¢ en, Bertoldo in the middle of the Wall cau≈øed an Altar to be Erected, where the whole Army a≈ø≈øi≈øted at Ma≈øs which was there ≈øolemnly ≈øung. The General at Sea and Bertoldo lea
‚Ä¢ ing a ≈øufficient number for the defence of the Wall, went to Encamp near Corinth, and there bu≈øied them≈øelves in planting Artillery, and fit
‚Ä¢ ing them for Service When the Spyes brought word that Amarbei Flambular of the Morea, had made an Inrode near them with a Party of 1200 Men: They immediately upon this advice, made a detachment of a good part of the Army, which was Encamped for the defence of the Eximile, and made ≈øo hot a fireing with their great Artillery on the Turki≈øh Forces, that their Commander was obliged to Retreat farther out of Gun≈øhot; though he again ≈øhewed him≈øelf about Noon to the Venetians, and
took his Lodgments not far from thence. Bertoldo ob≈øerved all the motions of Armabei while the other Geral went to pro≈øecute the Siege: But perceiving that the Turk ≈øeemed to de≈øi≈øt from his de≈øign, through the difficulty there was of executing it without too great a hazard, Bertoldo ≈ølighted him, and went to joyn him≈øelf with the other General to advance the Siege; it happened by a Misfortune, the forerunner of many others, that as ≈øoon as the General arrived at the Camp, he was ≈øtruck dead upon the place with a blow of a Stone, ≈øuch was the end of this great Captain; and Bettino da Calcinato who ≈øucceeded him in the Command of the Troops, found them ≈øo di≈øcouraged by this fatal Accident, and was him≈øelf ≈øo frightned at the approach of the Beglerbey with an Army of Four≈øcore thou≈øand Men, that he not only left the Camp before Corinth, but neglected al≈øo the defence of the Eximile, after that Wall had been rai≈øed with ≈øo great a charge to the Republique.

div.head: Corinth.
div.p: THe City of Corinth, which Strabo and Polybius call Corinthus, Laurembergh Ephyro, the People Coranto, and the Turks Gerame, had its begining and foundation from Aletes, who lived in the time of Cecrops King of the Athenians Anno 3066. 'Tis ≈øituated as it were in the mid≈øt of the I≈øthmus, in the place where the Ionian and Aegean Seas commix their Waves: It is the See of an Archbi≈øhop, di≈øtant from Patras 80 Miles, 50 from Athens, 85 from My≈øitra, 25 from Argos. It is Commanded by the Fortre≈øs of Acrocorinthus, which is near to it; it is ≈øo advantagiou≈øly ≈øeated, that ≈øome have thence taken occa≈øion to term it the Eye of Greece, others the Band thereof, and the Bulwark of Peloponne≈øus: Plutarch judged it the mo≈øt excellent, and Cicero the mo≈øt beautiful City, the ≈øplendor of all Greece; nay it arrived to that height of Glory, that Syracu≈øa and Corfu thought it an Honour to be its Colonies.

The Romans under a pretence of revenging them≈øelves on this City, for ≈øome violences committed upon ≈øome Roman Citizens ≈øent the Con≈øul L. Mamius Anno Mundi 38 18. to abate, as they ≈øaid, their Pride, with expre≈øs Order to raze the City to its Foundations, and that giving the Spoil and Pillage to his Souldiers, the Women and Children ≈øhould he made Slaves.

By the Bounty and Care of Augu≈øtus it was rebuilt and re-peopled, and again flouri≈øht in Riches and Beauty; but through the hard fate of the Times and continual devouring Wars, it can now only ≈øhew the mi≈øerable Remains of its pa≈øt Glories, who≈øe Ruines are now the A≈øylum to a few poor Inhabitants, forced by Nece≈ø≈øity rather than Choice to live here. It has been twice the Theatre whereon the Barbarity of Amurat the Second and his Son Mahomet has been Acted; where the Turki≈øh fury has been ≈øo Mercile≈øs, that at this day not above a ≈øcore of Hou≈øes, or rather Huts, remain; the ≈øad Image of its ancient Splendor: we may add that we yet ≈øee entire with their former
Beauty, 12 Columns of 5 Foot Diameter, with a ≈øimple Cordon, or Li≈øt for its Capital about 15 Paces from each other, ≈øtanding on a little Hill in the Figure of an Amphitheater, at about a Miles di≈øtance from the Sea; from this Hill there goes an ea≈øie de≈øcent to Port Lech√©, where as yet ≈øtands a Tower, formerly a Lanthorn or Sea-mark.

The Corinthians imbraced the Catholick Religion by the preaching of St. Peter and Paul, and were therein confirmed in the year 169 by the careful diligence of St. Denis the Second Bi≈øhop of this place, which they per≈øevered in, till the time that the Greek Emperours refu≈øed longer Obedience to the See of Rome.

Roger of Normandy King of Naples took Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of this City, and might have rai≈øed his Glory to a great height, if he could have added this Flower to his Crown, and gained the Hearts of the Corinthians to a willing Obedience, and have made them pay him the ≈øame Homages that they did the Emperour Emanuel; but when he was in the greate≈øt hopes of obtaining
this de≈øire, the Army of the Venetians with the Troops of the vanqui≈øht Greeks, ≈øo oppo≈øed his Conque≈øts, that after a defeat of the greate≈øt part of his Forces, he was con≈øtrain'd to con≈øult his own ≈øafety by a ha≈øty flight. The Rout of this Princes Army, and the Di≈øadvantages he thereby received were of great con≈øequence to his Enemies, as the rich Spoil of his Camp was very con≈øiderable, which was divided among≈øt the Auxiliary Troops, there being but little need to put them to more nece≈ø≈øary u≈øes after the regaining of Corinth. Scarce two Ages were pa≈øt before this City ≈øubmitted it ≈øelf to the De≈øpotes of Greece; they would willingly have yielded it to the Venetians, in con≈øideration that they could not otherwi≈øe po≈ø≈øe≈øs it than by u≈øurpation, the ju≈øt right thereof belonging only to the Venetian Republique, who had employed its own Forces and the Blood of its Subjects to deliver it from the hands of Strangers.

Mahomet the Second could not make ≈øo ju≈øt Reflections, who≈øe mind was uncapable of any thing but a boundle≈øs
Ambition, he re-took Corinth; after ≈øeveral great endeavours made by the Venetians to regain this Conque≈øt, they were not able to overcome the fury of the Barbarians, who≈øe long re≈øi≈øtance made them at la≈øt ≈øen≈øible of the nece≈ø≈øity of de≈øi≈øting from their De≈øign.

at the foot whereof is its The 21. of June 1245. Seli≈øtar Ba≈ø≈øa was taken the Port of Navarin, with a great number of Ships which he commanded for the Siege of Candia. Port, wherein two thou≈øand Ve≈ø≈øels may ride at Anchor; on the right hand of the ≈øame ≈øtands the new Navarin: The Ancient is a Fortre≈øs, which lying ≈øo much in the Eyes of the Enemies, has been no ≈ømall Temptation to them, upon which account it has more than once changed its Ma≈øter.

In the Year 1498. while ≈øubject to Baudrand calls Navarin Albaxinus, Nelea, Albarinos & Javarin; 'tis thought to have been the Country of Ne≈øtor. the Venetians it underwe ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ furious a≈ø≈øault of the Turks, who ≈øound there ≈øuch re≈øi≈øtance, that far from triumphing as they had flattered them≈øelves, they were forced to put off their Enterprize to another Opportunity, when they might ≈øucceed better by ≈øurpri≈øe, as indeed they did ≈øome time after; for being made Ma≈øters of Modon, the Inhabitants of Zunchio rendered them≈øelves as ≈øoon as they had Encamped before it: But the Venetians ≈øoon regained it from the Turks, by the means of one Demetrius of Modon, who with one of his Friends, an Albanian, undertook to put the Garri≈øon
to the Sword, by opening the Gates of the Fortre≈øs; yet the Turks ≈øtood ob≈øtinately to the defence of a place they had ≈øo lately gained, came with a re-inforcement on the ≈øide toward the Land, with a great Detachment of Cavalry, and with fourteen Gallies and five Fu≈øtes, under the Command of a Turki≈øh Officer called Gamali. The Republique had before ordered three Gallies for the guard of the Port. But tho≈øe who ought to have been watchful, never thinking the Enemy would have taken the fir≈øt opportunity of repo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øing the place, and being in a great uncertainty what to do, when they ≈øaw them≈øelves ju≈øt ready to be attacqued, left the Entrance free to the Turk, who with a great deal of frankne≈øs declared him≈øelf the Patron and Defender of any that would ≈øubmit them≈øelves to his di≈øcretion. But tho≈øe who ≈øeemed to be of his Party, in great con≈øternation at the change of their Fate, expo≈øed them≈øelves to the hazard of their Lives, embarquing them≈øelves in little Boats, and they were happy that got aboard five great

The Inhabitants of Zunchio were Spectators of all this Cata≈øtrophe, and finding them≈øelves attacked by Land, found no other expedient but to deliver them≈øelves up to the Enemy.

div.head: Modon.
div.p:
IN the Frontiers of the Province of the ≈øo fertile and plea≈øant Belvedere, lying in that part of the Peloponne≈øus which was the Ancient Me≈ø≈øenia, among≈øt the re≈øt of the Cities in the Archbi≈øhoprick of Patras the Epi≈øcopal and Staple Town, which Sophianus calls Modon, is reckoned: The Turks name it Mutum, and Pliny Methone, in Memory of Methena the Daughter of Honer: It is ten Miles off of Coron, an hundred and twenty from Napoli di Romania, and ≈øeventy
two from the Cape of Matapan: Its Situation favoured in ≈øeveral particulars by Nature and Art, makes it very ≈øtrong, and is upon a Promontory advanced into the Sea of Sapienza, fronting the Coa≈øts of Africk; at its Foot is a ≈øafe and Commodious Haven, where u≈øually re≈øides the Sangiac of the Morea, much re≈øpected at the Port for his good Government.

In ≈øeveral Ages this place has been expo≈øed to the A≈ø≈øaults of tho≈øe who, intending to make them≈øelves Ma≈øters of the Realm, have thought of gaining this City and Province; from hence it has happened that the famous Wall built at its entrance, and which for its breadth and ≈øolidity makes a con≈øiderable Oppo≈øition, has been oftentimes attacked and gained, and by that means the whole Province ≈øubdued, and forced to pay a Tribute to keep them≈øelves in any ≈øhew of Command. The People of Naples by means of the Spartans, made them≈øelves Ma≈øters of Modon, and to ≈øubject it more ea≈øily to their Rule, they placed there a Colony of their own People.

Some time after the Illyriaus entertaining an Ambitious de≈øign of enlarging their Dominions by conque≈øts, cho≈øe them a King, and having got together a very numerous Army, made an irruption into the neighbouring Countrys. When they came near to Modon, they gave its Inhabitants to under≈øtand with feigned ≈øhews of Amity, that they de≈øired but to buy the nece≈ø≈øary Provi≈øions which they wanted. Tho≈øe of Modon believing the matter to be ≈øo without any deceit or trick, took care to provide for them accordingly, ≈øome bringing them Bread, others Wine, and others Provi≈øions. When the Illyrians ≈øaw a great number of them without the Gates, they thought (as it really was) that they were ≈øo fool-hardy as to leave but a few to guard the Fortre≈øs, ≈øo they ran all at once to ≈øeize on all the Po≈øts and Avenues, and fell on with their whole Army with that fury, that they put a great many to the Sword, and made the re≈øt their Slaves, making the City a ≈øad Example of their Perfidie and Deva≈øtation. The Emperor Trajan touch'd with the Misfortune of tho≈øe
poor People that, e≈øcaping from the fury of their Traiterous Enemies, were returned thither, gave them Proofs of his Genero≈øity, granting them ≈øeveral Priviledges and Freedoms. After this manner they lived in a kind of Ari≈øtocracy till the time of the Emperour Con≈øtantine, who left Rome for Con≈øtantinople; yet when ≈øubject to the Empire they kept ≈øo much of their fir≈øt immunities, that the ≈øame form of Government remained; and as to the Homages paid the Emperor, they were rather protected by him, than entirely ≈øubjected to him.

In the year 1124. this City was Attacked, and taken by the Doge Dominico Michael, when he returned the third time Triumphant from the Holyland, over the Conque≈øts of Tyre and A≈øcalon in Soria, and of Rhodes, Scio, Samos, Lesbos, and Andros, in the Archipelago; and to the≈øe memorable Exploits may be added the entire defeat of the Army of the Infidels, when he rai≈øed the Siege of Zaffo. And though the next year this place returned under Dominion of the Emperor of Greece, yet in the Divi≈øion of
the Empire, Anno 1204. it again came under the Republique, out of who≈øe hands it was forced by Leon Vetrane, a Genoe≈øe by Nation, who was a famous Pirat; he kept it not long, for ≈øoon after being made Pri≈øoner on the Helle≈øpont, he was tran≈øported to Corfu, and there received a violent Death from the hands of the Hangman, as a ju≈øt reward for all his Rapines. This Death of their Head di≈øheartened the whole Party, and by that means the Captains Dandolo, and Promarino without much trouble became Ma≈øters of this Town.

It happened, for the common good of This was in the French Tran≈ølation. Chri≈øtendom, that whil≈øt the≈øe Memoires ‚Ä¢ ere printing in French, we received the ‚Ä¢ greeable news of the taking of Modon
‚Ä¢ rom the Turks by the Venetian Army, ‚Ä¢ nder the wi≈øe Conduct of the Valiant General Moro≈øini. This will much advance the Conque≈øt of the whole Morea, which ju≈øtly belongs to that Triumphant Republick.

div.head: Coron.
div.p:
COron has a ≈øtrong and advantagious Situation in the Province of Belvedere, the mo≈øt Fertile and Rich in the whole Kingdom, and which was part of the Ancient Me≈ø≈øenia, at about ten Miles di≈øtance by Land, and
twenty by Sea from Modon; on the right ≈øide of Cape Gallo, by Ptolomey called Acritas Promontorium; Strabo and Pliny knew it by the ≈øame name, which was given it upon the account of what happened when its Foundations were laid; for in digging they found a Sea Swallow, by the Greek ‚Ä¢
called Coronis, and as an happy Pre≈øage of future Pro≈øperity, they named this City from the Bird, Coron.

It was once a Bi≈øhops Seat, Suffragan Strabo l. 9. Plin. l. 4. c. 7. Giov. Bemb. Giu≈øt in Ferrari ≈øub L. C. Baudrand Moreri Hofm. Verdizz. Sagredo. to the Bi≈øhop of Patras, and at another time 'twas reckoned a Colony of the Thebans, which the Poets called Pedo≈øus; Laurenberg, Ni≈øi: and Pau≈øanias, Epea, and all the Ancient and Modern Hi≈øtorians make honourable mention thereof.

It makes the Figure of a Scalen ‚Ä¢ Triangle, and in one of its Angles i ‚Ä¢ a great Tower, built by the Venetian ‚Ä¢
Anno 1463. for a Magazin; the other two ≈øides, which are not wa≈ø ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ by the Gulf of Coron, leave a ≈øufficient ≈øpace fit for the Tower of th ‚Ä¢ Fortre≈øs, which is encompa≈øs'd with an old Wall of an unequal thickne≈øs flanked with great Towers, and a ‚Ä¢
≈øome Paces from thence on the North ‚Ä¢ de there is a Suburbs of 500 Hou≈øes.

Since it has been ≈øeveral times expo
‚Ä¢ ed to the A≈ø≈øaults of the Enemy, ≈øo it ‚Ä¢ as been often forced in different Ages ‚Ä¢ o pay Tribute to different Nations. Baudrand has thought it was yielded up to the Venetian Republick by the De≈øpotes, Princes of the Morea; and Verdizotti ≈øays that at the time of the Divi≈øion of the Graecian Empire, and in the ≈øame year that this glorious Republick, having made Alliances with ≈øeveral Princes, thought upon the gaining of this Kingdom, Coron was a≈ø≈øigned for its Portion.

It was ≈øurpri≈øed Anno 1204. by Leon
Lexic. Geogr. Baudr. ≈øub lit. C. Verdizz. fatti Ven. l. 7. p. 152. Veteran, a Genoe≈øe by Nation, and Pirate by Profe≈ø≈øion, who enjoyed not long his unju≈øt Triumph, for being taken on the Helle≈øpont, as we ≈øaid before, he was put to Death by the common Hangman at Corfu; who≈øe death being known to his Companions, all in amazement and di≈øorder, they ≈øought ≈øafety by an ha≈øty flight; at who≈øe di≈øper≈øion the Inhabitants of Coron after ≈øome ≈ølight Attempts ≈øubmitted them≈øelves to the Venetians.

Bajazet the Second Emperour of the Ea≈øt, all inflamed with the de≈øire of extending the Bounds of his Empire Anno 1498. marched with a powerful Army ≈øtrait to Modon, which having gained, he turned his Victorious Arms again≈øt Coron, which he could no otherwi≈øe win but by force.

In the Year 1533. the General Doria, who had under his command a Spani≈øh Armado of 35 great Ve≈ø≈øels, and 48 Gallies with a de≈øign of environing this City, cau≈øed a great number of Troops as well Spaniards as Italians, the later under two Captains, Girolamo Tuttavilla and the Count Sarno, and the Spaniards Commanded by Girolamo Mendozza. The≈øe three Commanders following the order of their General, began with fourteen Cannon to batter the City, and to gain Entrance by a large breach; but this Enterprize had not the Succe≈øs that was hoped for: The Turki≈øh defenders ob≈øtinately with≈øtood the Attack, and killed 300 Chri≈øtian Souldiers; neverthele≈øs tho≈øe Forces by Sea performed what the Troops by Land failed in: for vigorou≈øly following
the Attack they got the Wall, and ob
‚Ä¢ iged the Defendants to hang out the white Flag; ≈øo the Turks were permitted upon Capitulation to go out, Bag and Baggage, and the Troops of Mendozza took Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Place: ≈øome time after the Turks attempted to form a Blocus, ≈øo to regain the Town: it then fell out that the Spani≈øh Garri≈øon being unwilling to endure a Siege, ≈øhewed a re≈øolution of going out to meet the Enemy, and what oppo≈øition ≈øoever Maccian Novare≈øe, who Commanded in Mendozza's place, made thereto, endeavouring to divert them there from, by putting them to the greate≈øt Labours, yet he found him≈øelf con≈øtrained at la≈øt to yield to their Importunity; wherefore he marched out for that bold Attempt to attack the Enemy, near Andru≈øa, where they lay encamped with an Army of 3000 Foot, among≈øt which were 500 Jani≈øaries, Commanded by Ca≈øan Aga.

The Spaniards being come near the Enemys Camp, to give them the greater amazement, thought be≈øt to ≈øet on fire the Stables of the Hor≈øes, who being
inraged to free them≈øelves from the Flames, made a ≈øtrange noi≈øe, which ≈øoon gave the Turks the alarm; who putting them≈øelves in a Po≈øture of defence, and finding the Chri≈øtian Army weak and few in number, endeavoured to encompa≈øs it; then was began a very bloody Combat, and in the mid≈øt of the Pre≈øs the Valiant Captain Maccian fell down dead of ≈øeveral Wounds; after that blow the Spaniards began to ≈øink, and had been utterly routed if one of their Musquetiers had not returned to the Turki≈øh Commander, the like Fate which their own had ≈øuffered; by who≈øe Death the Turki≈øh Courage began to cool, and the Spaniards made an Honourable retreat back to Coron, where they took a Re≈øolution to embark and abandon the Place; and ≈øo the Emperor was willing not to rai≈øe new difficulties that might ob≈øtruct the making of the Peace in Hungary: After this manner that unfortunate City returned under the Barbarian Yoak.

In the mid≈øt of this Calm, and whil≈øt the Forces of the Republick were not employed about any great
Enterprizes, the Procurator Franci≈øco Moro≈øini, Captain General of the Republick, toucht with the Sentiments of Honour and his great Courage, conceived the de≈øign of making u≈øe of the pre≈øent opportunity to regain tho≈øe places in the Morca, which the Ottomans had ravi≈øht from the Venetians; for which purpo≈øe, con≈øidering that if once they were Ma≈øters of Coron, which was no difficult matter, a means might be found of carrying on their Conque≈øts; he ≈øet ≈øail for this City Anno 1685. and ≈øat down before it, but ≈øcarce had the Venetians approacht the Place, when a great Body of Turks came down from the Country, and took up their Lodgments within Pi≈øtol-≈øhot of the Chri≈øtians; by this bold Act the be≈øieged were animated to a more Vigorous re≈øi≈øtance, and it proved a great hindrance to the Valour and De≈øigns of the be≈øiegers, who neverthele≈øs de≈øi≈øted not from doing what ever they thought might advance the Siege and promote the taking of the Place. They gave Fire to a Mine of 100 Barrels of Powder, and were prepared
for the A≈ø≈øault, if any Breach ≈øhould be made, as they hoped there would; and notwith≈øtanding the bad Succe≈øs of their Mine, they proceeded to advance their Lodgments, and repul≈øe the Turks with an extraordinary impetuo≈øity. In this far advanced Po≈øt they defended them≈øelves by their Dragoons, and were reinforced with ≈øome Troops of Malta; but in the end, after above three hours Combat, they were beat back and routed, and mu≈øt all there have peri≈øht, had they not found a means of e≈øcaping the Pur≈øuit and Sword of the Enemy; yet for all this they carryed off from the Turks Seventeen Colours, and a Trophy of other rich Spoils: Being returned into their Retrenchments, to di≈øcourage the be≈øieged, they ≈øet up at the end of their Pikes 130 Turks Heads; yet this abated not the Ardour of the Turks, who, although in continual Action, that they had ≈øcarce time to breath, yet would entertain no thoughts of Rendition, nor ≈øo much as Capitulation, ≈øo much were they encouraged by the hopes of receiving a ≈øpeedy Succour; and indeed a great number
of di≈øper≈øed Fugitives and others got together from ≈øeveral parts of the Kingdom; or ≈øent from the Turki≈øh Army, came down, ≈øo that they were con≈øiderably encrea≈øed; and then they thought upon the readie≈øt means to procure a ≈øpeedy deliverance of the place. But their Efforts turned again≈øt them, for having attempted to force the Be≈øiegers in their Retrenchments, they were briskly repul≈øed by a terrible Volley of Musket-≈øhot and Granado's; and being then pur≈øued by a Regiment, and 200 Dragoons, they left 400 of their Men upon the place, and their Vi≈øier Calil Ba≈ø≈øa was found among≈øt the re≈øt of the Dead.

After this blow, which was not a little advantagious to us, our General making Reflection, that the Enemies were often refre≈øht with new Supplies, to the great di≈øadvantage of his own Men, whereof he had lo≈øt a great number, without any hopes of recruiting them, he at la≈øt concluded that the whole Succe≈øs depended upon the Defeat of the Turki≈øh Camp; wherefore he applyed him≈øelf to whatever might contribute to make this Attempt
≈øucce≈øsful and advantagious, he animated his Troops, took his Mea≈øures, gave Orders and ≈øaw them Executed ≈øo well, that he not only forced the Ottomans from their Camp, but put them to ≈øo great a rout, that flying with precipitation, there were a great number of them cut in pieces by our Forces in the pur≈øuit. They left the Chri≈øtians a con≈øiderable Booty, con≈øi≈øting of ≈øix Bra≈øs Guns and much other Arms, all ≈øort of Ammunition and Implements of War, 300 Hor≈øe, a great many Tents and Colours, among≈øt which the General-Standard, ≈øhewing, by the Hor≈øe Tails that adorned it, the Quality of the Commander, who was Machumat Ba≈ø≈øa, who had the entire Conduct of the Army, and was killed, as we ≈øaid before.

After ≈øo fortunate an Adventure, the Venetians found them≈øelves freed from the great Ob≈øtacles of the Turks that were encamped without the Place; and being Ma≈øters of the Field, they had hopes of ≈øoon putting the Be≈øieged out of all thoughts of defence. They prepared for a general A≈ø≈øault,
≈øpringing a Mine, who≈øe Effect ‚Ä¢ rought them to an Attack for three Hours; the be≈øieged with≈øtood them with an incredible Valour and Oppo≈øition, fatal to a great many Nobles and Valiant Souldiers, who peri≈øht there. This con≈øiderable lo≈øs gave a few moments breathing to the Attack, put the Courage wherewith they again fell on made the be≈øieged think it high time to come to a Capitulation, as they te≈øtified by hanging out a white Standard on the Rampart: Arms then were laid down to regulate the Articles of the Capitulation, but this was only a trick of Ottoman Perfidiou≈øne≈øs, who made a feigned ≈øhew of Rendition, to procure a greater lo≈øs to the Be≈øiegers, by a brisk and unexpected A≈ø≈øault: The Venetians al≈øo took a more firm Re≈øolution than ever to put an end to the Siege, which had already continued Nine and forty days, and having ≈øwept the Ramparts with their Shot, mounted the Walls and entered the Town, where being heated as they were with the A≈ø≈øault, they made a dreadful ≈ølaughter of all the Inhabitants, without regard of
Sex or Age. They found there 128 Pieces of Canon, of which 66 were Bra≈øs, be≈øides a great quantity o ‚Ä¢ Ammunition and Victuals.

There happened during the ≈øpace of ≈øo long a Siege ≈øeveral Remarkable matters that would make a great Volum. I ≈øhall but touch at ≈øome of the mo≈øt Con≈øiderable, and for tho≈øe, my de≈øign is rather to beget an admiration of the extraordinary Valour there ≈øhewn by its A≈ø≈øailants, who were di≈øtingui≈øht either by Birth or their great Employs, and fell there a Sacrifice for Glory; than to open our Wounds and renew our Grief for their lo≈øs and our Misfortunes: among≈øt others was the Death of la Tour, Commander General by Land, and Knight of Malta; of the Prince of Brun≈øwick, and of the Prince of Savoy: The≈øe Illu≈øtrious Warriours gave in the face of the Enemy ≈øufficient Proofs of the greatne≈øs of their Courage, an≈øwerable to the de≈øerved high Thoughts conceived of their Merit.

To the≈øe great Per≈øons we may add, as he ju≈øtly de≈øerves a more than ordinary
remembrance, that excellent ‚Ä¢ aptain France≈øco Ravagnini, but 34 ‚Ä¢ ears old, Brother to Girolamo;
‚Ä¢ e have been informed of this parti
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ lar Circum≈øtance of his Death, ‚Ä¢ hich alone merits an eternal remem
‚Ä¢ ance among≈øt Men. At the la≈øt Pe
‚Ä¢ ods of his Life, after having made ‚Ä¢ s Will for the di≈øtribution of his ‚Ä¢ ≈øtate, he earne≈øtly de≈øired, that after ‚Ä¢ s death, his Body might be buried ‚Ä¢ o where but in Coron, te≈øtifying, by ‚Ä¢ at, his a≈ø≈øurance, that the place ‚Ä¢ ould be taken; and nothing can ‚Ä¢ ore demon≈øtrate with what ardor he ‚Ä¢ u≈øt nece≈ø≈øarily go to the Attack, ‚Ä¢ an this firm per≈øwa≈øion of their be
‚Ä¢ g Crowned with an happy ≈øucce≈øs.

After being a little recovered of the ‚Ä¢ reat fatigues of this Siege, the Gene
‚Ä¢ al rai≈øed a Trophy of the great Stan
‚Ä¢ ard taken from the Enemies, and an Explication was made of the words ‚Ä¢ hat were upon it; with a general Ap
‚Ä¢ lau≈øe the Ornament of the Golden ‚Ä¢ tar was conferred by the Republick on his Brother Lorenzo, as a recompence for his great Services. The taking of Coron gave the People a perfect
joy and ≈øatisfaction, te≈øtified p ‚Ä¢
lickly by them, e≈øpecially in their ‚Ä¢
ving Thanks to the God of Arm ‚Ä¢ and Supream Triumpher, who ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ given them ≈øo great a Victory o ‚Ä¢ the Enemys of his Faith. The ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ accompanied by the whole Sen ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ with an Infinite Concour≈øe of Peop ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ went to the Church of St. Mark, a ‚Ä¢ after a Solemn Ma≈øs, Te Deum was ≈øun ‚Ä¢ and the ≈øame was done in all ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Churches with all imaginable Po ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ and Ceremony.

div.head:
The Relation of the Battel befo ‚Ä¢
Coron, by the Venetian For ‚Ä¢ again≈øt the Ottomans, the 7th. Aug. 1685. With the De≈øcript ‚Ä¢
on and Draught of the Standar ‚Ä¢ and Hor≈øes Tails, taken from t ‚Ä¢
Turks.
