div.p:
There were not above an hundred and thirty Chri≈øtians killed and
wounded, among≈øt which the Gene
‚Ä¢ l by Land ended his days; Com
‚Ä¢ ander la Tour, of the Order of Mal
‚Ä¢
a Captain, well meriting the Grief ‚Ä¢ f the whole Army; notwith≈øtand
‚Ä¢ g the lo≈øs ≈øu≈øtained by the Turks, ‚Ä¢ ey were not le≈øs ob≈øtinate in their ‚Ä¢ efence: Ours on the other ≈øide to ‚Ä¢ ve them more terrible Effects of ‚Ä¢ eir Power, made a furious di≈øcharge ‚Ä¢ f their Cannon, Bombes, and ‚Ä¢ ones; at the ≈øame time the Turks
July 30.
‚Ä¢ llyed again after their ≈ølight, and ‚Ä¢ crea≈øed by a great number of Soul
‚Ä¢ ers got together from all Parts of the
‚Ä¢ orea, and with the Forces of the ‚Ä¢ aptain Ba≈ø≈øa, again attempted with ‚Ä¢ eater impetuo≈øity than before, to ‚Ä¢ row them≈øelves into the Venetian
‚Ä¢ renches; but ≈øo great a di≈øcharge of ‚Ä¢ usket and Granadoes was made upon ‚Ä¢ em, that they were obliged to re
‚Ä¢ eat, and were followed by the Regi
‚Ä¢ ent of Colonel Bianchli with 200 Dra
‚Ä¢ ons up to their own Retrenchments: ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ this Action 400 of them were left ‚Ä¢ ead; but what mo≈øt increa≈øed their ‚Ä¢ ≈øs was, that a Cannon Shot took off
‚Ä¢ alil Ba≈ø≈øa Vi≈øier Commander General
of the Ottoman Army, and we lo≈øt but forty of our Men, yet all the≈øe lo≈ø≈øes would not abate the Turki≈øh Pride, and bring them to yield; for they knew where to gather a recruit of fre≈øh Troops, and omitted not daily to di≈øturb the Venetians in their Trenches. The≈øe frequent Attacks had much le≈ø≈øened our Men, who were be≈øides much harra≈øed with continual Action; ≈øo that doubtle≈øs 'twas very needful for the General to encourage them, which he did, ≈øhewing him≈øelf a fearle≈øs Example of Valour, being the fir≈øt in all Dangers and fatigues.

In the end this prudent Commander finding the only means to reduce the place, was to force the Enemys Camp, propo≈øed the De≈øign to the Council of War, which was approved of by them. He drew out of the Gallies 1500 Voluntiers, who under the Command of Lieutenant Colonel Magnani landed about Mid-night, and next day being the 7th. of Augu≈øt 1200 of them filed off to the left of the Enemys Retrenchments by the Entrance of a Valley, and the re≈øt of them went to the right; at the
≈øame time the other Troops had order to follow their Motions, to be ready to give them a ≈øpeedy Succour at nece≈ø≈øary places, ≈øo to favour and promote the de≈øign.

Twilight of the next Morning being come, two Barrels of Powder were fired, as a Signal, which was immediately followed with a di≈øcharge of all the Cannon, and ≈øurious Salvo of all the Musketeers, with a continual ≈øiring on the Front and Flank of the Enemies Camp. This brisk and unexpected A≈ø≈øault put the Turks into an extream di≈øorder, and the forwarde≈øt of them began to give back and ≈øly, without being able to be retained by the Example of the mo≈øt fearle≈øs, or the Commands of their Officers; all yield, and the Venetians find no more re≈øi≈øtance, but make a continual Butchery of the Turks, ≈øcarce any e≈øcaping their Swords. The Event was ≈øuch, that the Victory which the Venetians gained in a very ≈øhort time, was accompanied with the entire Defeat of their Enemies, and the Ground was all covered with dead and dying Men,
and Streams of the unbelieving Blood ran down; in this Action but few of the Chri≈øtians were lo≈øt or wounded.

A very rich Booty was found in the Turks Camp of Artillery, Arms, Ammunition and Provi≈øion, with above 300 Hor≈øes, Tents, Standards, ≈øix Bra≈øs Guns, three whereof were marked with St. Mark of Venice, be≈øides the≈øe the Imperial Standard adorned with Hor≈øe Tails, the mark of a general Command and a numerous Army.

By the order of the Senate this Monument of their Victory was de≈øigned for the Church of the Tolentins of Venice, to be there for ever expo≈øed to the Eyes of the People, over the Altar of St. Gaetan, as an Eternal Memorial that this Saints Fe≈øtival was the day whereon the Venetians had ≈øo Glorious a Succe≈øs again≈øt the Infidels; and at the ≈øame time it was Decreed that every year on the ≈øame day, this Fe≈øtival ≈øhould be kept with all the Solemnity po≈ø≈øible, conformable to what was then done. The mo≈øt Serene Doge, with
the whole Senate and a general Concour≈øe of all the City, went on Wedne≈øday the Twelfth of September, carrying the Standard with the Tails to that Church, where they ≈øung a Te Deum, and a ≈øolemn Ma≈øs was Celebrated in Thanks to God, to the great Comfort and Edification of the People.

The Figure which we have given repre≈øents the Magnificence of the Standard, and form of the Batons and Tails; the whole was de≈øigned and graved with ≈øo much care and exactne≈øs, that one who has the Skill of Blazonry, will ea≈øily comprehend not only its Grandeur, but likewi≈øe the Colours of this Standard; wherefore 'tis needle≈øs to particulari≈øe it here: It was thought be≈øt to oblige the Curious with the interpretation of the Turki≈øh Characters that make the Moon, and the Faces of the Lance on the end of the Standard.
On the right ≈øide of the Standard are read the≈øe Words,
In the Name of the mo≈øt High and Almighty God, God the Lord of all, and of the holy Prophet above all other Saints, Mahomet Abubechir, Homer, O≈øman, Ali.
There is no other God but one only God, and Mahomet is his Prophet: Our God; thou art the God of Nations; thou art the Soveraign Good and Di≈øpencer of Good. Kalil Ba≈ø≈øa.
On the Face of the Standard are ≈øeen the≈øe Words repeated,
There is no other God but one only God, and Mahomet is his Prophet.

The Turks ≈øhew the≈øe Tails as a ≈øign of their Re≈øolution, to make new Levies, and that a great Army will march; and afterwards they give them to him that is to be the Commander in chief, as a ≈øign of good Augury. This Cu≈øtom took its ri≈øe among≈øt them, from an Adventure that happened to them, when they fir≈øt began to e≈øtabli≈øh their Tyrannick Rule out of their own Country. In a Battel their Enemy made 6000 of them Pri≈øoners, who took occa≈øion to throw off the Victors Yoak, and ≈øet them≈øelves at Liberty; and wanting Standards to range them≈øelves under, they thought upon, and made u≈øe of ≈øome Hor≈øes Tails for that purpo≈øe, ≈øince which time they have ≈øtill continued the Cu≈øtom; calculating the future by their fir≈øt Succe≈øs, and think them≈øelves, under the≈øe Colours, able to deal with the mo≈øt Couragious of their Enemies, and re≈øi≈øt their mo≈øt furious On≈øets. But as once when the Sabins, a proud and fierce People, planted their Standard in the Face of the Romans to affront them, with the≈øe words; Sabinis
Populis Quis Re≈øi≈øtet; Who dares re≈øi≈øt the Sabin People. The Romans an≈øwered them with an equal fiercene≈øs, in words beginning with the ≈øame Letters. Senatus Populus Que Romanus, The Senate and Roman People. So the Perfidious Ottomans will find their vain and ridiculous Sign oppo≈øed by the Sign that is revered in Paradi≈øe, which will one day procure their final Ruine, when we ≈øhall have made our ≈øelves worthy of this Favour from Heaven by our con≈øtant Prayers.

div.head: Calamata.
div.p:
In the Year 1659. there was a very ≈øtrong and numerous Garri≈øon, who hindred Six thou≈øand of the Magnotes who performed the Greek Rites, from ≈øhaking off the Barbarian Yoak, as they de≈øigned; they offered them≈øelves to General Moro≈øini, and te≈øtified their great Zeal that they always had toward the Republick. The General re≈øpecting their Generous inclination, and to take away all impediment of their deliverance, cau≈øed a ≈øufficient number of Forces to land, under the Command of Chevalier de Gremouille, who cau≈øed them to advance to Attack the Ca≈øtle; it happened at the time when our Troops drew near it, that they were met by a great Body of Turks that ha≈øted to its Succour. Captain Georgio
Cornaro had the Fortune to rout them, and that this Succe≈øs might procure another of more importance, he cau≈øed ≈øome Venetians to enter into the Ca≈øtle, together with the Turks, as if they had been all one; tho≈øe of the Garri≈øon never perceiving the Stratagem till it was too late to hinder its ≈øad Effects, ≈øo that they thought only upon flight; and thus they became Ma≈øters of the place without ≈øtriking a blow. They found in the place a great Provi≈øion of Victuals, and after they had taken as much as they could di≈øpo≈øe of, and burnt the re≈øt, with a good part of the Country, they left the Ca≈øtle and returned to their Ships, leaving the place to be reinhabited by the Turks.

This place was again taken by the Venetians, on the day of the Exaltation of the holy Cro≈øs, Anno 1685. under the command of the ≈øame General Moro≈øini; he made Governour there, Baron General Degenfeld, who ‚Ä¢ fterwards had Orders to raze it to the Ground. The Plan we give thereof repre≈øents it as it was when it was taken.

div.head: Zarnata.
div.p:
ZArnata is a Fortre≈øs much favoured by Nature, but made much ‚Ä¢ ore con≈øiderable by Art; its Figure ‚Ä¢ almo≈øt round, and its Situation on ‚Ä¢ very plea≈øant Hill: in the Year 1685. ‚Ä¢ he Captain Pa≈ø≈øa encamped within ‚Ä¢ ive Miles of this place, and though he had a numerous and powerful Army, yet he contented him≈øelf in be
‚Ä¢ ng an admirer of the Valour and Forces of the Venetian Army, without daring to attempt any Act of Ho≈øtility; willing rather to expo≈øe the place to the Enemy without Succour, than him≈øelf by defending it to a Ruin, which he thought inevitable: After this manner the Gari≈øon delivered it ≈øelf up to General Moro≈øini, upon Conditions that were upon that account exactly ob≈øerved; that they ≈øhould carry off their Lives and Baggage untoucht; for 60 of them who went out of the place the eleventh of September, were convoyed to a certain place prefixt, without receiving the
lea≈øt violence or in≈øulation from our Part. The Aga that Commanded them had no mind to go with them, for fear of lo≈øing his Head; but cho≈øe rather to ≈øubmit him≈øelf to the Genero≈øity of the Chri≈øtians, and being retired into their Camp, he obtained of Angelo Michieli Captain of the Slaves to ≈øtay aboard his Galley.

The General gave the Government of this place to two remarkable Voluntiers, in Qality of Repre≈øentants, named Bartolomeo Contarini, and Angelo Emo, leaving a Garri≈øon of One hundred and fifty Souldiers, under the direction of Lieutenant Colonel Pra≈øtini.

div.head: Chielefa.
div.p: It is not far from the place where once Vitulo ≈øtood, a famous Trading Town, from whence the Port that is near it took and retains the name of Vitulo, though it is now but little frequented, being neither commodious nor ≈øafe.

When General Moro≈øini was upon his expedition by War, to increa≈øe the Venetian Conque≈øts, he pre≈øented him≈øelf with his Army before this Fortre≈øs, and began to Attack it with great Vigour; but the Garri≈øon thinking it ≈øelf not in a Condition to oppo≈øe ≈øo great a Captain, endeavoured to procure a favourable Capitulation.

The fearful Turks made humble reque≈øt to the General to ≈øpare their Lives, and permit them to go out without ≈øuffering any Violence from the Chri≈øtians. A≈ø≈øar Pa≈ø≈øa, who re≈øided there in quality of Commander of the whole Province, went fir≈øt our, carrying the Keys of the Place to the Generals Galley, followed by a thou≈øand Per≈øons, whereof Three
hundred and fifty embarked them≈øelves on the Ships of Pi≈øani, ≈øometime director of this Fortre≈øs, who tran≈øported them, with what Baggage they had ≈øaved, to the I≈øle of Staggs.

After they had returned Thanks to Heaven, and planted the Standard of the Cro≈øs, and the glorious St. Mark, the General e≈øtabli≈øht for Proveditor ordinary Bernardo Balbi, and Lorenzo Venier for extraordinary.

div.head: A Relation of the Victory obtained by the Venetians, over the Turks; Before the Fortre≈øs of Chielefa, on the fir≈øt of April 1686.
div.p:
THe Ottomans have now made Proof of what often happens, when by endeavouring to regain what we have lo≈øt, we draw upon us new and ≈øometimes greater Lo≈ø≈øes. They intended at the beginning of the Campagn, to retake the Fortre≈øs of Chielefa, which the Venetians had ju≈øtly taken from them the year before;
confiding in an Army which they had gotten together of Ten thou≈øand Foot and fifteen hundred Hor≈øe: with a great number of Pioniers, they began to Attack the place, playing upon it with ≈øix great Pieces of Ordnance, fully per≈øwaded that they dur≈øt not, or at mo≈øt could not maintain the place long; neverthele≈øs they were ten days without much advancing their Works, or finding the Be≈øieged any thing inclined to Rendition; it fell out that the Venetian Army ha≈øting to their aid Encountred the Turks, and the Attack was ≈øo brisk and furious, that the In≈øidels betook them≈øelves to their Heels as their only refuge. The Defeat was ≈øo ha≈øty, that they left a very Rich Booty to the Conquerors; and a great many of their Men dead upon the place.

div.head: Pa≈ø≈øava.
div.p: PA≈ø≈øava is a Fortification ≈øeated in the Province of Maina, near the Shore of the Gulf of Colochina, upon Cape Matapan, oppo≈øite to Chielefa and Port Vitulo; its Figure is as we have repre≈øented it in our Draught thereof; it is built upon an Eminence, but is altogether irregular, and not in a condition to hinder the inroads of the Enemy into the Province.

Captain General Moro≈øini cau≈øed a Twenty fourth of September 1685. great Party of Magnotes to make an halt before this Fortre≈øs, at the ≈øame time that the Turks went out of Chielefa, to ≈øet up the Standard of St. Mark, but perceiving the Garri≈øon ready to march out, and ≈øtayed but to tran≈øport the great Guns of the place, he ≈øent a Detachment of five hundred Foot, under the Command of Sergeant Major Gregorevick a Forreigner, to reinforce the Magnotes, and hinder their de≈øign. The Turks di≈øcovering at a di≈øtance the
Venetian Colours, in a great fright and di≈øorder ran and left their Po≈øt. So we became Ma≈øters of the place without a ≈øtroak: It was not judged worth the leaving a Garri≈øon to maintain it; but on the contrary it was re≈øolved to raze it, which was the more readily concluded on, in that it was an u≈øele≈øs place, and that there was very near to it a ≈øtrait pa≈ø≈øage where a few Men might put a ≈øtop to, and engage a very numerous Army.

div.head: My≈øitra.
div.p:
AS this place has had ≈øeveral appellations, ≈øo ≈øome have cho≈øe to call it rather by one than another; it was at the fir≈øt called Sparta, then Lacedaemon, and at la≈øt My≈øitra; it is one of the mo≈øt famous of all the Graecian Cities, and has been of ≈øo va≈øt an extent, that in Forty eight Stadia make 5440 Geometrick Polybius's time it contained a Circuit of Eight and forty Furlongs. Its Figure was almo≈øt round, and its Situation
was partly upon an Eminence, and partly upon the declivity of the Hill. The Mountain Taygeta commands it on the We≈øt.

From that va≈øtne≈øs it once had, it is now ≈øhrunk to a little Town, ≈øcarcely ≈øhewing any remains of its former Glory: Although it had no Walls for Eight hundred Years, yet it maintained it ≈øelf very well again≈øt its Enemies, and of tho≈øe that afterwards incompa≈ø≈øed it, though they have been often rebuilt; there is now only the Ca≈øtle and the Foundations, where they once ≈øtood, to be ≈øeen. It has but two great Gates, one on the North ≈øide towards Napoli di Romania, the other on the We≈øt towards Exokorion, to which an≈øwer two High-ways or great Roads, one called Aphetais or grand Bazar, the other Hellerion.

The Inhabitants are expo≈øed to exce≈ø≈øive heats during the Summer: for be≈øides that the City lyes full South, being ≈øeated at the Foot of the Mountain, the Suns Rays by this oppo≈øition are reflected and redouble the heat.

The Learned Mon≈øieur La Guilletiere being ≈øome years ago upon the place, took the height of the Pole three ≈øeveral days one after another, viz. the 19. 20, and 21, of June, and regulating him≈øelf by the Meridian height of the Sun, by the Shadow of a Cylindrical Body, divided into a thou≈øand equal Parts, the difference of the Shadows at the≈øe three Ob≈øervations was unperceivable, and the length of the Shadow was ≈øtill found to be 211 Parts of the Cylinder; whence he concluded the Sun was 12 degrees and 56 Minutes from the Zenith, and the Latitude of My≈øitra 35 degrees and 26 Minutes.

The City is divided into four Quarters, each of which being ≈øeparated from the re≈øt, makes of it ≈øelf a di≈øunited Body. The Ca≈øtle is one of them, the City another, and two Suburbs the other; whereof the one is called Melokerion, that is to ≈øay the middle Suburb, and the other is called Exokorion or the outward Suburb, by the Turks named likewi≈øe Maratche.
The Exokorion is ≈øeparated from the other three by the River Va≈ø ‚Ä¢ li Potamos, and has no Communication with them but by a Stone B ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ge.

The Ca≈øtle named to Ca≈øtron is ≈øeated on an Eminence, is of a conical Figure, and has good Walls; it had ≈øome years ≈øince Ten Pieces of Artillery, and a Garri≈øon of Eighteen or Twenty Jani≈øaries Commanded by a Di≈ødar that ≈øeldom re≈øides there.

There are always Magazines well ≈øtored with Corn for the Armies u≈øe, for each Turki≈øh Family is obliged to bring his Corn in to renew the Store every year. There are al≈øo ≈øome Ci≈øterns, and in the mid≈øt of the Ca≈øtle a Mo≈øque, once a Chri≈øtian Church.
This Citadel is ≈øo advantagiou≈øly ≈øituated, that Hi≈øtories a≈ø≈øure us it was never taken, though Mahomet the Second and the Venetians have Attacked it with great Vigour.

It was a work of the De≈øpotes in the declining of the Greek Empire, and that becau≈øe the old Ca≈øtle ≈øeated
on the oppo≈øite Hill, whereof now the Ruines are only to be ≈øeen, did not ≈øufficiently Command the Town.

It is not certain who was the fir≈øt Founder of Sparta, Hi≈øtorians not yet agreeing thereon: Some ≈øay 'twas Spartus the Son of King Amiclas; others, the Prince≈øs, King Lacedaemon's Wife, who was called Sparta; many affirm 'twas Cecrops, who likewi≈øe founded Athens; and again others attribute its Foundation to Spartus the Son of Phoroneus, King of Argos, Contemporary with Jacob the Patriarch, 1763 Years before the Birth of Chri≈øt, ≈øince according to the Calculation of Father Petau, the Patriarch Jacob was born 1876 Years before the Year of our Redemption, ≈øo that to this pre≈øent Year 1687, there are 3422 Years ≈øince the building of this City; therefore it is older than Rome 983 Years, than Carthage 867, than Syracu≈øa 995, than Alexandria 1405, than Lyons 1639, and than Mar≈øeilles 1136.

There never was any Nation in the whole World that may be compared to the Lacedaemonians for Polity, and they never had a King but one of their own People; and the≈øe People only have ≈øeen upon their Royal Throne two Virtuous and de≈øerving Heads circled with the ≈øame Diadem; and often among≈øt them have been ≈øound Prodigies for Wi≈ødom and the Art of Governing, that they have been thought the only Politicians; and upon the≈øe Foundations 'tis that it could endure and flouri≈øh 800 years; it declined in its Pro≈øperity and Glory, when it lo≈øt Colemanes the third King of that name.

Finally, the Ea≈øtern Empire having been divided into Temata or general Governments, Lacedaemon was made an Appendant to the Emperors elde≈øt Son; ≈øince when it lo≈øt its name of Lacedaemon, and was only called Sparta; and its Princes who had under their Dominion the whole Morea were called De≈øpotes.

The De≈øpote Theodorus, who E≈øpou≈øed the Daughter of Renier Prince of Athens, and was Brother to Andronicus and Emanuel, who ≈øucceeded each other in the Empire; finding him≈øelf unable to attempt to re≈øi≈øt Bajazet, treated with Philibert de Naillac Prior of Aquitain, and great Ma≈øter of Rhodes, about the Sale of Sparta and Corinth; which Treaty was almo≈øt concluded, when Tamerlain Triumphing over Bajazet, the Spartans were ≈øo encouraged thereat, that they ab≈øolutely refu≈øed to con≈øent to Theodore's Alienation of Tzaconia, and the People being in a Tumult, the two Deputies for the great Ma≈øter, that were to take po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Government had notice that it was their be≈øt way to retire, or otherwi≈øe they ≈øhould be treated as Enemies; and ≈øo they lo≈øt Corinth again, when they were already in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion thereof, and Theodore was not well plea≈øed to refund the Money he had ≈øo lately ≈øingered.

At la≈øt he dying, left the De≈øpotate to one of his Nephews of his own name, Son to the Emperor Emanuel: this new De≈øpote married an Italian Lady of the Hou≈øe of Malate≈øta, upon which that Family grounds a right to the Duch√© of Sparta. Theodore the Second took a Re≈øolution to go to Con≈øtantinople, to ≈øucceed his Brother John in the Empire, leaving his De≈øpotate to his Brother Con≈øtantine; it was at this time that Amurath the Fir≈øt made an irruption into Tzaconia. Con≈øtantine being rai≈øed to the Imperial Throne, Sparta fell to Demetrius, out of who≈øe hands 'twas ravi≈øht by Mahomet the Second, who barbarou≈øly ≈øawed the Governour of the Ca≈øtle in two.

In the Year 1473 Benedetto Colleone, who had the command of the Venetian Army conquered Sparta, and had well nigh reduced the Citadel. San≈øovino ≈øhews us in his Hi≈øtory, that this City together with the whole Province was under the Republick, at the time
that Henry Dandolo was Prince of the Senate.

div.head: Maina at Cape Matapan.
div.p: OF all the Promontories of Peloponne≈øus, that which ≈øhoots it ≈øelf farthe≈øt into the Sea is the Cape of Matapan, which was once called Pliny, Senec. Ptolom. Promontorium Taenarium, in the Bowels whereof is the Cave Taenarus, who≈øe dreadful Mouth gave the Poets occa≈øion to call it the entrance of Hell; and they added that the invincible Hercules came forth at this pa≈ø≈øage, Triumphant over Cerberus; from whence they ≈øay among≈øt other Titles it had that of Taenarus, though others again will have its name from Taenarus, who ≈øprung from Elaphus the Son of Ieanus, who marryed Elemanda the Daughter of Dama≈øicles.

In the Year 1570. The Captain of the Gulf, Quirini, ≈øetting ≈øail from Candia with twenty four Gallies, came to Anchor at Corfu, where being informed that this Fort was built upon that motive we have declared, immediately de≈øigned to Attack it; but before he attempted it he went into the≈øe two Ports, giving the Magnotes advice of his Magnati Campana. De≈øign; who indeed on this occa≈øion gave good Proofs of their good Will and Courage. After a very ≈øharp and brisk Combate, wherein the Turks had the wor≈øe, the Captain became Ma≈øter of the Fort, and would not ≈øtir out of the Gulf, till he had taken away this Eye≈øore from a People ≈øo well inclined to the Republick: ≈øo having taken out whatever might be ≈øerviceable, he cau≈øed it to be demoli≈øht.

div.head: Malva≈øia or Malvoi≈øie
div.p: THe City commonly called Malva≈øia, which Ptolomy named Epidaurus Limera, and Baudrand after Thucydides. others Monemba≈øia, is ≈øituated on a Rock, from whence is a plea≈øant Pro≈øpect Ea≈øtwards over the Ancient Laconia, a Region rude and uneven, yet as Fertile as any part of Peloponne≈øus, this Province is at this day known by the name of Braccio di Maina, becau≈øe it extends it ≈øelf on the left ≈øide of that Arm where begins the Gulf, by Ptolomy called Argolicus Sinus, now the Gulf of Napoli di Romania.

It has the Title of an Archbi≈øhoprick; being ble≈øt with a very advantagious ≈øituation, for it is built on the Top of a Rock who≈øe Bottom is wa≈øht by the Waves of Archipelagus; yet it enjoys this benefit of Nature, that it has ≈øeveral ≈øources of ≈øweet clear Springs, which by watering the little Ground that is
about it, makes it ≈øo Fertile as to maintain the Garri≈øon of the place, con≈øi≈øting of 50 or 60 Men, it is inacce≈ø≈øible on all ≈øides, but one place where it is defended with a very thick triple Wall, at which place is joyned to it a Suburb or Lower Town, of a con≈øiderable number of Hou≈øes, ≈øtrengthened with a ≈øtrong Rampart at that place, where the Inhabitants i≈ø≈øue forth to go to the main Land, which is ≈øeparated from the ground whereon this Town ≈øtands, and is united thereto by a Wooden Bridge of a good length; it has likewi≈øe a very ≈øpacious Port which is better defended than the Fortre≈øs.
Its Territory bears a great quantity of Rai≈øins, and incomparable Wines are there made, not a whit yielding to any of the Wines of Candie.
In times pa≈øt the Graecians came from all Parts to this little I≈øle, to adore the God Aeculapius, who≈øe Wor≈øhip made the place famous through the World.

The People of Epidaurus when they were once deputed by their Commonalty to this place, as they ≈øailed from Argos, which was their Country then, had ≈øeveral Dreams which made them hope for an happy and pro≈øperous Succe≈øs in their Enterprize; and ≈øo being arrived at the Port, they determined there to ≈øettle a Colony and build a City, which they called Epidaurus; the Buildings are now wholly ruined by tim, that has been no more kind to that place than others, and the name is all that now remains.

It is true that time and chance rules all things, an example whereof is ≈øeen in the Fate of Malva≈øia or Epidaurus; for though its ≈øituation ought to render it invincible, yet it has for all that often by ill Fortune undergon ≈øeveral changes of Government.

In the time when it was ≈øubject to the Emperors of Con≈øtantinople it was taken from them; when the French and Venetians having made them≈øelves Ma≈øters of that Empire,
and Baldwin Count of Flanders was Emperor, this place was given in Ann. 1204. Fee to a French Baron, called Guillaume, as a recompence for his great Services performed in that War; but at la≈øt Michael Paleologus having di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed the French, and being rein≈øtalled in the Empire, he made the ≈øaid Guillaume Pri≈øoner, who at that time made a renunciation of all Right and Title to Epidaurus; the Baron being ≈øo e≈øcaped out of the Emperors hands came to Venice, and there made a donation of the ≈øame Rights and Preten≈øions to the Republick, affirming what he had done to Paleologus was extorted from him, and upon that account invalid, that Act being not voluntary, but forced. So the Venetians relying on this donation, ≈øet a great Army to Sea, and made them≈øelves Ma≈øters of Malva≈øia, which they kept till the year 1537. when Solyman began to pa≈øs the bounds of Thrace, to invade the Graecian Empire, and endeavour the ruine of Chri≈øtendom.

The Venetians mo≈øt re≈øented the≈øe U≈øurpations, and the Barbarous Conqueror not contented to have put ≈øeveral parts of their Dominions Ann. 1536. Paruta, p. 2. l. 9. to pay him Tribute, gave order to Ca≈ø≈øin, Sangiac of the Morea, to lay Siege to and to reduce this People; who getting together a numerous Army began to execute his Orders. When Solyman reflecting upon the de≈øign, that to Attempt this place were to hazard the Reputation of his Forces and lo≈øe time, changed his mind and turned his Arms another way; yet ≈øometime after he Ann. 1537. returned thither, and reduced the place not by pure force but by a≈ø≈øurances of Peace.

During the Wars of Candia and Dalmatia, when the Venetians, as much as in them lay, oppo≈øed the irruptions and violent inundations of the Enemy; General Fo≈øcolo being near Epidaurus with a Squadron of Twenty two Gallies, Eight tall Ships, and ≈øix Galea≈ø≈øes, went to Attack the Fort which the Ottomans had built without the Suburbs.
This Attack was very brisk, and the Venetians became Ma≈øters of the Fort in one day: but it happened as they put the Enemy to flight with loud ≈øhouts and crys, that a Mine took Fire under the Victorious, and left an Hundred and fifty of them dead, with as many hurt and wounded. The Venetians revenged the Death of their Companions, entring the place with their Swords in their hands, and having demoli≈øht the Fort, they left it, taking away with them Twenty two Cannons, wherewith the Enemies covered and defended the Saicks that came there to Anchorage in the Port, waiting till a fit time to ≈øet ≈øail for Candia offered.

div.head: Napoli di Romania.
div.p:
AMong≈øt the celebrated Cities, once the glory of Argia, at this day called Saccania or Romania Minor, a very rich Part of the Morea, Napoli pre≈øerves to this time the remains of its former Beauty; it is named by Sophianus, Napli, by the Greeks
M. Spon. Voyage de Grace, l. 2. Anaplia, and by Ptolomey, Herod. Xenoph. Strab. Nauplia; this ≈øtrong and trading Town was built by Nauplius the Son of Neptune, and Amimone in the innermo≈øt part of the Gulf, commonly called di Napoli, and by Ptolomey Argolicus Sinus, on the point of a little Promontory which extends it ≈øelf on two ≈øides; that which is towards the Sea makes a large Port and very ≈øafe, and the other is a great hindrance to the Commerce of tho≈øe that pa≈øs that way, becau≈øe they cannot climb up it but by one very ≈øteep narrow Path, which lies between mount Palamedes and the Sea.

The City is ≈øituated near to this place, and with very con≈øiderable advantages which it has on three ≈øides, puts as it were a Bridle on the Waves of the Sea; who≈øe Shores are ≈øo high and ≈øteep, that in all hazardous Attempts they ab≈øolutely hinder the Enemy not only from landing, but likewi≈øe from battering the Walls of the City from their Gallies; the Bay is very ≈øpacious within, but it is ≈øtopt up at its entrance, and no Gallies can get in till they have pa≈ø≈øed through a Chanel, where they are expo≈øed to the great Artillery. The City is defended by a Citadel well provided, and which being built upon a Shelf or Rock, about 300 Foot out in the Sea, cannot be Attacked on that ≈øide toward the Land, and the Rocks that ≈øurround it prevent all ≈øurprize: In fine, on which ≈øide ≈øoever one looks upon the Town, one ≈øhall find that Nature and Art have con≈øpired as much as po≈ø≈øible to render it ≈øtrong: Nor Baudrand. Hofman. Lauremberg. has it wanted its honourable Titles, for it was once a Bi≈øhops Seat, who≈øe
Metropolis was Corinth; and at this day it is an Archbi≈øhops it ≈øelf, and one of the Chief. It is di≈øtant Fifty five Miles from Athens; ≈øixty from My≈øitra; Thirty ≈øix from Corinth: It is the Re≈øidence of the Governour of the Province, in which are reckoned to be Sixty thou≈øand Greeks, be≈øides a great number of other Inhabitants, which according to Pau≈øanias were anciently Aegyptians, who inhabited there with Danaus, as in a Colony of their own. Napoli has ta≈øted of the ≈øame Fate with other places, to pa≈øs under the Rule of ≈øeveral Princes and forms of Government.

As Paulus Ranu≈øius reports, it was Paulo Ranu≈øio querra di Con≈øt. 1. 5. p. 160. taken Anno 1205. by the Venetians joyned with the French; but ≈øome time after King Giovani≈ø≈øa turning his Arms again≈øt this City, though he found it well furni≈øht with Ammunition and Men, yet he gave ≈øo Vigorous an A≈ø≈øault to it, that he carryed it; where at his entrance he gave terrible Marks of his Rage, for he put the Commander and the
whole Garri≈øon to the Sword, and Sacked the Town, which was at that time rich, powerful, and ≈øeated in the be≈øt part of the whole Romania.

Verdizzoti is of Opinion, that in the 13. Century this City being in the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Marie of Erigane, the Widow of Peter, the Son of Frederic Cornarus Pi≈øcopia, this Lady not finding her ≈øelf able to oppo≈øe ≈øo many powerful Enemies, that had a mind to the place, e≈øpecially Bajazet above the re≈øt, made a grant of it to the Republick; under this new Rule Napoli quietly let ≈øome Ages pa≈øs over, yet not without often ta≈øting tho≈øe Misfortunes, whereto all places are ≈øubject, that are the aim of the Ottoman de≈øire; for being ≈øeveral times Attacked by tho≈øe Barbarians, it often proved the Mi≈øery of want and Famine, together with the eating and tearing Misfortune of ≈øeditious Per≈øons, cau≈øed by the≈øe frequent allarms.

Mahomet the Second greatly thir≈øted to ravi≈øh it out of the Arms
of its lawful Prince; and thinking there was no other way to obtain his end, but by Arms, he gave Orders to Macmut Ba≈ø≈øa, to go and Be≈øiege it with a powerful Army; but this Siege was not Succe≈øsful; for having found the Defendants very Valiant and able to re≈øi≈øt him, armed with a con≈øtant re≈øolution to with≈øtand all his violences, he was obliged after ≈øeveral Attempts and great Lo≈ø≈øes ≈øu≈øtained to quit his Enterprize.

div.head: Argos.
div.p:
AS Baudrand the famous Geographer of our times reports, there have been three Cities called by the ≈øame name of Argos; one which Pliny calls Argos Amphilochium which is in Epirus. The Strabo. Second Argos Pela≈øgicum in Macedonia, and the Third Argos Peloponne≈øiacum. Of the two fir≈øt we will make mention each in their place; at pre≈øent we will ≈øpeak of the third, which was once called Phoronia of Phoroneus; Hippobote from the great numbers of Hor≈øes bred
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ere; Ja≈øia from the name of a Va
‚Ä¢ nt Captain; be≈øides the≈øe it was ‚Ä¢ lled Dipo≈øia and Jappia; it is the ‚Ä¢ apital City of the famous Argia, and ‚Ä¢ ckoned among≈øt the noble≈øt Cities ‚Ä¢
Peloponne≈øus. It is ≈øeated on the ‚Ä¢ iver Plani≈ø≈øa which the Latines name
‚Ä¢ achus, at Thirty ≈øix miles di≈øtance ‚Ä¢ om Corinth, Sixty from Sparta, and ‚Ä¢ ive from Napoli di Romania, it is the ‚Ä¢ at of a Bi≈øhop, Suffragan to the ‚Ä¢ rchbi≈øhop of Corinth; it has on the We≈øt the Mountain Cronia, on the North Cleone, and on the South the Ruins of the Antient Mycenia, rai≈øed ‚Ä¢ n the Ruines of ≈øome other Neighbouring Cities, it vaunted that the World could not ≈øhew its like for Magnificence; and there is a Tradition that from her all the Greeks took the name of Argives, as if to te≈øtifie that ≈øhe alone was enough to maintain the Glory and honour of the whole Nation at the greate≈øt height de≈øirable.

Its Rule began with Inachus its fir≈øt Founder, in the year of the World 2197. and continued for 546. years till Acri≈øius who was ≈ølain by his Nephew
Per≈øeus An. 2742. ≈øeveral Authors, a Patena, Clemens Alexandrinus, &c. ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
firm that this Inachus was contemporary with Mo≈øes; but Eu≈øebius ≈øh ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ the contrary, and proves that he li ‚Ä¢ e 346 years before the Children of I≈øra ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
went out of Aegypt.

div.head: A Chronological Table of the King ‚Ä¢ of Argos.
div.p:
There are Authors who be≈øides the≈øe, ‚Ä¢ ake mention of Megaphentas, Anax
‚Ä¢ goras, Melampus and Bias, which they ‚Ä¢ dd to the Kings of Argos.

After having been for a long time ‚Ä¢ he principal City of the Morea, it be
‚Ä¢ ame a Commonwealth, and in that quality had a part in all the Grecian Wars, as is ≈øeen in Pau≈øanias, Moreri
‚Ä¢ nd Lauremberg: At this day 'tis but a mi≈øerable hole giving ≈øhelter to a very few Inhabitants, and retains only the name of its pa≈øt Glory. Now that this City belongs to the Venetians ≈øeveral Hi≈øtorians affirm, and the Decrees ratifie; and if they agree not as to the manner, yet they all unanimou≈øly conclude it has been ju≈øtly enjoyed by them. Baudrand pretends that the Duke of Sparta offering it to ≈øale to them that would give mo≈øt for it, 'twas purcha≈øed by the Republick for a great Sum of Money.

It appears by a Decretal of the Senate in the ≈øixteenth of March, Anno 1383. which we have here rehear≈øed, That Peter, the Son of Frederick Cornaro, at the ≈øame time po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed Argos and Napoli di Romania. Verdizzoti a≈ø≈øures the
≈øame, adding that Marie d' Anguien,
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
Enguien, by corruption called d' Erig ‚Ä¢
no, being left without Children, t ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Widow of Peter became Governe≈øs of Argos, as pretending a right to it; but not being in a condition to defend it again≈øt ≈øo many powerful Enemies, e≈øpecially the ambitious Bajazet, who was the mo≈øt to be feared, ≈øhe offered to deliver it to the Senate: and this Act of Marie d' Erigano happ'ned in the Month of December, Anno 1388. as we ≈øhall prove by a Copy of the Original that is in the Library of that Noble and Honourable Seigneur Giov. Bapti≈øta Cornaro Pi≈øcopia, Proveditor of St. Mark, the worthy De≈øcendent of Peter, and the Father of that Illu≈øtrious Helena, the Beauties of who≈øe Mind were much more ≈øurpri≈øing and admirable, than tho≈øe of the Body of the fair Grecian Helen: who though cut off in the She died in the 31. year of her age, on the 26. of July, 1684. at Badova and is there buried in the Church of St. Ju≈øtin. Flower of her Age, yet ≈øhewed the World prodigious Effects of her Knowledge and Parts.

In the Year, 1463. the Republick ≈øent to make its Complaints again≈øt Mahomet the Second then reigning, for that, contrary to the Faith of their
Treaties, he ≈øhewed him≈øelf as an Enemy, by putting Argos under the Government of the Flambular or Sanza
‚Ä¢ hei of Corinth. The≈øe Complaints produced no good effect with that barbarous Prince; wherefore deliberating on the Means to obtain Ju≈øtice upon this his infringement of the Peace, War was concluded upon; and Bertoldo d' E≈øt√©e, who commanded the Army of the Republick, was ≈øent before the Place with fifteen thou≈øand men, who ≈øoon won the Fort: The Cittadel made ≈øome re≈øi≈øtance, but that likewi≈øe in a ≈øhort time delivered up it ≈øelf. It happ'ned afterwards that this General dying, Dauch Pa≈ø≈øa ≈øoon put to rout the Venetian Army, his own con≈øi≈øting of twenty four thou≈øand men. Thus Argos was pre≈øently retaken again by him, and three≈øcore Cro≈øs-bow-men of Candia made Pri≈øoners and cruelly put to death.

Petri ad honorem no≈øtri dominii, & ≈øicut ≈øentitur, ad con≈øervandum dicta loca expedit, ut Per≈øona dicti Ser. Petri vadat ad dicta loca propter pericula, quae po≈ø≈øent occurrere.

Vadit pars, quod concedatur dicto Ser. Petro Cornario, quod ip≈øe c√πm illo numero Per≈øonarum, & familiae, quae videbuntur Dominis Con≈øiliaris Capitibus, Sapientibus Ordimon, vel majori parti dicti Collegii po≈ø≈øit ire, & conduci ≈øuper Galeis Culphi in proximo exituris ad loca ≈øua praedicta.
