div.head: Of the Confines of the MOREA.
div.p: The Confines of this Penin≈øula are (as we have ≈øaid) the Ionian Sea, that of Sapienza and the Aegean: To this we will add the De≈øcriptions of the Gulfs of the≈øe Seas.

div.head: The Gulfs of the Ionian Sea.
div.p:
AMong≈øt the Gulfs of the Ionian Sea, that of Lepanto ≈øhall have the fir≈øt place, which the Ancients called Cri≈øaeus; Strabo, Halcyonius; others Corinthiacus Sinus; and Sophianus the Gulf of Pedras. It is an hundred
miles long, and reaches on the North ‚Ä¢ o the very Borders of Achaia, and on the South to tho≈øe of the Morea.

The Gulf, called that of Patras, from the name of a Maritime Town of the Morea, ≈øituated within the Dutchy of Chiarenza, being in part invironed by the firm Land, and in part by the I≈øles that are oppo≈øite thereto, re≈øembles a great Lake. Taking its length Northwards, it is 24 miles long, from the I≈øle of Santa Maura, to the mouth of the Gulf of Corinth. On the Ea≈øt it extends it ≈øelf almo≈øt as much from one ≈øide of the Morea, beginning at the mouth of the ≈øaid Gulf quite on to the Promontory of Ca≈øtel Torne≈øe. On the We≈øt, over again≈øt it at a di≈øtance from each other, with a Strait of ≈øeven miles Sea between them, are ≈øeen the I≈øles of Cephalonia and Santa Maura; this of fifteen, the other of forty miles length: The end of the I≈øle of Cephalonia comes within twelve miles by Sea of the I≈øle of Zant; and this is ≈øeparated from the utmo≈øt Cape of the Morea by a ≈øpace of twenty five miles.

The Gulf called that of Chiarenza, from the name of an Ancient Maritime
Town, has its length from the Cape of Chiarenza to Ca≈øtel Torne≈øe.
The Gulf of Arcadia which Ptolemy calls Chelonates or Chelonites Sinus, and others Locardian, reaches from the Cape of Torne≈øe to Cape Jardan.
The Gulf of Zonchio, otherwi≈øe Cypari≈øius Sinus, extends it ≈øelf from Cape Jardan to the Cape of Sapienza.

div.head: The Gulfs of the Sea of Sapienza.
div.p: THe Gulf of Coron which wa≈øhes the City of that name, is likewi≈øe named that of Calamata, from a place not far di≈øtant from its Shores. Ptolemy and Pliny call it Me≈øeniacus Sinus, becau≈øe it was contiguous to the Ancient Province of Me≈ø≈øenia; Strabo, Me≈ø≈øenius, and others Coroneus and A≈øineus Sinus: It is between Cape Gallo and Cape Matapan.

The Gulf of Colochine, or of Ca≈øtel Rampani, or of Fleos, which Strabo and Ptolemy entitle Laconicus Sinus, beats upon Luconia with its Waves, and reaches from Cape Matapan to Cape Malio.
Though this Gulf be u≈øually compre
‚Ä¢ ended in the Sea of Sapienza; yet
‚Ä¢ audrand places it to the Sea of Can
‚Ä¢ ia.

div.head: The Gulfs of the Aegean Sea on the ≈øide of the Morea.
div.p: THe Gulf of Napoli di Romania named from the Town ≈øo called, extends it ≈øelf a great way along the Morea, between the Capes of St. Angelo and Schilli. It once bore the name of Argolicus Sinus, wa≈øhing the Ancient Argia.

The Gulf of Engia is divided from that of Lepanto, by the I≈øthmus. It comprehends a great number of I≈øles and Rocks: 'Tis named Saronicus Sinus, from the River Saron that di≈øcharges it ≈øelf into it. Ptolemy and Pliny call it Salaminiacus, from the I≈øle of Salamis: By Strabo 'tis named Eleu≈øinus; and if we credit Pintianus, 'twas al≈øo called Hermonicus Sinus, at la≈øt 'twas named Egena, from an I≈øle of that name, that lies about the mid≈øt of the Gulf, and is extended
North and South between Attica and Saccania, of twenty four miles circumference, according to M. Spon. This is bounded by the Capes of Colonne and Schilli.

div.head: Of the I≈øles and Rocks that are round the Morea, and in the Ionian Sea.
The I≈øle of Corfu.
div.p: AMong≈øt the I≈øles of the Ionian Sea that are under the Venetians, the I≈øland of Corfu is not the lea≈øt con≈øiderable. It lies at the extreamity of the Gulf of Venice in the Ionian Sea.

This I≈øle is divided into four Parts, which tho≈øe of the Place call Balie. The fir≈øt towards the Ea≈øt is named Lefchimo by Marmora, Leuchino by Porcacchi, and Leucimne by Thucidides. The ≈øecond towards the We≈øt is named Laghiro or Agiru. The third Mezzo. The fourth Loros or Oros: Each of the≈øe Parts has its Territories. There is ≈øpread over all a very pure clear Air, and exceeding whole≈øome, as may be gathered from the Fore≈øts of Oranges and Cedars that there flouri≈øh: And with ≈øome rea≈øon the Poets ≈øung ≈øo much of the Gardens of Alcinous, who dwelt in this I≈øle. The Country is al≈øo very fruitful in all kinds of Grain, and Honey, and Wax, with Wine and Oyl of an extraordinary goodne≈øs; nor does it want plea≈øant Flats in its Northern Parts.

In the fir≈øt Territory of Lefchimo, where yet remains ≈øome Tracts of the Ancient and Epi≈øcopal City of Gardichi; at two miles di≈øtance from the Sea of Garbino there is a Fountain
which made it famous, which after making a ≈ømall River, runs down to the Sea; on which Stream are ≈øeveral Mills. This Territory contains about ten thou≈øand Inhabitants in twenty five Burroughs, the bigge≈øt whereof is named Potamos from a Canal that divides it in two. It is inhabited by very civil and gentile People. From thence is a Canal for Ve≈ø≈øels down to the Sea.

The Territory of Laghiro or Agiru on the Ea≈øt of the I≈øle abounds in all ≈øorts of nece≈ø≈øaries. It has eight thou≈øand Inhabitants in twenty Villages. It had had more if the Africans had not come and demoli≈øhed a City built in a Penin≈øule, where at pre≈øent ≈øtands a Mona≈øtery with a good number of Religious, who≈øe Church is dedicated to the Holy Virgin, and is called Palio Ca≈øtriza. The Ca≈øtle called Angelo Ca≈øtron, built by the Emperour Michael Comnenes upon the Promontory Palachrum, is at this time named St. Angelo.

The third Territory called Mezzo, in which ≈øtands the City of Corfu, had once a larger City. In an extent of ≈øixty miles Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion there are thirty Ca≈øtles or Lord≈øhips and Villages, which
together with the Capital contain twen
‚Ä¢ y five thou≈øand Per≈øons.

The fourth Territory called Loros
‚Ä¢ r Oros in forty five miles Country, and ‚Ä¢ wenty five Towns, has about eight ‚Ä¢ hou≈øand Inhabitants. Ca≈ø≈øiopa now
‚Ä¢ a≈ø≈øiopo, a very famous City was ancient
‚Ä¢ y its Capital. The whole I≈øle has properly no Rivers; for though on the ‚Ä¢ ide of Garbinio there ≈øeems to be one which they name Me≈øongi, that takes ‚Ä¢ ts ≈øource near the Fortre≈øs Cardicchi, yet it ought rather, as well as all the re≈øt, to be reckoned a Brook than a River.

Hi≈øtorians agree not as to the Original of the Inhabitants of this I≈øle, as may be ≈øeen in the Hi≈øtory of Corfu, writ by Marmora: yet all or mo≈øt of the People at this day are Greeks, and ob≈øerve the Rites of the Greek Church.

One Hi≈øtorian ob≈øerves, that this I≈øle was once of a con≈øiderable force Eu≈øtachio Sopra Dionigi. by Sea, and that, in the time of the War between the Greeks and Per≈øians, it put thirty armed Galleys to Sea. The Greek are not the only Hi≈øtorians that make honourable mention of this
I≈øle; for be≈øides what Thucidides ≈øay ‚Ä¢ of it, ≈øpeaking of the Wars of the Moreae, in which the Corcyreans had often their part, we find that Titus Livius makes them to receive Orders in the Army of Q. Fulvius Flavus, to guard the Coa≈øt of Calabria, and that they went in pur≈øuit of the Amba≈ø≈øadors of Carthage, who at the ≈øollicitation of Hannibal were ≈øent to make a League with Philip King of Macedon; and that the≈øe Amba≈ø≈øadors having been brought before the Captain General, he ≈øe ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ them to Rome.

The People of this I≈øle after having been long ≈øubject to the Kings of Naples, weary at la≈øt of being ≈øtill ≈øubject to the frequent Commotions of that Kingdom, offered to put them≈øelves under the Obedience of the Venetian Republick. This their De≈øign they communicated to Giov. Penela≈øco, then re≈øiding at Corfu in quality of Con≈øul for the Venetians, who gave advice thereof to the Senate: and becau≈øe the Prince of Tarentum made ≈øome pretences, they ≈øent to him the Secretary Pietro Compitelli or Campitelli, to ≈øhew him the danger that would en≈øue, if
the I≈øle ≈øhould fall into the Enemies hands, and ≈øo with a good ≈øum of money they found means to ≈øatisfie that Prince.

As Porcacchi reports, the I≈øle became ≈øubject to the Republick in the Year 1322. though Giov. Miani, Captain of the Gulf, did not take the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion thereof from the hands of Riccardo Altavilla and Giov. Ale≈ø≈øio Cavalila, till the ninth of June, 1327. yet Marmora a≈ø≈øures that Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion was taken on the twentieth of May, 1386. which la≈øt Author pretends he had it from the authentick Archives. This whole Affair was managed and tran≈øacted by a Religious of the Order of St. Francis, called Padre Mae≈øtro Giulio Vanello, a man of good parts and much e≈øteemed. He ≈øo brought the bu≈øine≈øs about, that he a≈ø≈øembled the chief men of the place in the Church of the Convent, then called St. Angelo, and there cau≈øed the Keys of the Gates to be delivered into the hands of Captain Miani, with a grant of the Authority over the City. The Repre≈øentants of the Republick come every Year on the ≈øame day into this Church, accompanied
with the Body of the Officers, before whom the Protopapa renews the memory of this Action. I might add that the Prince has a≈ø≈øigned to this Church, as a Mark of his acknowledgment to the Order, two Ducats, yearly to be taken out of the Fi≈øcale Chamber of Corfu.
The Venetians were after this manner po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of it, till the Year 1401. when Ladi≈ølaus King of Naples, the Son of Charles, for thirty thou≈øand Ducats left it quite free to the Republick.

It has been ≈øtill maintained under the Venetian Government, who have guarded and defended it, as a place very nece≈ø≈øary for the con≈øervation of their Empire by Sea; for it has ≈øeveral very good Ports where the Navy may refre≈øh it ≈øelf commodiou≈øly; be≈øides it has a convenient Situation for the Defence of the other I≈øles and States of the Levant, and can hinder a great Army from entring the Gulf, who will hardly venture to pa≈øs by and leave ≈øo powerful an Enemy behind in ≈øo advantageous a Po≈øt. Wherefore 'tis well named the Gate of the Gulf and the Rampart of Italy again≈øt the barbarous.

In the≈øe la≈øt Ages that the Ottoman Forces are much increa≈øed, the Repub
‚Ä¢ ick has, for the common benefit of Chri≈øtendom, been at great expences in Works and Fortifications in this I≈øle, to make the Fortre≈øs impregnable: Wherein they have hitherto ≈øucceeded. On the middle of the Circle of the I≈øle, there rai≈øes it ≈øelf up a ≈øolid Rock, on which is built the old Fortre≈øs, encompa≈ø≈øed on all ≈øides with the Sea, except on that part which faces the Land, where 'tis Flanked with two Bulwarks, with their Curtain, and a good Ditch cut from one ≈øide of the Sea to the other. Under this Fortre≈øs is ≈øituated the City, joyning to which ≈øtands the new Fortre≈øs rai≈øed on the Mount of St. Mark, with infinite charge to front Mount Abram, that lies over again≈øt it, and which for ≈øome time has been much levelled.

The City glories in the birth of Aeneas, and has now the Title of an Arch-bi≈øhoprick. The Republick ≈øends thither ≈øix Nobles, who remain in their Government two years. The fir≈øt has the Title of a Bail; the ≈øecond of a Proveditor; the third of a Captain, who
with the fourth are the Councillor ‚Ä¢ One dwells in the Cittadel of the ol ‚Ä¢ Fortre≈øs, the other in the City; th ‚Ä¢ fifth is the Grand Captain, and has the new Fortre≈øs for his Lodgement, and the ≈øixth is Lord Ca≈øtellain of the Ca≈øte called Della Campana, in the old Tow ‚Ä¢ .

In the year 1537. Barbaro≈ø≈øa ≈øhewed him≈øelf before Della Campana, with an Army of five and twenty thou≈øand Turks, which he commanded by the order of Solyman. They had thirty great Guns, with which they planted a Battery again≈øt the place, but by rea≈øon of the great di≈øtance they were at, their Bullets were not able to make a breach in the Walls. But the Artillery of the great Fortre≈øs made terrible Di≈øtruction in the Army and Fleet of the Turks; five of their Galleys went to the bottom, and even that of Barbaro≈ø≈øa was not out of the Cannons reach. During thi ‚Ä¢ Siege, the Republick ≈øent an extraordinary Amba≈ø≈øadour to Rome, to repre≈øent to the Pope, and by him to the Emperour, of what con≈øequence the lo≈øs of Corfu would be to the Kingdom of Naples, to Sicilia and all Italy. He endeavoured all he could in this Emba≈ø≈øage,
that the Emperour would ≈øend Fifty Galleys with Fifty other Ships as he had done once before again≈øt the Turks, to joyn with 100 Galleys and the Gallea≈ø≈øes, and three Gallions and a good number of other Ve≈ø≈øels that the Republick had then in the Sea.

At fir≈øt the Pope applyed him≈øelf to this affair, to procure ≈øo great a benefit to Chri≈øtendom; but his endeavours were un≈øucce≈øsful; ≈øo that the Republick were left alone to with≈øtand the Ottomans, and they obliged them ≈øhamefully to rai≈øe the Siege: And thus that important place, Corfu, was delivered.

div.head: The little I≈øles or Rocks that lie round about Corfu.
div.p: FAnari, or Ottonus, is a little I≈øle on the We≈øt of Corfu, to which it is ≈øubject; it lies at 15. Miles di≈øtant from Cape Agiru of that I≈øle, and from that of Santa Maria or Otranto 50. 'Tis 8. Miles in Circuit, and contains 200. Inhabitants, in a Fertile Land.

La Serra is a Rock in a ≈øtrait towards
Ca≈ø≈øiopo, between Corfu and Epi ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
It rai≈øes it ≈øelf up above the Wav ‚Ä¢ and at its Foot lie ≈øeveral other cr ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
gy hidden Rocks, very dangerous ‚Ä¢ tho≈øe that Sail by them.

Sant Vido, or according to the Anc ‚Ä¢
ents, the little I≈øle Pitia is a Rock fa ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
ing the City of Corfu, from whence ‚Ä¢ t is but a Mile and half: it is covered ‚Ä¢ ll over with Olive Trees.

Condiloni≈øi, is a Rock on the We≈øt Or We≈øt-North-We≈øt. of Corfu, of ≈øolid Stone, whereon formerly grew Canes, which they u≈øed to write withal. There is a Church on it dedicated to the Holy Virgin.

Sant Demetrio, is a ≈ømall I≈øland, in which is a Lazar-hou≈øe, with all conveniences for tho≈øe of Corfu, in ca≈øe of nece≈ø≈øity. Near this I≈øle is ≈øeen a white Rock above the Water, which at a di≈øtance ≈øhews like a Ship under Sail: which figure gave ground to the Fable, that this Rock was formed of ∆≤ly≈ø≈øes's Ship, which being ≈øunk in this place, was by the Gods turned into a Rock.

Paxo, is a little I≈øle not inferiour to the re≈øt that encompa≈øs Corfu, either as to Fruitfulne≈øs of any nece≈ø≈øary for life, or as to the number of its Inhabitants.
Bourdon calls it Pac≈øu, Porcacchi ‚Ä¢ achi≈øo, Pliny Ericu≈øa, and others
‚Ä¢ axu Major, 'tis ≈øeated on the South ‚Ä¢ f Corfu, at 100. Miles di≈øtance from Cape St. I≈øidore in Cephalonia, and 12. ‚Ä¢ rom Epire. Porcacchi takes it to be ‚Ä¢ en Miles about, others make it five ‚Ä¢ nd twenty. On the We≈øt-North-We≈øt ‚Ä¢ de of it, is Port St. Nicolas, whereinto ‚Ä¢ Ship of any burden may enter; at its ‚Ä¢ ntrance lies a Rock. On the We≈øt at Garbin is the Valley of St. Andrew, a commodious Haven for Galleys. The other Valley at Siroc, is called ∆≤romo Lincione: On the ≈øide of Siroc, is the ‚Ä¢ ≈øle called Antipaxu, a Fertile but un
‚Ä¢ nhabited place: between the≈øe two ‚Ä¢ ittle I≈øles is a very deep Sea. In the Channel between the≈øe I≈øles and the firm Land lies a dreadful Rock almo≈øt even with the Waves, two Miles from Paxo. It has been thought by ≈øome, that Paxo was once joyned to Corfu, and was thence ≈øeparated by the beating of the Waves.

div.head: The I≈øles called Curzolares.
div.p:
THE Curzolares, which Strabo and Pliny name Echinades, and S ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
phanus Echinoe, are five I≈øles of the Ionian Sea, in the Gulf of Patras, the large≈øt of which are Samos and Dulichium. The≈øe being not above a Mile from the Continent, look towards Lepanto on the Ea≈øt at 35. Miles di≈øtance: on the We≈øt 45. Miles off, is ≈øeen the I≈øle of Santa Maura, and in a ≈øtrait Line the Canal Gui≈øcardo, 60. Miles from it. On the North they re≈øpect the firm Land, and on the South they lie ju≈øt over again≈øt the Channel of Zant, at a ≈øpace of twenty four Miles. The ≈ømallne≈øs of them would doubtle≈øs have let them remain unregard ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , if the glorious Expedition of the Army, in the year 1571. had not made them famous.
In the time of the Trojan Empire, as we find in Homer, the≈øe I≈øles were po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by Megetes with the re≈øt of the I≈øles thereabouts.

div.head: The I≈øle of Lefcade, or Santa Maura.
div.p:
THE I≈øle which we at this day call Lefcade, or Santa Maura, Ptolemey named Leucus, Strabo, Pliny, and Mela Leucadia. It lies in the Ionian Sea, nine Miles di≈øtant from Cephalonia, and twenty five from the Curzolares. It was once United to Achaia, but was divided thence by the People that inhabited it, tho it remained not long ≈øo ≈øeparated;
for the Impetuo≈øity of the Winds filled up the ≈øpace between with Sand, which made a kind of I≈øthmus by which it was reunited, ≈øo it became a Penin≈øula. This I≈øthmus having bee ‚Ä¢ worn away, 'twas ≈øupplied by a wooden Bridge over ≈øeveral little I≈ølets, that are ≈øeparated from each other by little Channels. This I≈øle is 70. Miles round; it brings forth abundance of Grain, Wine, Oyl, Tabaco, and all kinds of Fruits. Be≈øides Santa Maura, to which it is joyned, it contains 30. Villages, the Principal of which are, Trini, Apolpena, Sfarchiotes, Caria, Azzani, Vurnica, Scuiro, San Pietro, Englovi, Dragano, Englimento; and ≈øtill as they have been left by the Fugitive Turks, they have been and daily are re-peopled by Greeks from the main Land. It has many Ports, which are, Demata, Santa Maura, Scivoto, Englimento, Vallone of Va≈øilichi; the two fir≈øt of the≈øe are the mo≈øt con≈øiderable. Be≈øide the≈øe, this I≈øle has a Haven which ≈øerves for a Retreat to the Galleys and Galea≈ø≈øes of the Venetians in their pre≈øent Wars with the Turks. There ≈øhoots forth likewi≈øe from its Continent three Promontories,
FORTERESSE DE S. MAURA map of Santa Maura
one called Angu≈øci, the two ‚Ä¢ thers, Cape Englimento, and Cape Du
‚Ä¢ ato. Round about it are the Rocks ‚Ä¢ f St. Nicolas of Sparta, of the Scorpion, of Figlia, of Magni≈øci, and of Se≈ø≈øola, whereon is found great numbers of Rats; wherefore 'tis al≈øo called Scoglio de Sorci, or the Rock of Rats.

div.head: The City and Fortre≈øs of Santa Maura.
div.p: THe City and Fortre≈øs of Santa Maura is encompa≈ø≈øed with the Waves of the Sea, and is ≈øeated between the I≈øle Lefcade, and the main Land, to which it is joyned by ≈øeveral little I≈ølands, by Bridges from one to another, and by its own Bridge, and a ≈øumptuous Aqueduct of Stone about a mile long, ≈øu≈øtained by three hundred and ≈øixty Arches. On the Ea≈øt there is a little Tongue of Land, which extending it ≈øelf along makes the Port of Damata; its Walls make an irregular Heptagon flanked with five great Towers. Sancta Maura's di≈øtant from Provi≈øa, 19. mil from Po ‚Ä¢ t Damata, 6.

It has indured divers Sieges in its own Defence, and although it has vigorou≈øly with≈øtood its Enemies, yet has it often been forced to indure the Turki≈øh Tyranny, and been as often ≈øubject to the Venetians. Anno 1479. it was attacked by the Turki≈øh Forces, and then taken from certain Greek Princes that po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed it.

div.head: The I≈øle of Cephalonia.
div.p: THat I≈øle in the Ionian Sea, called Cephalonia, was not long ≈øince by the Greeks named Ca≈ø≈øa or Chieffali, to ≈øhew that it was the head of the I≈øles in that Sea: and becau≈øe it once had four Cities, 'twas called likewi≈øe Tetrapolis.

Be≈øides the≈øe different names, Authors have given it ≈øeveral others; as Pliny calls it Melena, Porcacchi and others Samo; ≈øome again Dulichium and Tilebi. 'Tis ≈øeated between the thirty ≈øeventh and thirty eight Degrees of North Latitude, and the forty ≈øixth of Longitude, the We≈øt part of Ferro being the fir≈øt. According to Porcacchi 'tis a hundred and ≈øixty miles round: but
it is indeed 170. It is of a triangular Figure, its mo≈øt advanced Angle being Northwards at Cape Gui≈øcardo, otherwi≈øe called Capo Capra: On the Ea≈øt it regards Chiarenza in the Morea, and on the North Corfu, on one ≈øide with the Point Schinori of the I≈øle of Zant; being at 18 miles di≈øtance, it forms the Channel of Zant, ≈øubject to frequent and dangerous Tempe≈øts; and on the other from Cape Vi≈øcardo to Samo it makes with the I≈øle of Teacchi the Channel called that of Vi≈øcardo, which is three miles broad in the narrowe≈øt place, and very deep. There are ≈øeveral Creeks where Galleys may ≈øafely ride, tho' there be a good number of them man'd with a great Army; for the Bay of Ale≈ø≈øandria, Port Argo≈øtoli (which is very con≈øiderable, and whereof we will treat apart) the Port of Vi≈øcardo and that of A≈ø≈øo will each receive two or three; and have, as likewi≈øe the whole Channel, a ≈øound Bottom.

The whole I≈øle is divided into ≈øeven principal parts, which are Argo≈øtoli, Li≈øcuri, Finea, Eri≈ø≈øo, Pillaro, Samo, Luceto. In the≈øe are ≈øeveral large Burroughs which take their Names
from the chief Families that dwell in them. The lea≈øt of the≈øe contains about 50 Hou≈øes: They are a very valiant and ingenious People.

Under the I≈øle of Cephalonia lies that of Teacchi, it affords great Quantities of Rai≈øins, whereof the Engli≈øh yearly take their Cargo, yielding a con≈øiderable Revenue to the Republick; and from thence come extraordinary large Citrons. The Corn that they ≈øow in the Spring is reaped again in June; the Vines grow very low, near the Ground, they gather their Fruits in April and in November, but the latter are ≈ømaller than tho≈øe of April: It produces al≈øo beautiful Narci≈ø≈øus's and Hyacinths, and it is common there to ≈øee Ro≈øes and Pinks all the Winter.
When the South Wind blows there in the Summer it cau≈øes exce≈ø≈øive Heat, which is tempered by the North.

The Republick keeps a Noble Venetian there as Governor, with the Title of Proveditor; and two other Noble Men as Coun≈øellors, who keep the publick A≈ø≈øizes alternately each their Month under the Proveditor; their Office la≈øts for two years. The City is
a Bi≈øhops Seat, and the Church belongs to Zant; in the twelfth Age it was rai≈øed to a Bi≈øhoprick by Marquis Rizzardo de Tochis Prince of Achaia, and of the≈øe I≈øles, who gave the Bi≈øhop the Tithes of ≈øeveral Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, as well of Cephalonia as of Zant, and to the Canons he gave the Tithes of ≈øeveral Lands in Cephalonia.

Strabo ≈øays that in his time Caius Antonius the Uncle of Mark Antony being bani≈øh'd from Rome (after his Con≈øul≈øhip, which he officiated together with his Colleague Cicero) went to Cephalonia, and being there as Soveraign, he laid the Foundations of a City, where he made his Re≈øidence, but he had not time to bring the≈øe De≈øigns to Perfection, for he was recalled from his Exile and imployed in more important matters.

Titus Livius reports, that the Con≈øul Marcus Fulvius having overcome the Etolians, turned his victorious Arms again≈øt the I≈øle of Cephalonia, and being arrived near to it, he ≈øent to the I≈ølanders to know if they would deliver it up freely into his Hands or try the chance of War in its Defence; they were all pre≈øently for delivering, except the
People of Samo, who valiantly ≈øu≈øtained four months Siege, at the End of which the Romans became Victorious and left dreadful Marks of their Rage again≈øt the Samians; for having pillaged the City, they ≈øold all the Inhabitants for Slaves.

In the Year 1224, the I≈øle was given to the Verdizzotti fatti Ven. l. 8. p. 163. And Moro≈øini in a little Treati≈øe of Cephal ≈øays it was given 1214. Republick of Venice by a generous and free Act of Gaius who was Lord and Governour thereof.
Anno 1479, there came from Gallipoli into the Ionian Sea, a great Ottoman Army which invaded Cephalonia, then in the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of a pety Toccho Napo. Prince, and took it out of his hands.

He al≈øo ≈øent a great Ve≈ø≈øel to Junoo to tran≈øport ≈øome of tho≈øe People that in great numbers were retired thither, to re people and cultivate this I≈øle. There came be≈øides ≈øeveral other People voluntarily to dwell there; and ≈øo the hard and tyrannick Government of the I≈øland was changed into a more mild and ju≈øt; whence en≈øued a meliorating of the Place and manuring of the Grounds.

div.head: The Fortre≈øs of A≈ø≈øo.
div.p:
THE important Fortre≈øs of A≈ø≈øo or Na≈ø≈øo in the I≈øle of Cephalonia, was built by the Venetians an. 1595 for the Defence of the Inhabitants, who in time of War could not all ≈øecure them≈øelves in the City of Cephalonia: It is ≈øeated upon a Rock who≈øe Point is very high and ≈øteep, environed with the Sea; ≈øo that 'tis hardly acce≈ø≈øable by ≈øome
narrow Paths; its Fortifications were made to an≈øwer the Situation of the Place, which is altogether uneven, ≈øo that 'tis very irregularly built. There is a Tongue of Land about 20 Paces long, whereby 'tis joyned to the I≈øle, and which makes the way to the Fortre≈øs: It was once propo≈øed to cut through it in the narrowe≈øt place and ≈øo to make a good Ditch there.
It is compo≈øed of 60 publick Hou≈øes and 200 particular Habitations.

At the Foot of it is a little Port which may ≈øhelter three Galleys, but it grows daily wor≈øe and wor≈øe, by rea≈øon that when ever any tempe≈øtuous and great Rains happen, the violent Torrents bring down with them from the Mountain a great deal of Sand and Stones which choak it up, for which there is no Remedy.
The Republick ≈øends thither a Patrician for Governour, with the Title of Proveditor, who≈øe Office la≈øts thirty two Months; the fir≈øt of them was ≈øent thither on the 23d. of June, an. 1596.

div.head: Argo≈øtoli.
div.p:
WE mu≈øt not pa≈øs by the Port of Argo≈øtoli in Silence, ≈øince it is of ≈øome Importance to the Republick; it took its name from the Ship Argo and the Argonauts, who came to land there. It has a Circuit of thirty Miles, and may contain the mo≈øt numerous Army. The Venetian Galleys and the Proveditor Generals u≈øually make a De≈øcent there when they are upon any Expedition in the≈øe Quarters. There is no Fortre≈øs upon it, ≈øo that it is free for all Ve≈ø≈øels to Land there: It has been propo≈øed to build a Fort there which may command the Port and the Entrance into the I≈øle, and if ever the De≈øign be put in Execution there is a very advantageous Situation for it upon a ≈øteep Rock. There is yet to be ≈øeen in the farthe≈øt part, the Remains of the ancient City built by the Corinthians, once called Cranea: Near to it towards the Sea is the Place now called il Cutego, where are to be ≈øeen the Foundations of great Caverns in the Earth, thought to
have been once the Ar≈øenal for the Port of Argo≈øtoli.

div.head: The I≈øle of Teacchi.
div.p: THIS I≈øle has almo≈øt as many Names as it has had Authors who have de≈øcribed it. Strabo and Pliny call it Itaca, Porcacchi and Denis the African Nerieia; Niger, Val di compagno; and Sophianus, Val di compare; the Greeks at pre≈øent name it Thiachi; the Turks, Phiachi; and u≈øually we call it Cefalonia Picciola, the Little Cephalonia.

It looks towards Cephalonia, from which 'tis ≈øeparated by the Arm of Vi≈øcardo, which is a very deep Channel, 20 Miles long and five broad, and in the narrowe≈øt place, three. The Shape of this I≈øle is irregular and longer than broad; it is 40 miles round with ≈øeveral Gaps and Creeks; it has ≈øeveral little Ports very nece≈ø≈øary for taking in Fire-wood: But of all the re≈øt that of Vathi has the be≈øt Anchorage, the firme≈øt Bottom, and very deep, which will receive a great number of Ve≈ø≈øels.
There are two others little inferiour to this, called Gidachi and Sarachinicco. I will not ≈øtay to give the Particulars of the others, being they are of ≈øo little U≈øe and ≈øo bad Anchorage that it is not worth the while to treat of them.

This I≈øle is thought to have been the Dwelling place of the cha≈øt Penelope and the Country of ∆≤ly≈ø≈øes; upon this Tradition the Cephalonians have a Veneration for certain Remains that are thought to be in the place where that illu≈øtrious Couple dwelt. It had once a City called by Plutarch Alalcomene, but there are now but ≈øome Villages, the chief of which are Vathi, Annoi, Oxoi. The Inhabitants are about 15000, a good part whereof are bani≈øh'd People from the I≈øles of Zant, Corfu, and Cephalonia.

The Citizens of Cephalonia elect every year one whom they call the Captain of Teacchi; but he cannot enter upon his Charge without the con≈øent of the Rectors, who are obliged once in the Year to go to that I≈øland, which they do in the month of March, to which time they remain in Office: the Authority of this Officer extends but to hear and decide Cau≈øes.

Andrew Moro≈øini the Son of Peter, who was Proveditor of Cephalonia, anno 1622, tells us, that this I≈øle was taken by the Confederates of Michael, the Son of the Emperor Paleologus, out of the Hands of that Emperor, after he had taken it him≈øelf from Charles Tocco a Neapolitan; this Per≈øon had ≈øo great a kindne≈øs for the Republick, that he remitted to them as to the ≈øupreme Judges the Hearing of all Cau≈øes as well criminal as civil.

div.head: The I≈øle of Zant.
div.p: This I≈øle has the Morea on the Ea≈øt at 80 miles Di≈øtance, on the We≈øt it borders on the I≈øle of Cephalonia, from whence tis 12 miles, on the South is the Coa≈øt of Barbary 150 miles off, and on the North it has another Part of the Morea about Ca≈øtel Torne≈øe at 16 miles Di≈øtance, and a little lower it looks towards the Country del Dichiamo, where are Natolico, the Curzolares, and Drago Me≈øtre, Places at above 50 miles di≈øtance.

The whole I≈øle is divided into three Parts, called Montagna, Pedimonte, and Pianura. Montagna begins on the Ea≈øt ≈øide, where lies Port Chieri, and makes the Circuit of the whole South and We≈øt ≈øide of the I≈øle even quite to the North, having in its middle a very
beautiful plain called Neruli, in the mid ‚Ä¢ whereof was a great Lake of water ‚Ä¢ from the Hills, till the Noble Angelo Barbarigo took the pains and care to drei ‚Ä¢ it. At this time 'tis a fair and fruitful plain 10 miles long and five broad, and borders on two ≈øides upon the Sea ≈øhore. Here ≈øtands the City Chieri giving name to the Port: from the waters of which comes the black Pitch, and there is an opinion among the Inhabitants that the Lake was anciently all of this Pitch. There are be≈øides ≈øeen here the Towns called Littachio, Pigadachita, Sculicado with fourteen more, who≈øe names for brevity I omit. On that part called Montagna are Ambelo, Chilomeno, Agelo, San Leo, Santa Maria, and other Towns to the number of nine. The farthe≈øt of them is called Volimes, lying towards the We≈øt. It contains above one thou≈øand hou≈øes.

There are be≈øides in this part three Mona≈øteries of Greek Caloieros called San Giovanni in Lancada, La Madonna Spilioti≈ø≈øa or Anafontria, and San Georgio di Grebani, which is the mo≈øt con≈øiderable and commodious for ≈øituation.

In that Part called Pianura, which is
on the North of the I≈øle, are the Towns ‚Ä¢ f Gaetani, Curculidi, San Quirico, Farao
‚Ä¢ nd San Dimetrio. Be≈øides the great ‚Ä¢ oted Mountain making a principal ‚Ä¢ art of the I≈øle, there are two others which encompa≈øs the I≈øle, one on the Ea≈øt, the other on the North: On the fir≈øt ≈øtand two Towns called Xeroca≈øtello, and Lambetti; on the other are four, Geracario, Bellu≈øi, Calenzi, and Tragacchi. In the whole I≈øle there is but one River named the Camura, who≈øe waters are bracki≈øh, being mixt with the waters of the Sea; but there is below the Ca≈øtle, not far from the Sea, a ≈øource of fre≈øh water, with all the qualifications of an excellent ≈øpring: It is at all times ≈øo plentiful, that all the Ships that pa≈øs for Con≈øtantinople and Alexandria, as well going as coming, take fre≈øh water there.

On the North, the I≈øle is all precepitious and ≈øteep, and on the South covered with all ≈øorts of fruit-trees. On the Greek ≈øhore is built a Ca≈øtle on an Eminence which commands the whole I≈øle; where re≈øide the Rector and the Governour. At the foot whereof lies the Town which ≈øtretches it ≈øelf for two miles along the ≈øhore, and one mile in
breadth towards the Mountain. The ‚Ä¢ are in this Town a great many hou≈øes which belong to the Citizens, Merchants, Artizans, or Mariners. They cure great Quantities of Rai≈øins there and make very ≈øtrong wines, and excellent oyl, which one year with another yields them the ≈øum of fifty thou≈øand Ducats. There is al≈øo abundance of as delicious fruits and rare Plants, as in any other place. Its Port is likewi≈øe called Chieri, of good anchorage for all ≈øorts of Ve≈ø≈øels, Ships or Galleys.

On the North ≈øide is Cape Schinan and the Rock called San Nicolo, where neither great nor ≈ømall Ve≈ø≈øel can enter, except on the Ea≈øt ≈øide; the ≈øhallowne≈øs of the water and the want of a good bottom hindering that on the We≈øt. On the Ea≈øt is the Valley of the ≈øalt-Pits where Ships come to take in their Lading of Salt. A little nearer to the City is the Rock called fra Filippo, at pre≈øent Trenta Nova; and a little farther is the point Laugun very near to the Town.

It is believed that Saint Veronica came to plant the Chri≈øtian Faith in this I≈øle,
and that ≈øhe converted the Inhabitants by ≈øhowing them the Holy Handkerchief, and thence preaching to them the Death and Pa≈ø≈øion of our Saviour.

The Republick ≈øends thither a Noble Man with the Quality of Proveditor, and two others for his Councellors, who all keep their charge two years. But the Inhabitants hold their Councils apart where they regulate Provi≈øions, health, and other matters that concern the Policy of the City. They have power al≈øo in civil cau≈øes to give Judgment under a certain Sum, and there lies an appeal from them to the Proveditor.

The mo≈øt part of the Inhabitants are Greeks and live according to their rites; and there are but few Latins, comprehending among≈øt them even the Souldiery. There are about a thou≈øand Jews who have three Synagogues. Their bu≈øine≈øs is trade, and they grow very rich all of them.

The People of this place are more inclined to Arms than Learning but of the few that apply them≈øelves to the Sciences, the brightne≈øs of that Eloquence ≈øhines forth, which is ≈øo natural
to the Greeks; and by a little ≈øtudy ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ the Laws and Rights, they ≈øoon becom ‚Ä¢ great Orators and skilful Lawyer ‚Ä¢ The People are in continual broils an ‚Ä¢ Suits with one another; tho≈øe of th ‚Ä¢ Country hate the Citizens, the mo≈øt o ‚Ä¢ which live upon Traffick; the meane ‚Ä¢ of the people are Sea-faring men an ‚Ä¢ are always in their frigates going to th ‚Ä¢
Morea, and other places that depen ‚Ä¢ on the Turk, to get their living.

The I≈øle is ≈øubject to Earthquak ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ which de≈øtroies what ever is good and beautiful. Some years ≈øince they felt in one night ≈øixty ≈øhakes, which were preceeded by a terrible noi≈øe: This noi≈øe u≈øually la≈øts half a quarter of an hour, and is communicated to the Rocks, that are ≈øtanding out of the Earth: and ≈øometimes there happens an infectious ≈øtink. When the Earthquake is very great it rai≈øes an exceeding boi≈øterous wind, upon which ≈øcore their buildings are but low and of few Stories.

There is a Bi≈øhop that makes his Re≈øidence in the I≈øle with the Title of Bi≈øhop of Zant, conferred on him by the Holy See: yet by the patents from the Senate of Venice, he is entitled the Bi≈øhop
of Cephalonia. At fir≈øt this Church ‚Ä¢ cknowledged the Pope of Rome, till ‚Ä¢ uch time as the Church of Con≈øtantino
‚Ä¢ le had a Patriarch of her own; and ‚Ä¢ hen the Patriarch, ≈øtrengthened by the favour of the Emperour, cau≈øed ≈øeveral of the Greek Churches, and ≈øome of the ‚Ä¢ talian to ≈øubmit to his See.

At the time, when ≈øeveral of the We≈øtern Princes a≈ø≈øociated them≈øelves to war upon tho≈øe that po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed the Holy Land, the Church of Zant returned to the obedience of the See of Rome. Several very noted per≈øons have flouri≈øht there, by rea≈øon of the great Revenues of the Bi≈øhoprick, which has amounted, as is ≈øeen in the Archives, to more than ≈øix thou≈øand Crowns. Po≈ø≈øibly the Bi≈øhops had then the force of the Laws and ≈øecular Arm, more than the Authority of their See and zeal of their preaching, to a≈ø≈øi≈øt them. Two Bi≈øhops of this Church ≈øucce≈ø≈øively went to the Council of Trent, where they were much di≈øtingui≈øht by their merit.

The fir≈øt was John Francis Comendon, who died during the time of the Council, who was ≈øucceeded by Petro Delfino, a Noble Venetian. The Pari≈øh
Churches of the Greeks comprehending tho≈øe of the City, the Cittadel, and others that have been founded out of devotion are about forty four. There are likewi≈øe a great number in Cephalonia that place being well Peopled. There are fifteen in the City, in each of which is a plain Altar, with the Altarpiece towards the Ea≈øt, adorned with paintings after the Greek fa≈øhion, who permit no Images in Relievo, in their Temples. The Altar is of ≈øtone inclo≈øed with a Rail, who≈øe entrance is forbidden to Laicks and Women. Nay the Women pre≈øently after Child-bed, and the Men that are found in any ill action, are forbid the Churches; but this cu≈øtom is now neglected.

When the Arch-bi≈øhop happens to die all the Greek Curates, of which there is a good number, a≈ø≈øemble them≈øelves; and according to a very ancient cu≈øtom, authorized by the Holy See, they give their ≈øuffrages in ≈øecret, to proceed to the election of another. The Bi≈øhop has no fixt Revenue and maintains him≈øelf upon Ca≈øualties, which the Greeks yearly pre≈øent to him as in a Quantity of Wheat and other
Grain: He likewi≈øe has a con≈øiderable gain by Ordinations; and by one way or other his Revenue is very large.

As a Qualification of a Bi≈øhop of this City, a man mu≈øt have been a Monk of the Order of St. Ba≈øil, upon which account there are ≈øo many Mona≈øteries of that Saint's in the≈øe I≈øles. The mo≈øt con≈øiderable of which is built on the Rocks commonly called the Strophades; of which in their place. This Mona≈øtery has ≈øeveral Revenues in Zant and Cephalonia; and the Greeks have the≈øe Monks in Great Veneration, becau≈øe they live very retired from ≈øecular affairs.

The≈øe Monks of St. Ba≈øil fa≈øt the whole year, except in ca≈øe of infirmity or ≈øickne≈øs, when they may have a di≈øpen≈øation for three days in the week, Monday, Wedne≈øday and Friday they eat nothing but milk, fi≈øh and oyl. They keep four Lents in the year; the fir≈øt is that of Ea≈øter called, i Megali Te≈ø≈øara-co≈øti; which la≈øts ≈øeven weeks; for which time they are not permitted to eat either fi≈øh or oyl, except two days in the week, viz. Saturday and Sunday, nor that, on Holy Saturday. Their nouri≈øhment then is only fi≈øh that have no blood,
as oy≈øters, dryed fi≈øh, Caveer, which is the Rows of fi≈øh ≈øalted; Botargo, which is made of the Row of a Sturgeon dryed and ≈øalted, &c. There are two other days on which they may eat, that is the 25 of March, being Annunciation-day, which they call Euangelismos, provided it happen before the Holy week; the other is Palm-Sunday, which they name Tou Vaghiou.

The Second Lent, is of the Agioi Apo≈øtoloi, in honour of the Holy Apo≈øtles, which la≈øts from the Munday ≈øevennight after Whit≈øuntide, till the Vigil of St. Peter and Paul; ≈øo that ≈øome years it la≈øts three weeks, others more.

The Third is called Tis agias Parthenou, dedicated to the Virgin Mary, which la≈øts from the fir≈øt to the fifteenth of Augu≈øt, in which time they eat no fi≈øh except on the ≈øixth, being the fea≈øt of the Transfiguration of Chri≈øt, which they ob≈øerve with Solemnity, and call it Metamorpho≈øis tou Sotiros.

The Fourth is called ton Chri≈øtogenon, which begins forty days before Christma≈øs, to wit on the fifteenth of November and continues till the twenty fifth of December, for which time they may eat fi≈øh except on Wedne≈ødays and Fridays.

The Caloieros, be≈øides the≈øe four, ob≈øerve three other Fa≈øts; the fir≈øt before St. Demetrius, which la≈øts twenty days; the ≈øecond begins on the fir≈øt of September, fourteen days before the Exaltation of the Holy Cro≈øs; the third eight days before the fea≈øt of St. Michael, Be≈øide the≈øe all the Greeks in general fa≈øt on Wedne≈ødays and Fridays, and ≈øeveral of the mo≈øt zealous on Mondays al≈øo. Moreover on the day of the Exaltation of the Holy Cro≈øs, and the Decollation of St. John the Bapti≈øt, they keep a more ≈øevere Fa≈øt. Except the≈øe times they eat fle≈øh all the week after Ea≈øter-Sunday, and that whole week after Whit-≈øunday, and for twelve days together after Chri≈øtma≈øs, and a week before the great Lent. They keep likewi≈øe three other Vigils in the year, That of the Epiphany, which they name Paramoni, on which day the Greeks baptize the Sea with a great Ceremony; the ≈øecond is the Vigil of St. John the Bapti≈øt, and the third that of the Cro≈øs whereon they are forbid to eat fi≈øh. Thus tho≈øe Greeks, that are not Monks, fa≈øt about a hundred and thirty days in the year.

All the Mona≈øteries of the Religious, ob≈øerve
the Rites of the Greek Church, and if there ≈øhould be one among≈øt them of the Latin Church; yet they mu≈øt ob≈øerve the Greek Rites. It is permitted to the≈øe Religious, on divers occa≈øions, to vi≈øit their ≈øick Relations; and to go about the Cities, living without any Cloy≈øter; which doubtle≈øs is contrary to the In≈øtitution of a Mona≈øtick Life.

There is not in the≈øe I≈øles any kind of Ho≈øpital for the Poor. Except only in Zant there are two little poor Almshou≈øes, one for the Men and another for the Women, under the direction of the Citizens of the Place: They u≈øed to receive into the≈øe hou≈øes Foundlings and Ba≈øtards; but that cu≈øtom is now left off. There are al≈øo, in the≈øe I≈øles, many Prote≈øtants, mo≈øt of them Engli≈øh. There are four Convents, one of Preaching Friars, two of Friars Minors Conventuals, one in Zant, the other in Cephalonia; and one of Minors Ob≈øervants in Zant, without reckoning the Pari≈øh Church of Argo≈øtoli, which is a jus patronale of the mo≈øt Serene Republick; which it has be≈øtowed on the Minor Ob≈øervants.

The≈øe People live willingly under the obedience of the Republick, which watches continually for their defence again≈øt the powerful irruptions of the Turks: And be≈øides for that they permit them to live conformable to their own Rites, of which they are ≈øo zealous, being per≈øwaded of their ancient and pure In≈øtitution.
There grows in this I≈øle very extraordinary Fruit; and that in as great abundance as any I≈øle thereabouts.
Caroldi reports, that the I≈øle of Zant was ≈øold with the other I≈øles by Robert Prince of Tarentum, Anno 1350. Tarante.
In the Year 1571. ∆≤luzzali Pa≈ø≈øa ≈øackt the City, wa≈øted the Country, and laid the whole I≈øle extreme de≈øolate.

div.head: The I≈øles Strivales.
div.p:
THe Strivales are two I≈øles, by the Mariners called Stamfane, and which Authors have known by ≈øeveral names, for Strabo, Pliny, and Apollonius name them Strophades, Pau≈øanias Strivali, Suidas Stromphides, and Camerarius Calydnes.
They are low, almo≈øt level with the water; their Port is di≈øtant from Zant above fifty miles; they are but of ≈ømall extent, the bige≈øt not above three or four miles in circuit. And tho they are ≈øo ≈ømall, they produce a Prodigious quantity of Grapes; and the wine of them is extraordinary good. There are al≈øo many fre≈øh Springs, all along which are found a great deal of Planc-Tree leaves; tho the neare≈øt place, where any of tho≈øe Trees grow, is in the Morea, at thirty miles di≈øtance; wherefore doubtle≈øs they mu≈øt be brought thither by ≈øubterranean pa≈ø≈øages.
The Inhabitants are all Greek Caloieros, who for their defence again≈øt the Turk, have built their Convent in form of a Fortre≈øs, well provided with Cannon, with a Port-cullis at the Gate.

The Poets feigned that Aello, Ocypite, and Celaeno, born of Thaumas and Teletra, inhabited the infernal Pit in the ≈øhape of Harpies, whence they went to torment wicked men at the command of the Gods: And they paint us the≈øe Harpies with lean, tho beautiful faces like Women; the re≈øt of their bodies being like horrible Vultures, with large wings
and pointed talons. The Fable adds, that Phineus King of Arcadia, like an inhumane Father, having pluckt out his own Childrens Eyes, the Gods returned the ≈øame puni≈øhment upon him, by tearing out his, and leaving him to the terrible pur≈øuit of the Harpies, which defiled his food with their ordure and ≈øtink. Ja≈øon touched with compa≈ø≈øion for the mi≈øerable King, and willing to relieve him, cau≈øed Zetes and Calais to drive the≈øe Mon≈øters from tormenting him and force them to retire into the Strophades.

div.head: The I≈øle of Prodano.
div.p: PRodano is a little I≈øle or Rock, which Pliny and Ptolemy call Prote, and other Proude, near the Morea, with which it makes a Channel of ≈øeventeen or eighteen foot water, where Ve≈ø≈øels may, commodiou≈øly ride ≈øafely under the Wind.

div.head: The I≈øles in the Sea of Sapienza.
div.p: THere are three I≈øles in the Sea of Sapienza, the fir≈øt which Bordon calls Sphagia or Sphateria, and Porcacchi Sfragia, and which is commonly named that of Sapienza. This gives name to the Sea which flows by its ≈øide, and wa≈øhes the South part of the Morea. It lies directly over again≈øt Medon, and exceeds the two others in extent.
The Second named Cabrera or Fu≈øchella, or Teganu≈øa and Cauriera, is but at a ≈ømall di≈øtance from the Fir≈øt, and is much le≈øs than it.

The Third called Venetico fronts Cape Gallo. It is ≈øo enclo≈øed on all ≈øides, that it may rather be accounted a Rock than an I≈øle. There lie about it ≈øeveral other Rocks, where the Pirates of Barbary lie in wait for the Ships that come from the Gulf of Venice and Sicily.

div.head: The I≈øle of Cerigo.
div.p:
ON the We≈øt of the Archipelago lies the I≈øle at this day commonly called Cerigo. Ptolemy named it Cythera from Cytheron, the Son of Phenicus; Ari≈øtotle calls it Porphyru≈øa, from the great ≈øtore of Porphyry dug out of its Mountains; and others again Scothera. 'Tis ju≈øt again≈øt the Laconian Gulf, but five miles off the Morea, forty from Candia, and has ≈øixty in circumference. It has ≈øeveral Rocks roundabout it, and good Ports on its ≈øides. On the South is the Port of the Fortre≈øs, which is but little frequented, becau≈øe 'tis but a narrow Bay, and lies much expo≈øed to the winds: The other, which is on the other ≈øide the Dragoniers, twelve miles from the Fortre≈øs, has a good bottom, is deep, and will contain a great Fleet: Above all things the natural ≈øhape of the Bay is wonderful, which may be ≈øhut up, and where forty Galleys may lie in ≈øafety. There is a Church dedicated to St. Nicholas, though no body dwells there. On the We≈øt at 25 miles di≈øtance from this Port, there is another little one called San Nicolo de modari,
proper for Galliots and ≈ømall Barks, where is al≈øo a Church dedicated to St. Nicholas.

There is in this I≈øle great quantities of wild fowl, but little corn, wine or oyl; and food is there very dear. There are ≈øeveral Villages, but of ≈ømall or no account: And ≈øome Mona≈øteries of Hieromonachi and Caloierros, of which one ≈øtands upon a Rock on the right ≈øide near to the Fortre≈øs, which they call San Giovanni della Grotta. It has been hewn out of the Rock by pure labour with the mattock. Tho 'tis very difficult to get up to it; yet the Greeks refu≈øe not that pains, when-ever the Religious are to perform their Vows, which they have made to God. The ≈øteep points of the Rock, affright all that look on them, for they hang over ≈øo, that they threaten to fall and overwhelm tho≈øe that approach them. But for all this the Inhabitants have a great Veneration for the place, upon a belief, that St. John began his Apocalyp≈øe there.

The City of the ≈øame name with the I≈øle has the Title of a Bi≈øhoprick: It ≈øtands upon a ≈øteep Rock in a very advantageous ≈øituation, having towards the Sea an E≈øplanade well mounted
with Canon, where they keep Guard.

The Republick of Venice has had the Some ≈øay ever ≈øince the De≈øpots of Greece. Command of it ever ≈øince the divi≈øion of the Empire of Con≈øtantinople, and ≈øends thither, every two years, one of her Noble Men, in Quality of Cha≈øtelain, and Proveditor. Selim attempted with a powerful Army, commanded by Hali and Portau to conquer it, but he ≈øoon gave it over, finding his endeavours but vain.

Some fabulous Writers ≈øay, that the Godde≈øs Venus had her Birth in this place, others that ≈øhe pa≈ø≈øed her fir≈øt days there. And was there acknowledged for a Godde≈øs, and there was a beautiful Temple dedicated to her; under the name of Cytherea in the mo≈øt Ea≈øtern part thereof: In which Temple was her Statue like a beautiful Woman holding in her right hand a Sea ≈øhell, and as if ready to leap into the Sea. She was all dre≈ø≈øed with blu≈øhing Ro≈øes and ≈ønowy Pidgeons flying around her, which ≈øeemed to follow and attend her motion. Three young Virgins, repre≈øenting the three Graces, hand in hand, went round her to ≈øerve her; two whereof were in action, as if they were
adorning her head, the third waited on her behind. Her Son Cupid was before her, armed with his bow, who, tho blind, yet wounded the God of Light, Apollo, with an Arrow from his bow.

'Twas in this Temple, that Paris, the amourous Son of Priam, met the fair Grecian Helen; and here they tempted each other to the fatal Rape, which armed the jealous Menelaus, and revenging Greece for the utter de≈øtruction of Troy.

The I≈øle is of no great extent, being not above ≈øixty miles; yet 'twas of great con≈øequence to the Spartans, when they were Ma≈øters of it; for it was to them as it were a Rampart and a ≈øhelter to their ≈øhips, which they ≈øent to Aegypt. They ≈øent thither every year a Pre≈øident to regulate civil and military affairs; and the keeping of this I≈øle was then ≈øo nece≈ø≈øary, that in the eighth year of the Peleponne≈øian War, the Athenians having won it, Sparta was without defence, and its Country lay open to the Enemy, till they ha≈øted to fortifie and put Garri≈øons in the neighbouring places.

The little I≈øle, or rather Rock, called de Cervi, lies between Port Rapini and
Cape St. Angelo, where with the firm Land it makes a Channel, unnavigable by Rea≈øon of the Banks of Sand that are in it.

The neare≈øt Rocks to Cerigo are the Dragonier, which have a good Anchorage, and may be ≈øailed from with any Wind, the others that are ≈øeen between this I≈øle and Candia, are Ovo, otherwi≈øe called Eple, O≈øo, Doi, Poro, Pore≈ø≈øa, Cicerigo, or Cerigotto, which the Ancients called Egila, or Egiale; it is the neare≈øt to Cape Spada, and the large≈øt of all. But there is none of all the≈øe that de≈øerves a particular De≈øcription, and ≈øerve only as Marks to the Sailer, being of no other u≈øe.

div.head: The I≈øles of the Gulf of Engia.
div.p: THE I≈øles in the Gulf of Engia, and which are a great Ornament to it, are fir≈øt (beginning at Cape Colonne) Patrocleia, which the People call Ga√Ødroni≈øi, and Macroni≈øi: It has likewi≈øe the Name Ebanoni≈øi, from the Ebany that grows there in great Plenty.

On a high Place there is a Marble Stone ≈øet up, which may be ≈øeen a great way, and ≈øerves for a Signal to the Mariner. On the ≈øide blowed on by the Greek Wind, near to the I≈øle lie ≈øeveral dangerous Shelves of Sand.
Sailing towards the Attick Shore we find the I≈øle of Eli≈ø≈øo, thought to be the Elou≈ø≈øa of Strabo.
Then is the Rock of Phlega, with five others contiguous to it, called Cumboni≈øa.
Between the I≈øle Culuri and Attica is the I≈øle Lip≈øo Coutalia, or P≈øyttalce near to Port Lion, where there is a prodigious Number of Hares and Foxes.
Between Culuri and Egena is ≈øeen the I≈øle called Laufa, near to which are three little Rocks.
Between the I≈øle of Egena and the City of Corinth, are the≈øe I≈øles, Argios, Thomas, Diaporia, Ebroeo, Agiolani, Platoni≈øi, and another little Rock that has no Name.
Between Egena and the Continent of Saccania, lie Angi≈øtri; Metopi, Dorou≈øi and Moni.
The I≈ølanders are much inclined to Fi≈øhing, and the rather for that their Shores are u≈øually full of Fi≈øh.

The old City of Salamene, once a Bi≈øhops Seat, Suffragan to the Arch-Bi≈øhop
of Athens, is ≈øituated four or five Miles off, a little Village of about 20 Hou≈øes, called Ambellachi, which has a ≈ømall Port over again≈øt Athens, near which is ≈øeen a Building like a Mona≈øtery, which has the Title of a Metropolis, joyned to another Hou≈øe.
The Circuit of the I≈øle is 35 miles, containing about a thou≈øand Inhabitants.

Megalo-kira, and Micro-kira, that is, the great and little Kira, are two Rocks between Culuri and the Terra firma of Attica. Over again≈øt Cape S ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
nio, otherwi≈øe Cape Colonne, is the Rock called Macroni≈øi, which Homer mentions in his Iliads under the Name of Cranae. Its fir≈øt Name was Helene, being the place where that Beauty of Greece was embraced by her enamour'd Ravi≈øher, Paris.

div.head: The I≈øle of Egena.
div.p:
EGena is an I≈øle di≈øtant from the Attick Coa≈øt 18 miles, 25 from Port Lion, 12 from the Morea, and 21
from Culuri. Strabo calls it Egina from Egine, the Mother of Eacus, the Daughter of A≈øopus: Baudrand, Ae
‚Ä¢ o ‚Ä¢ e; Brietius, Myrmidonia; and the Mariners, Engi; though this I≈øle has 36 miles Circuit, yet has it never a Port to receive any Ve≈ø≈øels, and they are obliged to ca≈øt Anchor between Augi≈øtri and Doru≈øa, or between it and Moni; as the Venetian Navy did during the Wars with Candia. Partridges there increa≈øe ≈øo, that the I≈ølanders are forced to ≈øearch over the I≈øland in the Spring to de≈øtroy their Eggs, le≈øt ≈øo great a Production of this Game devour up their Corn.

There are yet to be ≈øeen two fair Monuments of Antiquity, which are two Temples, the one ≈øituated in the North Part of the I≈øle, by Pau≈øanias thought to be that, once dedicated to the godde≈øs Venus; the other ≈ølands in a grove upon a little Hill of an admirable A≈øpect; 'twas built in the Honour of Jupiter, by Eacus, the fir≈øt King of this I≈øle; there is ≈øtill to be ≈øeen 20 Columns of the Dorique Order, canellated or fluted with their Architraves, placed in a good Proportion.

The City of the ≈øame Name with th ‚Ä¢ I≈øle, Egena, was once honoured with a Bi≈øhops Seat ≈øuffragan to the Arch-Bi≈øhop of Athens, and famous by the Birth of Paul de Medicis, but is now reduced to a ≈ømall Burrough joyned to the Fontre≈øs, con≈øiderable only for its ≈øituation upon a very high ≈øteep Rock, whence are di≈øcovered many of the I≈øles of the Archipelago, even to Amimilo.

This I≈øle was once ≈øubject to Duke Galeotto Malate≈øta, by his Marriage with the Daughter of Anthony, King of Boeotia; whence it came afterwards to be under the Venetians. But Frederic Barbaro≈ø≈øa, having entred the I≈øles of the Archipeldgo, advanced as far as Egena, intending its Conque≈øt, thinking doubtle≈øs, that all the re≈øt would bring but little glory in Compari≈øon of this, which was then full of People and well. de≈øended under the Government of France≈øco Sorian, who there ruled for the Republick.

Anno 1674, Franoe≈øco Moro≈øini, Captain General of the Army of the Republick, ≈øetting Sail in the Archipeldgo, for the Exaction of the Contributions,
being to refre≈øh the Slaves of his Galley, ‚Ä¢ as informed that Egena was full of a ‚Ä¢ ort of barbarous People who waited ‚Ä¢ ut for an opportune Sea≈øon to tran≈ø
‚Ä¢ ort them≈øelves in ≈ømall Barks to Ca
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ a: This, back'd with the refu≈øal they ‚Ä¢ ade of paying the Impo≈øition, made ‚Ä¢ im take up a Re≈øolution to reduce ‚Ä¢ hem by Force; wherefore having landed his Forces, and begun the Attack, ‚Ä¢ e ≈øoon repre≈ø≈øed the boldne≈øs of the Defenders; and having brought them to yeild at Di≈øcretion, he pillaged the Place, and then demoli≈øh'd it, condemning 300 of the Greeks, and 40 Turks to the Galleys.

div.head:
Of the maritime Places between the Morea and th ‚Ä¢
Negropont.
Megara.
div.p:
During the Reign of Codrus, tho≈øe ‚Ä¢ f Peloponne≈øus, having declared War ‚Ä¢ gain≈øt the Athenians, without gaining ‚Ä¢ ny Fruit of their Attempts, in their Return ≈øurprized Megara; and ≈øo it ‚Ä¢ ecame ≈øubject to the Corinthians, for ‚Ä¢ ho≈øe that took it gave it to the Corin
‚Ä¢ hians and others of their Confederates ‚Ä¢ hat would go to dwell there; from which time the Megareans changed their Cu≈øtoms and Dialect into the Dorique.

Authors ≈øpeak diver≈øly of the Original of the Name; and there is an Opinion, that it was called Megara in the Reign of Carus the Son of Phoroneus, who were the two fir≈øt that con≈øecrated Temples to the Honour of the
Godde≈øs Ceres. The Boeotians repo ‚Ä¢ that Megarus the Son of Neptune, wh ‚Ä¢ dwelt in Onche≈øto, ha≈øting with an A ‚Ä¢
my to the Succour of Ni≈øus, beat ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
Minos, was killed in the Combat, an ‚Ä¢ being buried in this place, gave the nam ‚Ä¢ of Megara to the City before calle ‚Ä¢
Ni≈øa. The Chronicles of the Meg ‚Ä¢
rians otherwi≈øe relate the Story o ‚Ä¢
Megarus; for they affirm that he ≈øucceeded Ni≈øus in the Government, having e≈øpou≈øed his Daughter called Finoes: So that 'tis not ≈øtrange the ‚Ä¢ ≈øhould be named Megarians from their King, they being once called Lelegian ‚Ä¢
from Lelegus, another of their Kings who coming from Egoto, was crowned King of this Place.

On the North of the Town in the Plain, ≈øtand nine or ten Churches, about which ≈øtood once a Village called Paloeochorio, the old Village which is now for≈øaken and ≈øuffered to fall to ruin. If time had not worn away all that anciently was great and beautiful, we ≈øhould yet ≈øee ≈øtanding a great number of ≈øtately Edifices, once the Glory and Ornament of Megara, and who≈øe broken Remains now ≈øurpri≈øe
tho≈øe that look on them. Among≈øt others there was a Fountain, where the Work-man had be≈øtowed all the Delicacies and Beauties of Art. Not far from this Fountain was a Temple, in which ≈øtood the Images of the twelve Gods, the Work of Praxiteles, together with the Effigies of the Emperors, the ≈øtatelie≈øt Show in the World. Megara al≈øo boa≈øted in the bra≈øs Statue of Diana, by the name of Salvatrix, by them erected to her, in acknowledgment of the aid they believed they had from her, when their City was dangerou≈øly attacked by the Army of Mardonius. For it fell out, that this General marching in the Night lo≈øt his way, and in his errour taking a Mountain for his Enemies, which he ≈øought after, he ≈øent all his Arms and Warlike Machins that way: So the Megareans falling upon him without Arms, had the advantage that might be expected from ≈øuch a mi≈øchance. Near this was al≈øo the Magnificent Temple of Olympick Jupiter, in which was the admirable Figure of that fal≈øe God made of Gold, Ivory, and Clay; though that Statue was not
brought to its perfection, the Megar ‚Ä¢
ans ≈øo unwillingly bearing the Athen ‚Ä¢
an Yoke, that they could not thin ‚Ä¢ upon any Work of Glory; and indee ‚Ä¢ they were unable, being ≈øo charged wit ‚Ä¢ Sub≈øidies and Impo≈øitions, which th ‚Ä¢
Athenians laid on them, to provide a ‚Ä¢ new for the Peloponne≈øian War. Th ‚Ä¢ rich Works that were to be the Ornaments of this Statue remained imperfect, and were laid in the back part o ‚Ä¢ the Temple, where hung as a Troph ‚Ä¢ the Ro≈øtrum of a Galley, which tho≈ø ‚Ä¢ of Megara had won from the Athenians, when they retook the I≈øle of Salamina, which had been forced from them.

At Megara al≈øo one might have th ‚Ä¢ Curio≈øity to go into the Rock called Caria, of Carus the Son of Phoroneus‚ñ™ where one might di≈øcover the Temple of Bacchus Nitelius, and at the ≈øame time that of Venus Epi≈øtrophia, called the Oracle of the Night.

div.head: Port Lion.
div.p: POrt-Lion or Porto-Lione, is ≈øo named from a marble Lion, ten foot high, that ≈øtands on the Shore of the Port. The Modern Greeks call it Porto Draco, and Cicero and Strabo Piraeus Portus. It has likewi≈øe had the name of Athenarus Portus, and is the Northern Part of the Gulf of Engia.

The entrance into this Port is narrow, ≈øo that ≈øcarce two Galleys can get in at a time; but when one is in there is every where a good bottom, except in one of its Creeks, which is almo≈øt filled up. 'Tis capable of a great Pl. l. 7. c. 37. Portolane is a Book in Folio of the de≈øcription of the Ports. number of Ve≈ø≈øels, Pliny ≈øays a thou≈øand, and Sirabo four hundred, and the Portalane of the Mediterranean five hundred, allowing it ten braces depth, but Mon≈øieur Spon, an exact Author, and of good reputation, has remarked, that as our Ve≈ø≈øels are much larger than tho≈øe of the Ancients, ≈øo now ≈øcarce above forty or fifty can be ranged there.

The greate≈øt Trade of this Port is
of the Velanede, that is gathered from the green Oaks of Eleu≈øis, and of Goat ‚Ä¢ hair.

Before Themi≈øtocles was Prince of the Athenians, they kept not their Ve≈ø≈øels in this Port, but in that of Phalerus, becau≈øe it was not far from their City‚ñ™ And from this Port they ≈øay Mene≈øteus ≈øet ≈øail with a Fleet for Troy: and before him The≈øeus when he went to revenge him≈øelf on Minos for the death of Androgeus. But Themi≈øtocles being cho≈øen Prince, and judging that the Pireus was the mo≈øt commodious, for that it had three di≈øtinct Ports for Ve≈ø≈øels, he fell to work to make it teneble, and made a wall three miles long, which reached quite to the City: the≈øe walls were called Macra Teichi, which were thrown down by Sylla, and of which yet the Foundations are to be ≈øeen. On the great Port of Pireus once ≈øtood the Tomb of Themi≈øtocles; the Place dedicated to Pallas and Jupiter, being a very long Lodgment for tho≈øe that dwelt along the Sea ≈øide, and ≈øeveral other Antiquities, as may be ≈øeen in Pau≈øanias.

div.head: ATEHNS.
div.p:
AThens is one of the mo≈øt Ancient Cities of Greece, the Seat of an Archbi≈øhop, and the Capital of Attica. Its Situation is not far from the Gulf of Engia, which makes part of the Ionian Sea. King Cecrops fir≈øt laid the Foundations, and called it from his own name Cecropia; but its perfection was owing to The≈øeus, who enlarged it, obliging tho≈øe in the Country to come and dwell there. The Cittadel ≈øtill kept the name of Cecropia, till at la≈øt 'twas named Acropolis. 'Tis built upon a living Rock precipitious on all ≈øides, except on the We≈øt where the entrance is. The Ea≈øt and South walls make two ≈øides of a Square, the re≈øt is not ≈øo regular, but an≈øwers to the Points and Windings of the Rock. 'Tis a thou≈øand two hundred ordinary paces round; but at the bottom of the Hill plainly appear the Foundations of another wall, which encompa≈ø≈øed it almo≈øt round, and rendred it the more difficult to ≈øcale. The Souldiers
of the Garri≈øon are in pay during their whole Lives, and dwell there with their Families. They ≈øtill are upon the watch again≈øt all ≈øurpri≈øe, by rea≈øon of the frequent inroads of the Pirats. The Cittadel is almo≈øt at an equal di≈øtance, between two high Hills; one of an equal height with it on the South-We≈øt, about a Falconet ≈øhot off, is called Mu≈øeum; the other is Mount Anche≈ømus, which is ≈øo rugged, that 'twere hard to plant a Battery of great Guns thereon again≈øt the City and Cittadel; be≈øides there is no Plain upon it, only ≈øharp Points of the Rock; upon one of which is the Chapel of Agis Georgios, where once ≈øtood the Statue of Anche≈ømian Jupiter. The lower part of the Town is on the North of the Cittadel, and when one comes from the Seawards it is ≈øo covered by it that the Hou≈øes of the Cittadel only can be ≈øeen, whence ≈øeveral, not having the curio≈øity to land, have thought, that of all the Grandure of Athens the Ca≈øtle only now remained. This Situation is very advantageons for it, as to the health of its Inhabitants; for the Climate being hot, 'tis much better to lie open to
the refre≈øhing North Winds, than to the Southern Burnings.
After all its Revolutions there is yet to be ≈øeen very fine Antiquities, the chief whereof are, the Temple of Victory of the Ionick Order; which the Turks make now their Magazin of Powder.
The Ar≈øenal of Licurgus of the Dorick Order, in which they lay up their Arms and Artillery.
The Temple of Minerva of the Dorick Order changed now into a Mahometan Mo≈øque.
The Lantern of Demo≈øthenes, now ≈øerving as a Receptacle to the P. P. Capuchins.
The Tower of the Winds of an Octogonal Figure, whereof Andronicus Cyrrhe≈øtes gave the Model, and Vitruvius has de≈øcribed.
The Temple of The≈øeus.
The Foundations of Areopagus, &c.

There is in Athens eight or nine thou≈øand Inhabitants, three quarters whereof are Greeks, and the re≈øt Turks, who have four Mo≈øques in the City, and a fifth in the Ca≈øtle. No Jews are permitted there, for the Athenians
are as cunning as they, whence the Proverb, God defend us from the Jews of Salonica, the Greeks of Athens, and the Turks of Negropont.
The Habit of the Greeks of Athens is very different from that of the Turks, for they wear only ≈øtrait Garments of black, or ≈øome dark Colours.
The City at pre≈øent is divided into eight Parts, called Platomata, which are

As to its Terretory, it once contained an hundred ≈øeventy four Burroughs or Villages, whereof ≈øome were as big as Cities; at this time the mo≈øt of them are in the Plain of Me≈øoia or Me≈øogia, wherein are the following Villages;
And the≈øe that are almo≈øt ruined, and are now called only Zeugalatia or Farmes;

list.item: Lambrica in the way to Athens, at Cape Colonne
Palaeo Lambrica, the Ruins of the Ancient Lampra

Gifi≈ø≈øia, in the way to Marathon, formerly Cephy≈ø≈øia

Calingi, as you go from Marathon to Negropont

div.p: Near to Athens among≈øt the Olive Grounds.
