Callirhoe, a few Hou≈øes near the Fountain.

div.p: This City was once an Academy of Arts and Sciences, and a School of Vertue; and all the Princes that have po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed it, have been ambitious to leave their Names upon ≈øome Monuments, thereby to gain an immortality in the Memory of man. Thus we find out upon a Portal, a Greek Ver≈øe, ≈øignifying, that this is the City of Adrian, and not of The≈øeus.

In the cour≈øe of Time it has been ≈øubject to ≈øeveral Princes by divers Misfortunes, to which it has yielded. Sylla after a long Siege took it, and Anno 687. from the Foundation of Rome. made it ≈øubject to the Common-wealth of Rome. Bajazet triumphed over it when it was under the command of Ari≈øtonicus the Epicurean Philo≈øopher. After that Renier Acciaioli having the Dominion of it, yielded it to the Venetian Republick; but it returned again under the Government of the ≈øame Acciaioli, who at once po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed Attica and Boeotia.

In the Year 1455. it was be≈øieged by
Mahomet the Second, and reduced for want of Succours; ≈øince which it has ≈øtill remained under the Ottomam Empire.

div.head: The I≈øle and Kingdom of Negropont.
div.p: THE I≈øle of Negropont is the mo≈øt con≈øiderable of all the I≈øles in the Archipelago. It has had divers Names, and that of Negropont has by corruption been changed into Egripont; the Turks call it Egribos, the Latins Euboea, either from the Retreat of the Daughter of A≈øopus, or of Inachus thither, whom the Poets feign to be turned into a Cow; which from its lowing is named Euboea.

It has al≈øo been called Macris from the Channel called ≈øo in Greek, Abantias from the People Abantides, Calcis and Chalcondantis: Pliny likewi≈øe gives it the name of A≈øopis, and Strabo ≈øays 'twas called Oche, and that once 'twas called Ellopia from Ellopus the Son of Jupiter.

Some have thought that this I≈øle was once joyned to Boeotia, and thence ≈øeparated by Earth-quakes; or as others ≈øay, by the ≈øwift and impetuous cour≈øe of the waves, which make the Canal called Euripus. The I≈øle is three hundred ≈øixty five miles round, in length, from South to North ninety miles, and forty broad, and twenty in the narrowe≈øt part. At which place it is joyned by a Bridge to the main Land.

It is, as it were, encompa≈ø≈øed with two Promontories, Cape Lithar, and Cape dell' Oro. The fir≈øt facing the Gulf of Volo is by Ptolemy and Strabo, called Cenaeum Promontorium, by Pliny Caeneum, and by Niger Canaia. Near this Promontory was the coa≈øt of Artemi≈øia, ≈øo called from a Temple of that name there erected: At which place the Greeks ≈øhelter'd their naval forces, during their wars with the King of Per≈øia. The ≈øecond looking toward the Ea≈øt part of the Archipelago, Ptolemy calls Caphareum Promontorium, Sophianus Chymium, Niger Capo figera, Stephanus Cathereus, Lycophron Zarax, I≈øacius Xylophagos. Upon the Top of this Promontory, Nauplius King of Negropont made fires,
that the Grecian Army returning from Troy, might by the light thereof arrive ≈øafely at the Haven. There was formerly three cities in the I≈øle, which made it famous, Ellopia, Hi≈øtiaea and Oraeus Cities, that were joyned together by rea≈øon of their vicinity.

The Capital City of the Kingdom of Negropont was at fir≈øt called in the Athenian Tongue Calcis; and then it took the name of the Kingdom it ≈øelf. It was once the ≈øeat of a Bi≈øhop, Suffragan to the Arch-Bi≈øhop of Athens; afterwards 'twas rai≈øed to an Arch-Bi≈øhoprick.

'Tis ≈øituated on the banks of the Euripus: The compa≈øs of its walls is about two miles, but there are more hou≈øes and people in the Suburbs, where the Chri≈øtians dwell, than in the City, inhabited by Turks and Jews. The Turks have there two Mo≈øques, and two others without, where the Chri≈øtians al≈øo have their Churches. The Jews have an hou≈øe, where they in≈øtruct the Youth. All the Inhabitants make about 15000. The City is divided from the Suburbs by a great Ditch with a flat bottom, in a ≈ømooth and even ground.

There is a Captain Ba≈øha that commands
the whole I≈øle, and part of Boeotia, who has in his ab≈øence his Kiaja or Lieutenant, and his Subkiaja. There is al≈øo a Bey or Lord, who has ≈øome Revenues, and is obliged to maintain a Galley. At the place where the ≈øtrait of the Euripus is narrowe≈øt to pa≈øs over into the I≈øle, they go over a ≈øtone bridge of five little Arches not above thirty paces long, and ≈øo under a Tower in the middle of the Channel, built by the Venetians, where St. Mark is yet ≈øeen over the Gate. From the Tower to the City is but one Draw-bridge about twenty paces long, built on ≈øharp bottomed boats, which is rai≈øed half to the Tower, and the other half to the City, to give pa≈ø≈øage to the Galleys and other Ve≈ø≈øels, which cannot ea≈øily be done without taking in their Oars.

There is al≈øo to be ≈øeen the Epi≈øcopal City, at pre≈øent called Cari≈ø≈øo, once Chironia, which Strabo names Cari≈øtus and Cari≈øtos, Sophianus Ca≈øtel Ro≈ø≈øo, and the French Chateauroux, it acknowledges Calcis for its Metropolis, being ≈øixty miles di≈øtant. It ≈øtands near Cape Caefareo. There was be≈øides another Epi≈øcopal City Eretria, which Moletius calls
Rocho, which in his time was not le≈øs famous than Calcis, which once was an Athenian Colony built on the banks of the Euripus before the fir≈øt de≈øtruction of Troy: both the≈øe Cities have peri≈øht by the fal≈øne≈øs of their own Inhabitants; So that now their names only remain: They were once pillaged and burnt by Darius.

The ≈øoil of the I≈øle is ≈øtony and ≈øandy, but this is only upon the top, for digging deeper they find it very good. There are ≈øeveral Fore≈øts, where good ≈øhip timber may be cut. Near Cari≈øtus is a Mountain of the ≈øame name of very beautiful marble: And near to it is found the Asbe≈øtos ≈øtone, which may be ≈øpun and made into cloth, which by putting in the fire grows white. There were formerly in the Territory of Calcis Iron and copper Mines, which are now lo≈øt. The I≈øle produces cotton enough to make Sails for a great Navy. There are ≈øeveral hot baths. It is watered with two Rivers, Fimileus and Cereus, of which the Poets ≈øaid, that one made the Sheep have black wool, the other white. In ≈øine the I≈øle abounds in all things; and Pope Pius the fifth advi≈øed ≈øeveral great Captains to go and
begin the War with the Turk in this Kingdom; becau≈øe it is capable of maintaining a whole Army, be≈øides it has good Ports on the ≈øide of the Continent. It is true indeed, that when one is once there, he can by no means get out to ≈øave him≈øelf. There are ≈øeveral places on the South part, the mo≈øt con≈øiderable whereof is called Spiritus.

When Pietro Zani was Doge, the Republick inlarged their Dominions by this beautiful Kingdom, which was yielded to them by the Emperor of Con≈øtantinople, as a reward for the good ≈øervices they had done him. The fir≈øt Governour that was ≈øent was Pictro Barbo, named il Zanco.

Anno 1469. the Turks attempting the Conque≈øt of it, came with three hundred Sail. At fir≈øt they made a Bridge upon the Euripus, that ≈øo they might land their Troops upon the Campaign of the I≈øle; but tho≈øe of the Country ≈øo vigorou≈øly oppo≈øed them, that they were forced to return to their Galleys. Within a a Month Mahomet came him≈øelf with an Army of twelve thou≈øand Men: He made a new Bridge over the Channel, from the Church of St. Mark, a mile off
of the City, and by this means made him≈øelf a way to attach Negropent. This City was in ≈øome ≈øort fortified at that time, and had in it in Garri≈øon twenty four thou≈øand Men under Ludovico Calbo and Paolo Erizzo Commanders. The la≈øt had been Governour of the City, and tho his time was expired, yet he would not leave the place, when he might contribute by his Arms and Coun≈øel, to its defence, and ≈øignalize his zeal for the Service of his Country. The Turks rai≈øed ≈øeveral Batteries in divers places, and continually plaid upon the Walls. And four times march'd to the a≈ø≈øault, where four thou≈øand Turks were killed. The Place was be≈øieged by Sea and Land, and extremely pre≈ø≈øed on all hands; yet the be≈øieged ≈øtill defended them≈øelves with advantage, and had already ≈øu≈øtained a months Siege, when a trea≈øonable practice was di≈øcovered. For a little Girl found a letter, wherein was mentioned the means and way of delivering up the place to the Ottomans. This letter was directed to Thoma≈øo Schiava. Luigi Delfino tran≈øported with indignation again≈øt the Traitor, attacked him
openly, and by meer force made him di≈øcover all the ba≈øe Intrigues he had with the Turks.

The be≈øieged ≈øtill animated more and more in their defence, gave daily notable proofs of their courage and con≈øtancy; but at la≈øt they were almo≈øt wearied out with continual labour and fatigue. In the≈øe extremeties, they, who had the Guard of Porte Bureliana, ran away from their Po≈øt, and left the place the twelfth of July, 1649.

The Enemy ≈øoon perceiving the place de≈øerted, and the entrance of the Gate free for them, entered the Town, and gave in all places dreadful marks of their Barbarity. Calbo was killed in the Place, and Bondulmiero in his hou≈øe. Paolo Erizzo beeing retrenched in an advantageous Po≈øt valiantly defended him≈øelf, and the Sultan promi≈øed him life if he would deliver him≈øelf up, which having done the cruel Turk broke his word, and cau≈øed him to be ≈øawed in two. One of his Daughters a very beautiful Virgin cho≈øe rather to be ≈øtabb'd than receive the Sultans care≈ø≈øes. All were murdered above twenty years old. This done Mahomet left the City
with a Garri≈øon for the Guard of the whole I≈øle and Kingdom.

div.head: Of the Ebb and Flow of the Euripus.
div.p: THe Euripus is a ≈øtrait of the Egaean Sea, ≈øo narrow, that ≈øcarce one Galley can pa≈øs it (under a Bridge that is made over it) between the Cittadel and the Tower or Dungeon of Negropont. It has been called Euripus Eubolcus, from the old name of the I≈øle, or Ghalcidicus from the ancient City Chalcis; the Latins named it Euripus, tho≈øe of the place Egripos, the Italians Stretto di Negreponte, and the French l' Euripe de Chalcidoine, or le detroit de l' Euripe. It is about ≈øixty miles long with little Gulfs in divers places.
Its Ebb and Flow is doubtle≈øs one of the greate≈øt wonders in the World, and it is fabled, that Aristotle drowned him≈øelf in it out of grief that he could not find out the cau≈øe thereof.

Antiphilus, a Native of Bizantium, ≈øays in a Greek Epigram, that the Euripus ri≈øes and falls ≈øix times; Strabo, Pliny
and Suidas, with ≈øeveral others, hold, that it flows and ebbs ≈øeven times a day.

Pomponius Mela a≈ø≈øures us, that this is done fourteen times a day, tho it ≈øeems by his words, that he means, that the Euripus continually ebbs and flows fourteen times in 24 hours. The≈øe are his words, lib. 2. cap. 7. Mare rapidum et alterno cur≈øu ≈øepties nocte fluctibus invicem ver≈øis, adeo immodic√® fluens, ut ventos etiam ac plenis velis navigia fru≈øtretur. That is, the Sea is there very rapid, running ≈øometimes one way, ≈øometimes the other ≈øeven times in a night, and as oft in the day with returning waves, with that violence that they prevail again≈øt the winds, and put a ≈øtop to ≈øhips under Sail.
Seneca ≈øeems to be of the ≈øame Opinion in one of his Tragedies, where he thus ≈øpeaks:
div.q: Euripus undas flectit in≈øtabilis vagas, Septemque cur≈øus flectit, & totidem refert Dum la≈ø≈øa Titan mergat Oceano Juga.
div.l: Swift Euripus receives within his brea≈øt
Seven times the ≈øtoods, as oft are outward pre≈øt,
While Titan drives his weary Steeds to re≈øt.
div.p: It ≈øeems al≈øo that Pliny would expre≈øs the ≈øame, that it flows and ebbs ≈øeven times a day, and as often at night, though his words are not very clear. Quorumdam Aestuariorum privata natura e≈øt, velut Taurominitani ≈øaepius et in Euboea ≈øepties die ac nocte reciprocantis: That is, there are Currents of a very peculiar Nature, as that of the Taurominians, which often goes, and returns, and that of the Euripus, which does ≈øo ≈øeven times in a day and night.

Titus Livius thinks he has hit the truth better, than the re≈øt. The Euripus, ≈øays he, has not ≈øeven regular ebbs and flows in a day, as the common report is, but it runs ≈øometimes one way, ≈øometimes another, like the wind, as a Torrent, falling with precipitation from a mountain. This agrees very well with the irregular days, but he is mi≈øtaken when he adds, that there is no Port wor≈øe, than that of Calcis, by rea≈øon of the
Current; for this ebbing and flowing, does not at all di≈øorder the Ve≈ø≈øels, which have room enough to keep them≈øelves from the Current, either in the great Port, which is covered with the walls of the Cittadel, or in that on the other ≈øide of the Bridge, as Father Babin the Je≈øuit ob≈øerved, Anno 1669. when the Turki≈øh Navy wintered at Negropont.

The ≈øame Father, con≈øidered the cour≈øe of the Euripus, at ≈øeveral times. There are eighteen or nineteen days each month, or to ≈øay better each Moon, whereon 'tis regular; and eleven others, wherein 'tis irregular, and broken. Such are the Terms, they u≈øe at Negropont, to de≈øcribe this wonder of Nature.

It is in its force and vigour, or to ≈øpeak plainer, it is regular from the three la≈øts days of the old Moon, till the eighth of the new, and on the ninth 'tis irregular and broken, and remains ≈øo troubled, till the thirteenth inclu≈øively. On the fourteenth it comes to it ≈øelf again, and re≈øumes its Forces; but grows di≈øorderly again, from the twenty fir≈øt to the 27, as will be better under≈øtood by the following Table.

div.head: A Table of the Regular, and Irregular flowing and ebbing of the Euripus, according to the Age of the Moon.

row.cell: 9. Irregular. of 12. 13. or 14. Ebbs and Flows.
10. Irregular. of 12. 13. or 14. Ebbs and Flows.
11. Irregular. of 12. 13. or 14. Ebbs and Flows.
12. Irregular. of 12. 13. or 14. Ebbs and Flows.
13. Irregular. of 12. 13. or 14. Ebbs and Flows.

div.p: So each Moon there is eleven days of irregularity, and 18 or 19 others, that are regular. It is then irregular from the fir≈øt Quarter, to about the full Moon, and after the la≈øt Quarter it begins again to be irregular.

During the time of its Irregularity in one natural day, that is, in twenty four or twenty five hours, there is eleven, twelve, thirteen, and ≈øometimes fourteen Floods and Ebbs, according to the ob≈øervations of the ≈øame Father; and as tho≈øe a≈ø≈øure us, that are daily at the Mills, and find the wheels alter often in a day, as the Stream turns. So that the Flood does not come only ≈øeven times in a day, as the Ancients wrote, but much frequenter.

When the Cour≈øe of the Euripus is regular for the other eighteen or
nineteen days; 'tis like the Ocean, and Gulf of Venice, that is in twenty four, or twenty five hours, it has but two Floods and Ebbs, and every day retards it one hour; as in the Ocean, it is ≈øix hours coming in, and as long going out, whether in Summer, or whether the wind be violent or calm. On the irregular days, it flows about half an hour, and ebbs three quarters of an hour.

All the Tides of the Euripus, whether regular, or irregular, differ in two particulars, from tho≈øe of the Ocean; fir≈øt, that in high water, it ri≈øes not above one Foot, and very rarely two, whereas the Ocean ri≈øes ≈øometimes eighty cubits, as in the Ports of Britain, though in the I≈øles of America, it mounts not higher, than in the Euripus.

The other difference, is that in the Ocean, when the water ≈øinks and abates, it retires into the deep Sea, as on the contrary, it rai≈øes it ≈øelf, and covers more ground, when it approaches the ≈øides. The Euripus is quite after another manner, for its Flood happens, when its waters run towards the I≈øles of the Archipelago, where is a much
greater Sea; and its Ebb is when it runs towards The≈ø≈øaly, and through the Channel, by which the Galleys pa≈øs to go towards The≈ø≈øalonica, as a ≈øhorter and ≈øafer way to Con≈øtantinople.

Between high and low water, there is a ≈øhort interval, when the water ≈øeems quiet and ≈øtill, and like ≈øtanding water ≈øo that ≈øtraws and feathers lie upon the water without motion, provided there be no wind.
Cae≈øar d' Arcons, who printed in French a Book in Quarto, concerning the Ebb and Flow of the Sea, has a particular Paragraph of the Tides of the Euripus.

D. The Towers flanking the Fortre≈øs.
F. The ≈øides of the Gulf of Volo.

div.head: The Fortre≈øs of Volo.
div.p:
THE Fortre≈øs of Volo, known to the Latins by the name of Paga≈øa, is ≈øituated in that Part of The≈ø≈øaly, which is mo≈øt joyned to Magne≈øia, a ≈ømall Country of Maoedonia, nine miles from Dimetrias; or as Livy and Pliny Demetrias and at the edge of the Gulf commonly called del Volo. Pliny names it Paga≈øi ‚Ä¢
cus ≈øinus, Pela≈øgicus ≈øinus, Ptolemy Paga≈øi ‚Ä¢
licus, Strabo Paga≈øaeus, Mela Jolciacus, O ‚Ä¢
vid Demetriacus, Lucio Macedonicus, Oro ‚Ä¢
≈øius Golfe d' Armiro.

The Fortre≈øs is built after the old fa≈øhion, and takes up a great ≈øpace, a few paces from the Sea, where it has a larg ‚Ä¢ Port, and of good Anchorage. I ‚Ä¢ is according to Bleau. vol. 2. l. 7. pag. 9. Bleau at 31 deg. 31 min Lat. and according to Ca≈øt aldo ‚Ä¢
at forty deg. fifty min. lat. and forty eight deg. forty min. Longitude.

div.head: The Gulf and City of Salonichi or The≈ø≈øalonica.
div.p:
THE Gulf of Salonichi has an Extent of 140 Miles length; it is bounded by a very beautiful Plain, whence it is nece≈ø≈øarily expo≈øed to the Winds, and therefore very dangerous to the Sea-man: In that Place where it mo≈øt wears away the Land, is a very advantageous and ≈øpacious Port. There
is ≈øituated, partly on an Hill, and partly on a Declivity, as the Ground goes, the famous City of Macedonia, called u≈øually Salonichi, or otherwi≈øe The≈ø≈øalonique; near it, on the We≈øt ≈øide, glides down the River Vardar, which Ptolemy and Strabo call Axius Fluvius, others Bardarus and Bardarius Fluvius, very full of Fi≈øh, and its Banks covered and adorned with goodly Trees. The Walls of the City are flanked with ≈øeveral Towers, and as to its circuit ≈øome make it ten, others twelve miles. It has three Forts to defend it; the fir≈øt, being the lea≈øt, comes fir≈øt in view at the Entrance or Landing-Place at ≈øome di≈øtance from the old City; 'tis Mouted with 20 great Guns. The two others are ≈øituated within View of the Sea, at the highe≈øt Part of the Wall, furni≈øhed with 30 or 40 Cannon; on the Land ≈øide is a Fortre≈øs like that of the ≈øeven Towers at Con≈øtantinople; this commands the whole Town, being built on a little Hill, at the Foot whereof is a very great Number of Hou≈øes making a Suburbs, encompa≈ø≈øed with a Wall apart, but which joyns to the City.

There are in this place a numerous
People, and the great Number of Habitations that are built in the Plain are but low and ba≈øe, and not ≈øufficient to contain the great Numbers of Jews that dwell in them: Be≈øides they are not a little incommoded by the horrid ≈øtink that is in the Streets, they are ≈øo narrow.

There is a con≈øiderable Trade, as well from the commodiou≈øne≈øs of its Situation, as for the great Quantity of Silk, Wool, Skins of all ≈øorts, Wax, Gun-powder, Corn, Cotton, and Iron. The Jews mo≈øt bu≈øy them≈øelves in Traffick, and have to them≈øelves the Manufacture of Stuffs to cloath the Janizaries; and by this means they find a Way to employ the Tribute they are obliged to pay the Grand Seignior. There are in it 48 Mo≈øques, in which is comprehended the Church of St. Demetrius, of three Iles, born up with very fair Pillars, where St. Paul Preached once; and that of St. Sophia, built by the Emperour, Ju≈øtinian, thirty Greek Churches, thirty ≈øix great Synagogues, and many other ≈ømall ones. The Governour has the Title of Mul√†, and his Place makes him very con≈øiderable at the Port.

In the Year 118, when Andronicus would have got the Empire, The≈ø≈øalonica was taken by William, King of Sicily; but at the end, being returned under the Dominion of its lawful Soveraign, the Emperour of Con≈øtantinople, Andronicus Paleologus; he, to unite him≈øelf the more nearly to the Venetian Republick, gave them all the Right he had to this City: But ≈øcarce two years pa≈øt e're the Turk ≈øeized on it without much Difficulty, by rea≈øon of its Di≈øtance, and the ill State of Affairs in Italy, and the ≈ømall Defence the Inhabitants were able to make.

div.head: The Gulf, and the Dardanelles of LEPANTO.
div.p:
THIS Gulf reaching on the North to the Shores of Achaia, and on the South to tho≈øe of the Morea, divides from each other the≈øe two great Parts of Greece. It has had ≈øeveral Names which Authors have given it according to the different Times and particular Occa≈øions they had to ≈øpeak of it.
The Ancients called it Cri ‚Ä¢ ≈øus; Strabo, the Sea of Alcion; Sophianus, Golfe de Pedras; ≈øome, Corintiacus Sinus, from the City Corinth; the Mariners, (as Niger reports) the Shores of the Bo≈øtria, and now commonly Lepanto: It contains four Rocks in it, and receives its Water from the Ionian Sea by an Entrance between two Promontories, ≈øtanding far out from the Continent, whereof one joyning to the Morea, is by Strabo called Anthirium Promontorium, and u≈øually Cape Antirio, upon the top of which is a Fortre≈øs called of Morea, or of Patras; the other joyning to Achaia, which Strabo calls Rhium Promontorium; and the Vulgar, Cap de Rhio, or Rio; this al≈øo is provided with a Fort called Romelie.

The≈øe two Ca≈øtles are otherwi≈øe called the Dardanelles of Lepanto: They are both built of a ≈øquare Figure, encompa≈ø≈øed with good Walls, and a ≈øtrong Battery, level with the Water; there is no Fault to be found with them, but that the Ground being Sandy, they admit of an ea≈øy Approach from the Enemy. There is no landing any Forces on the ≈øide of Romelie, within two
Italian Miles of the Fortre≈øs, but it may be approached in ≈ømall Barks within 100 Paces. The Plain to the little Hill is very large, but it grows le≈øs and le≈øs as you come nearer to the Ca≈øtle. At the Foot of the Mountain is a great Valley, where tho≈øe that de≈øign to attack the Fort may march forward undi≈øcovered.

All Merchandi≈øes brought out of the Gulf, as Skins, Oyls, Tabaco, Rice, and Barly, pay three per cent. to the Emin, who is likewi≈øe obliged to di≈øbur≈øe ≈øix thou≈øand Crowns a year, into the Coffers of the Grand Seignior.

Once all Merchandi≈øes that came from the We≈øt, as likewi≈øe tho≈øe from the Ea≈øt, after having pa≈ø≈øed the Gulf of Engia, were brought into this Port; but at this time the Entrance is forbid to all ≈øtranger Ships, which upon that Account are obliged to ≈øtay at Patras; and the mo≈øt of tho≈øe that put in here are Cor≈øairs, and indeed one calls Lepanto the little Algiers. The greate≈øt part of the Inhabitants of this Place are Moors that have black Children like tho≈øe of Barbary.

div.head: The City of Lepanto.
div.p: THE City of Lepanto is by the Latins called Naupactus; by the Vulgar, Epactos; and by the Turks, Einebachti; 'tis ≈øituated in the Country of Livadia, on the Edge, not far from the Mouth of the Gulf of the ≈øame Name, invironed with an high conical Mountain, on the Top of which is built a Fortre≈øs with four ≈øtrong thick Walls round it, ≈øeparated from each other by little Di≈øtances, where the Inhabitants have their Dwellings; the Port is not above 60 Foot big, and which may be ≈øhut up with a Chain being but narrow at its Entrance, upon which Account, but a few Ve≈ø≈øels can lie there; and at ≈øometimes al≈øo they cannot get out of it for want of Water: And if the famous Pirate, Durach Bey, u≈øed to ≈øhelter him≈øelf there with his Galleys, he mu≈øt have taken a ≈øpecial Care to keep it clear.
Under the Empire of the Turks 'tis governed by a Vaivode. There are ≈øeven Mo≈øques, two Greek Churches which are held in great Di≈ødain by the Turks, and three Jewi≈øh Synagogues.

If the Inhabitants want plea≈øant Places within the Town, they have, without, on the Ea≈øt ≈øide near the Sea, a plentiful Stream of Water, which after having ≈øerved the Powder-Mills and the Tanners of Leather, in which con≈øi≈øts the Riches of the Place, waters about a dozen very great Plains, and makes the Place very delightful. There is likewi≈øe round about very plea≈øant Gardens and Fields covered with Limons and Orange Trees: The Soil produces a Wine that ≈øurpa≈ø≈øes all the Greek Wines in Goodne≈øs.

The taking of this Place was very Difficult, before the U≈øe of great Guns. In the Year 1408, it was ≈øubject to the Emperour of Con≈øtantinople, but the Emperour, Emanuel, finding it too hard
a Task for him to keep it, delivered it into the Hands of the Republick of Venice. Under this new Dominion, it received a new Form, and was fortified ≈øo as to be able to re≈øi≈øt a powerful Army; and indeed, being be≈øieged anno 1475, it de≈øtroied thirty thou≈øand Turks, and their Army was forced ≈øhamefully to rai≈øe the Siege, after having ≈øate down before it above four Months. The Inhabitants could not be better plea≈øed with their Rulers, nor ever made more ardent Vows to be kept there and pre≈øerved from the barbarous Tyranny of the Turks, when Bajazet, 2. came to attack them by Sea and Land, with an Army of an hundred and fifty thou≈øand men, and brought them to the mo≈øt deplorable State that can be imagined. There is yet to be ≈øeen St. Mark of Venice, to ≈øhew us, that the Rights of the Republick are as well founded there as its Arms ineffaceable; and to give us Hopes, that triumphant Republick will add to the Conque≈øts it has made the≈øe la≈øt Years, that of this Place; which will be crowned with Glory and immortal Fame.
